TEXT.English: [TAB]Warfare has been a recurring phenomenon throughout the history of mankind, and it continues to plague the world today. Although war is not a desirable situation, it is important that even the most peaceful of societies be prepared for the possibility of war. When warring nations are closely matched in technology and manpower, the army with the best training usually wins battles. Military schools and academies exist all over the world, established for the purpose of training military personnel in the latest methods, tactics, and technology. Men and women who graduate from such facilities possess higher than average command and military and technological skills, making them more effective in combat situations.
TEXT.Chinese: 战争是人类历史上频繁出现的现象，直到今天仍给人类制造着灾难。尽管战争并非人们所愿，但即便是最和平的社会也要随时防备着它的来临。当交战国在科技和人力方面相匹敌时，更训练有素的军队通常能赢得战斗。军事院校今天已遍布世界，其建立的目的是为了用最新的方法，战术，科技培训军事人员。军事学院的毕业生拥有更高水准的指挥，军事和科技技能，从而使他们在战场环境中的能力更强。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A plantation is a long, artificially-established forest, farm or estate, where crops are grown for sale, often in distant markets rather than for local on-site consumption. Plantations are developed on a large scale as the crops are grown for commercial purposes, not for local consumption.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]种植园是一种长期的人工建立的森林、农场或庄园，种植作物是为了销售，通常是在遥远的市场上，而不是为了当地的现场消费。种植园是大规模发展的，因为作物是为商业目的而不是为当地消费而种植的。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Temple of Kukulkan (also known as El Castillo or the Temple of Quetzalcoatl) is one of the best-known Mayan buildings in Chichen Itza. The structure itself is a typical four-sided step temple, but at its base rests stone pillars carved with feathered serpents (revealing the strong Toltec/Aztec influence). Many archeologists believe that its design is based upon the Mayan calendar, since each stairway has 90 steps. Add the total steps to the number of stairways plus the top platform, and you reach the number of 365 (the number of days in [our] typical calendar year).
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]库库尔坎神庙（也称为埃尔卡斯蒂略或格查尔科特神庙）是奇琴伊察最著名的玛雅建筑之一。这座建筑本身是一座典型的四面台阶式寺庙，但其底部有雕刻有羽毛蛇的石柱（显示出托尔特克/阿兹特克强大的影响力）。许多考古学家认为它的设计是基于玛雅历法，因为每个楼梯有90级台阶。把总台阶数加上楼梯数加上顶部平台，你就达到了365（我们典型日历年的天数）。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A constitution is a set of fundamental principles or established precedents according to which a state or other organization is governed. These rules together make up, i.e. constitute, what the entity is. When these principles are written down into a single document or set of legal documents, those documents may be said to embody a written constitution; if they are written down in a single comprehensive document, it is said to embody a codified constitution. Some constitutions (such as the constitution of the United Kingdom) are uncodified, but written in numerous fundamental Acts of a legislature, court cases or treaties.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]What is sometimes called the "enlightened constitution" model was developed by philosophers of the Age of Enlightenment such as Thomas Hobbes, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, and John Locke. The model proposed that constitutional governments should be stable, adaptable, accountable, open and should represent the people (i.e., support democracy). The United States Constitution, ratified June 21, 1788, was influenced by the writings of Polybius, Locke, Montesquieu, and others. The document became a benchmark for republicanism and codified constitutions written thereafter.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]宪法是一套基本原则或既定先例，根据这些原则或先例，一个国家或其他组织受到管辖。这些规则一起构成，即构成，实体是什么。当这些原则被写进一个文件或一套法律文件中时，可以说这些文件体现了一部成文的宪法；如果这些原则被写进一个综合性文件中，则可以说是体现了一部法典化的宪法。有些宪法（如英国宪法）是未经修改的，但在立法机关、法院案件或条约的许多基本法案中都有明文规定。[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]有时被称为“开明宪法”的模式是由启蒙时代的哲学家如托马斯霍布斯提出的，卢梭和洛克。该模式建议，宪政政府应稳定、适应性强、负责任、公开，并应代表人民（即支持民主）。1788年6月21日批准的美国宪法受到波利比乌斯、洛克、孟德斯鸠等著作的影响。该文件成为共和主义的基准，并编纂了此后的宪法。

TEXT.English: [H1]Zara Yaqob[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of Ethiopia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.1399 - 1468 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Zara Yaqob was Emperor of Ethiopia from 1434 until 1468. A member of the Solomonic Dynasty, which traced its heritage back to the Biblical King Solomon, Zara Yaqob was an extremely devout, if occasionally draconian, ruler. Confined to the Amba Geshen prison for the early years of his life due to being a potential threat to his brother Tewodros's grip on the throne, Zara Yaqob only gained monarchal power in 1434 after his brother's death.[PARAGRAPH:2]As a highly religious leader, Zara Yaqob introduced many reformations and innovations in daily living based off his beliefs. Christmas was celebrated monthly in addition to many other feasts and celebrations. All thirty three festivals to the Virgin Mary were celebrated as if they were on the Sabbath, regardless of the actual day of the week on which they fell.[PARAGRAPH:2]Zara Yaqob was strict in his religious beliefs. Citizens who did not rigidly follow the prescripts of the Christian Church and adorn themselves with religious markings were put to death. If a person admitted to, or was accused of, worshipping the devil (or another non-Christian god), they were put to death. Even Zara Yaqob's own family was not sheltered from these punishments. Several were beaten and put to death, including his own wife, in an effort to give credibility to his harsh punishments, which were widely criticized.[PARAGRAPH:2]After a conspiracy organized by one of his subordinates came to light early in his reign, Zara Yaqob started exhibiting signs of paranoia. He began replacing all of his higher officials with female family members whom he felt he could trust. The emperor eventually attempted to appoint his own sisters, daughters and nieces to various governorships. Due to this paranoia, Zara Yaqob's reign is distinguished as being uniquely female dominated in a time when men traditionally held the majority of social power.[PARAGRAPH:2]Zara Yaqob also sent several diplomatic missions into Europe and India in both an attempt to create alliances against the rising Middle Eastern Islamic powers and to bring skilled workers and artisans into his country.[PARAGRAPH:2]Known mostly for his draconian religious laws, Zara Yaqob none the less was a practical leader and managed to protect Ethiopian interests from outside influence for the duration of his reign. Several of his progressive writings on religion, including the Mashafa Berha and the Mashafa Milad, are still available today.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]札拉·雅各布[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]埃塞俄比亚国王[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]生卒年份:[\BOLD]约1399-1468[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]背景:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]扎拉·雅各布是从1434年到1468年统治埃塞俄比亚的皇帝，属于所罗门王朝，这个家族可以上溯到圣经中的所罗门王。扎拉·雅各布是一位极其虔诚甚至严苛的统治者。早年时，由于雅各布对他的哥哥特沃德罗斯取得王座有着潜在威胁，因此他被囚禁于安巴监狱，直到1434年，他的哥哥死后，扎拉·雅各布才取得了国王的权利。[PARAGRAPH:1]作为一名十分虔诚的领导人，扎拉·雅各布基于他的信仰，在日常生活中引入了许多改革和创新。圣诞节每月都要举行一次，再加上许多其它的盛宴和节日。所有的33个纪念圣母玛利亚的节日都要被庆祝，就好像它们总是在安息日一样，而不管它们具体是在哪一个星期。[PARAGRAPH:1]扎拉·雅各布对他的宗教信仰的执行十分严格。没有严格执行基督教堂指示或没有用宗教标志装饰自己的市民都要被处死。如果一个人承认，或是被指控崇拜恶魔（或是其他非基督教的神灵），也要被处以死刑。即使是扎拉·雅各布的族人，也不能免于惩罚，一些人被责打并处死，包括他自己的妻子，这种行为是为了给他的这种广受指责的惩处措施一种公信力。[PARAGRAPH:1]在他早年的时候，一起由下属发起的针对他的阴谋被曝光，使得扎拉·雅各布开始表现出一种偏执狂的状态。他将所有的高层官员都替换为他认为值得他信赖的女性。这个皇帝甚至打算任命他的妹妹、女儿和侄女成为各种政府官员。因为这种偏执狂的表现，扎拉·雅各布的政府同其他的政府截然不同：女性占据了本来由男性主导的全部统治地位。[PARAGRAPH:1]扎拉·雅各布同时也向欧洲和印度派去了几个外交官员，试图寻求联盟，以对抗日益崛起的中东伊斯兰势力，并将熟练工人和艺术家带到他的国家来。[PARAGRAPH:1]尽管更多的是因为他严厉的宗教法令而闻名，扎拉·雅各布同时也是一位有作为的领导人，在他的统治期间，他在外来势力的影响下努力保护着埃塞俄比亚的利益。他的一些宗教上的进步著作，包括《光书》和《诞生书》，现在我们仍然可以读到。

TEXT.English: [H1]Cyrus II the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Kings of Persia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.576 - 529 BC[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Cyrus was the first Emperor of Persia (which occupied about the same land upon which Iran now stands). He is known as a great warlord and a great ruler. He created one of the largest empires the world had seen, and he ruled his subjects with fairness and compassion. Cyrus also founded Pasargade, the capital city of Persia.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the time of Cyrus's birth, Iran was divided between two major tribes: the Persians and the Medes. Ascending to the Persian throne, Cyrus conquered the Medes. He joined the two tribes together, creating the country of Persia. To ensure full cooperation of the newly-conquered Medes, he allowed their nobles to become government officials and gave them equal status with the Persian nobility.[PARAGRAPH:2]Once he had secured Persia, Cyrus turned his attention to the east. He conquered Drangiana, Arachosia, Margiana, and Bactra. He built a series of fortified towns along the border to secure his flank and protect his empire from the nomads of Asia. He then turned west, conquering mighty Babylon.[PARAGRAPH:2]As a civil leader, Cyrus was progressive far beyond his time. He left the institutions in conquered lands alone, allowing the people to largely govern themselves. He didn't meddle with local religions, and he tried to put an end to religious persecution - when he conquered Babylon, the Jews there welcomed him as liberator. In fact, he freed about 40,000 Jews from bondage in Babylon, allowing them to return to their homes in Palestine.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the early part of his rule, Cyrus issued a decree on his objectives. This decree is now recognized as the first declaration of human rights. When he died, Cyrus was mourned by millions, including his conquered subjects. The Hellenes called him "Law Giver," and the Jews named him the "Anointed of the Lord."
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]居鲁士[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]波斯国王[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]生卒年份：[\BOLD]约前576-前529年7月[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]背景:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]居鲁士是第一位波斯国王（古代的波斯地区今属伊朗）。他是位杰出的军事家，也是位伟大的统治者。他建立了历史上面积最广阔的帝国之一，他对臣民的统治则公正而仁慈。居鲁士也是波斯都城帕萨尔加达的建立者。[PARAGRAPH:1]在居鲁士出生的时代，今伊朗地区分为两个主要部族：波斯和米底亚。在成为波斯人的领袖之后，居鲁士征服了米底亚人。他将这两个部族结为一体，成为统一的波斯王国。为了巩固在新征服的米底亚的统治，他允许米底亚贵族担任政府官职，给予他们与波斯贵族同等的待遇。[PARAGRAPH:1]完成波斯的统一之后，居鲁士的目光转向东方。陆续征服了德兰格亚那、阿拉霍西亚、马吉安那和巴克特里亚。此后居鲁士沿东方边境建造了许多城池要塞，确保他的帝国免受亚洲游牧民族的侵扰。接下来他的目标又转向西方，并征服了强大的巴比伦。[PARAGRAPH:1]在治理国家方面，居鲁士的思想超越了他的时代。他允许被征服地区保留原有制度，允许各族臣民自己进行管理。他从不干涉当地人的信仰，并努力制止各种宗教迫害行为——在他征服巴比伦时，当地的犹太人将他视为解放者。事实上，他释放了被掳到巴比伦为奴的40000名犹太人，并允许他们返回巴勒斯坦故乡。[PARAGRAPH:1]在执政初期，居鲁士向全体臣民颁布了一道法令。这道法令被人们称作是最古老的人权宣言。居鲁士去世后得到了无数人的哀悼，包括被他所征服的民族。希腊人称他为“立法者”，犹太人称他为“受主眷顾的人”。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A nemeton is a sacred place of the ancient Celtic religion. Nemeta are typically thought of as outdoor spaces in which druids would perform ceremonies. However, there is evidence that nemeta took a variety of forms, including ritual enclosures, shrines, and temples. Several toponyms in modern Europe derive from the word "nemeton".
TEXT.Chinese: 尼美顿是古代凯尔特宗教的圣地。尼梅塔通常被认为是德鲁伊举行仪式的户外场所。然而，有证据表明，尼梅塔采取了多种形式，包括宗教围栏、神殿和寺庙。现代欧洲有几个地名来源于“nemeton”一词。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Tokyo Metropolitan Central Wholesale Market, commonly known as the Tsukiji fish market is the biggest wholesale fish and seafood market in the world and also one of the biggest markets of any kind in the world.[PARAGRAPH:2]The market handles more than 400 different types of seafood from tiny sardines to 300kg tuna, from cheap seaweed to the most expensive caviar. Overall, more than 700,000 metric tons of seafood are handled every year at the three seafood markets in Tokyo, with a total value in excess of 600 billion yen (approximately 6 billion US dollars). Tsukiji alone handles over 2000 metric tons of seafood per day.[PARAGRAPH:2]The first market in Tokyo was established by Tokugawa Ieyasu during the Edo period to provide food for Edo castle (nowadays Tokyo). Tokugawa Ieyasu invited fishermen from Tsukudajima, Osaka to Edo in order to provide fish for the castle. Fish not bought by the castle was sold near the Nihonbashi bridge, at a market called uogashi (literally, "fish quay") which was one of many specialized wholesale markets that lined the canals of Edo (as Tokyo was known until the 1870s).
TEXT.Chinese: 东京都会批发市场，俗称“土基集鱼市场”，是世界上最大的鱼肉批发市场，也是世界上最大的市场之一。[第2段]市场处理了400多种不同类型的沙丁油鱼，从小沙丁鱼到300公斤金枪鱼，从便宜的海藻到最贵的鱼子酱。总的来说，东京三个海鲜市场每年处理的海鲜超过70万公吨，总价值超过6000亿日元（约60亿美元）。慈济每天只处理超过2000公吨的海鲜。[段落：2 ]东京第一个市场是在江户时期由Tokugawa Ieyasu建立的，为江户堡提供食物（现在的东京）。德川怡安邀请大阪筑田岛的渔民到江户，为城堡提供鱼。城堡里没有买的鱼是在日本桥附近的一个叫uogashi（字面意思是“鱼码头”）的市场出售的，这个市场是江户运河沿岸的许多专业批发市场之一（直到19世纪70年代，东京都是这样）。

TEXT.English: [H1]Trading Companies[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]If you are either Portugal, Spain, France, England or the Netherlands, building the Trading Company triggers an event that gives you the opportunity to expand your colonial empire into South Asia. The event selects a number of target cities and gives you the choice to either attempt to acquire them by investing money or raising an army. In case of the former, the owning civ can decline your gold offer, which means the gold is lost. In case of the latter, you lose population and happiness in your capital (similar to drafting), armies appear close to the target cities and you enter war with their owners. If the target areas are empty, you get a settler there instead. AI civilizations get the same opportunity by discovering Astronomy and Gunpowder (Portugal and Spain) or Economics and Rifling (France, England and Netherlands), without building a Trading Company. [NEWLINE]The target areas of each civilization are as follows: [BOLD]Portugal:[\BOLD] three (five for the AI) cities out of Sao Salvador, Quelimane, Muscat, Goa, Cochin, Malacca and Canton [BOLD]Spain:[\BOLD] always Manila [BOLD]France:[\BOLD] one city in South India [BOLD]England:[\BOLD] three cities in India [BOLD]Netherlands:[\BOLD] three cities in Indonesia
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]贸易公司[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]当你控制葡萄牙、西班牙、法国、英国或者荷兰时，建造贸易公司会使你的帝国向南亚殖民。事件会让你控制一定数量的城市并且让你在金钱投资和建立军队之间做出抉择。若选择前者，城市所在的原有文明可能会拒绝你的要求，这就意味着金钱的损失。若选择后者，你的首都将使人口和幸福指数下降（类似于征兵），军队将会出现在目标城市的附近，你将会立即与目标城市的文明开战。如果目标区域没有城市，你将立即在那里获得一队移民。AI控制的文明在发现光学（葡萄牙和西班牙）或经济学(法国，英国和荷兰)后便能触发此事件，无需建造贸易公司[NEWLINE] 以下是每个文明的归属地区： [BOLD]葡萄牙：[\BOLD] 萨尔瓦多（Sao Salvador）、克利马内（Quelimane）、马斯喀特（Muscat）、果阿邦（Goa）、科钦（Cochin）、马六甲（Malacca）和广州（Canton）中的三座城市 (AI是四座) [BOLD]西班牙：[\BOLD] 马尼拉 [BOLD]法国：[\BOLD] 南印度的一座城市 [BOLD]英国：[\BOLD] 印度的三座城市 [BOLD]荷兰：[\BOLD] 印度尼西亚的三座城市

TEXT.English: [TAB]The territory of what is now Colombia was originally inhabited by indigenous peoples including the Muisca, Quimbaya, and Tairona. The Spanish arrived in 1499 and initiated a period of conquest and colonization ultimately creating the Viceroyalty of New Granada, with its capital at Bogotá. Independence from Spain was won in 1819, but by 1830 "Gran Colombia" had collapsed with the secession of Venezuela and Ecuador. What is now Colombia and Panama emerged as the Republic of New Granada. The new nation experimented with federalism as the Granadine Confederation (1858), and then the United States of Colombia (1863), before the Republic of Colombia was finally declared in 1886. Panama seceded in 1903.[PARAGRAPH:2]Since the 1960s, the country has suffered from an asymmetric low-intensity armed conflict. The conflict escalated in the 1990s, but since 2000 the conflict has decreased considerably.[PARAGRAPH:2]Colombia is ethnically diverse, and the interaction between descendants of the original native inhabitants, Spanish colonists, Africans originally brought to the country as slaves, and 20th-century immigrants from Europe and the Middle East, has produced a rich cultural heritage. This has also been influenced by Colombia's varied geography, and the imposing landscape of the country has resulted in the development of very strong regional identities, in many cases stronger than the national. The majority of the urban centers are located in the highlands of the Andes mountains, but Colombian territory also encompasses Amazon rainforest, tropical grassland and both Caribbean and Pacific coastlines.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]现在哥伦比亚的领土最初由土著人民居住，包括穆伊斯卡人、昆巴亚人和泰罗纳人。西班牙人于1499年来到这里，开始了一段征服和殖民时期，最终建立了首都位于波哥大的新格拉纳达总督府。1819年脱离西班牙获得独立，但到1830年，“格兰哥伦比亚”随着委内瑞拉和厄瓜多尔的分裂而崩溃。现在的哥伦比亚和巴拿马成为了新格拉纳达共和国。在1886年哥伦比亚共和国最终宣布成立之前，这个新国家曾尝试过联邦制，比如1858年的格拉纳丁联邦，1863年的哥伦比亚合众国。巴拿马于1903脱离。[段：2 ]自20世纪60年代以来，该国遭受了一场非对称的低强度武装冲突。冲突在20世纪90年代升级，但自2000以来，冲突大大减少。[段落：2 ]哥伦比亚是种族多样的，原始土著居民的后代、西班牙殖民者、非洲人最初作为奴隶被带到该国，以及来自欧洲和中东的二十世纪移民之间的相互作用，产生了丰富的文化遗产。这也受到哥伦比亚不同地理环境的影响，该国壮丽的地貌导致了非常强烈的区域特征的发展，在许多情况下比国家特征更强烈。大多数城市中心位于安第斯山脉的高地，但哥伦比亚的领土还包括亚马逊雨林、热带草原以及加勒比和太平洋海岸线。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A national gallery is a country's major public art gallery. With different names, they are widespread in almost every nation capital. They are a space for the exhibition of art, usually visual art, and usually primarily paintings, illustrations, and sculpture. The art museum is considered a fairly modern invention, the first being the Louvre in Paris, which was established in 1793, soon after the French Revolution when the royal treasures were declared for the people.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]国家美术馆是一个国家的主要公共美术馆。它们有着不同的名字，在几乎每个国家的首都都很普遍。它们是一个展示艺术的空间，通常是视觉艺术，通常主要是绘画、插图和雕塑。艺术博物馆被认为是一项相当现代的发明，第一个是巴黎的卢浮宫，建于1793年，在法国大革命后不久，当时皇室的珍宝是为人民申报的。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A lake is an area (prototypically filled with water, also of variable size), localized in a basin, that is surrounded by land apart from any river or other outlet that serves to feed or drain the lake. Lakes lie on land and are not part of the ocean, and therefore are distinct from lagoons, and are also larger and deeper than ponds, though there are no official or scientific definitions. Lakes can be contrasted with rivers or streams, which are usually flowing. However most lakes are fed and drained by rivers and streams.[PARAGRAPH:1]Natural lakes are generally found in mountainous areas, rift zones, and areas with ongoing glaciation. Other lakes are found in endorheic basins or along the courses of mature rivers. In some parts of the world there are many lakes because of chaotic drainage patterns left over from the last Ice Age. All lakes are temporary over geologic time scales, as they will slowly fill in with sediments or spill out of the basin containing them.[PARAGRAPH:1]Many lakes are artificial and are constructed for industrial or agricultural use, for hydro-electric power generation or domestic water supply, or for aesthetic or recreational purposes.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]湖泊是指位于盆地中的一个区域（原为充满水的区域，大小也不一），其周围是陆地，而不包括任何河流或其他用于给湖泊供水或排水的出口。湖泊位于陆地上，不是海洋的一部分，因此不同于泻湖，也比池塘大和深，尽管没有官方或科学的定义。湖泊可以与通常流动的河流或溪流形成对比。然而，大多数湖泊被河流和溪流所喂养和排水。[段落：1 ]自然湖泊一般存在于山区、裂谷带和正在进行冰川作用的地区。其他湖泊则分布在内陆海盆地或成熟河流沿岸。由于上一次冰河时代遗留下来的混乱的排水模式，世界上有些地方有许多湖泊。所有的湖泊都是在地质时间尺度上的临时性的，因为它们会慢慢地填满沉积物或溢出含有它们的盆地。〔段落：1〕许多湖泊是人工的，它们被建造用于工业或农业用途，用于水力发电或生活供水，或用于审美或娱乐目的。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A steamship, often referred to as a steamer, is a type of steam powered vessel, typically ocean-faring and seaworthy, that is propelled by one or more steam engines that typically move (turn) propellers or paddlewheels. The first steamships came into practical usage during the early 1800s; however, there were exceptions that came before. Steamships usually use the prefix designations of "PS" for paddle steamer or "SS" for screw steamer (using a propeller or screw). As paddle steamers became less common, "SS" is assumed by many to stand for "steam ship". Ships powered by internal combustion engines use a prefix such as "MV" for motor vessel, so it is not correct to use "SS" for most modern vessels.[PARAGRAPH:2]As steamships were less dependent on wind patterns, new trade routes opened up. The steamship has been described as a "major driver of the first wave of trade globalization (1870鈥?913)" and contributor to "an increase in international trade that was unprecedented in human history".[PARAGRAPH:2]The steamship was preceded by smaller vessels designed for insular transportation, called steamboats. Once the technology of steam was mastered at this level, steam engines were mounted on larger, and eventually, ocean-going vessels. Becoming reliable, and propelled by screw rather than paddlewheels, the technology changed the design of ships for faster, more economic propulsion.[PARAGRAPH:2]Paddlewheels as the main motive source became standard on these early vessels. It was an effective means of propulsion under ideal conditions but otherwise had serious drawbacks. The paddle-wheel performed best when it operated at a certain depth, however when the depth of the ship changed from added weight it further submerged the paddle wheel causing a substantial decrease in performance.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]蒸汽船，通常被称为蒸汽船，是一种蒸汽动力船舶，典型的远洋性和适航性，由一个或多个蒸汽机推动，通常移动（转动）螺旋桨或桨轮。第一艘蒸汽船在19世纪初开始实际使用；然而，以前也有例外。轮船通常使用前缀“PS”表示桨式轮船，或“SS”表示螺旋式轮船（使用螺旋桨或螺钉）。随着桨式蒸汽船变得越来越不常见，许多人认为“SS”代表“蒸汽船”。内燃机驱动的船舶使用一个前缀，例如“MV”用于机动船，所以对于大多数现代船舶来说，使用“SS”是不正确的。[段落：2 ]由于蒸汽船较少依赖于风模式，新的贸易路线打开了。轮船被描述为“贸易全球化的第一次浪潮（1870—1913）的主要驱动者”，并为“人类历史上前所未有的国际贸易增加”做出贡献。[胡：第2段]汽船之前是为岛屿运输而设计的小型船只，名为蒸汽船。一旦蒸汽技术掌握在这一水平，蒸汽机就被安装在更大的，最终，远洋船只上。这项技术变得可靠，并用螺钉而不是轮子推进，改变了船的设计，以更快、更经济的推进。[段落：2 ] Paddlewheels是主要的动力源，成为这些早期船只的标准。它是理想条件下的一种有效推进手段，但在其他方面有严重的缺点。当桨轮在一定的深度下工作时，表现最好，但是当船的深度从增加的重量改变时，它进一步淹没桨轮，导致性能大幅度下降。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Pir refers to a site of pilgrimage of the Zoroastrian faith. Pirs range from localized devotional sites to major centers of worship. Among the most well-known pirs are the six mountain pir which can be found in and around the city of Yazd, Iran. However, pirs can be found in cities throughout the Persian world including Kerman, Shiraz and Tehran.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]Pir是指拜火教教徒朝圣的地方。Pirs的范围从局部的宗教场所到主要的礼拜中心。其中最著名的pir是伊朗亚兹德市及其周边地区的六座山pir。然而，皮尔斯可以在波斯世界的城市中找到，包括科尔曼，设拉子和德黑兰。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Balangay is the first wooden watercraft ever excavated in Southeast Asia. Also known as the Butuan boat, this artifact is evidence of early Filipino craftsmanship and their seamanship skills during pre-colonial times. The Balangay Festival is also a celebration in Butuan, Agusan del Norte to commemorate the coming of the early migrants from Borneo and Celebes, on board the Balangay boats. When the first Spaniards arrived in the 16th century, they found the Filipinos having a civilization of their own and living in well-organized independent villages called barangays. The name barangay originated from balangay, the Austronesian word for "sailboat".[PARAGRAPH:2]With the balangay's size, it was used for cargo and raiding purposes, giving proof that Butuan played a central role in trade throughout the region of the Philippine islands and with neighboring areas.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]The Balangay is the first wooden watercraft ever excavated in Southeast Asia. Also known as the Butuan boat, this artifact is evidence of early Filipino craftsmanship and their seamanship skills during pre-colonial times. The Balangay Festival is also a celebration in Butuan, Agusan del Norte to commemorate the coming of the early migrants from Borneo and Celebes, on board the Balangay boats. When the first Spaniards arrived in the 16th century, they found the Filipinos having a civilization of their own and living in well-organized independent villages called barangays. The name barangay originated from balangay, the Austronesian word for "sailboat".[PARAGRAPH:2]With the balangay's size, it was used for cargo and raiding purposes, giving proof that Butuan played a central role in trade throughout the region of the Philippine islands and with neighboring areas.

TEXT.English: [H1]Limited Resource Effects[\H1][NEWLINE]In Dawn of Civilization, the number of cities a resource can provide health or happiness to is limited. For example, each instance of the Silk only provides happiness to three cities in your empire. It is therefore necessary to secure multiple instances of a resource to supply all cities in a large empire. If a civilization does not control enough instances of a resource to supply all of its cities, the effect is applied to more cultured cities first. In consequence, it is advisable for large empires to focus on obtaining multiple instances of the same resource, while small civilizations should focus on a diverse set of resources. Note that these new rules only apply to health or happiness directly from resources. Health and happiness from resources with buildings remain unaffected, as well as all other resource effects (e.g. enabling units or providing power).
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]有限的资源效应[\H1][NEWLINE]在文明的曙光中，一种资源能提供健康或幸福的城市数量是有限的。例如，每一件丝绸都只会给你帝国的三座城市带来幸福。因此，有必要确保一个资源的多个实例，以供应一个大帝国中的所有城市。如果一个文明没有控制足够的资源实例来供应其所有的城市，那么这种影响首先会应用到文化程度更高的城市。因此，大帝国最好集中精力获取同一资源的多个实例，而小文明则应该集中精力获取一组不同的资源。请注意，这些新规则仅适用于直接从资源获得的健康或幸福。来自建筑物资源的健康和幸福不受影响，以及所有其他资源影响（例如，使能装置或提供电力）。

TEXT.English: [H1]Bargash bin Said[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of Zanzibar[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned: [\BOLD]1837 - 1888 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Text
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]Bargash bin Said[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of Zanzibar[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned: [\BOLD]1837 - 1888 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Text

TEXT.English: [H1]Karl XII[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Sweden[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] June 17, 1682 - November 30, 1718 AD[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Carl XII, Karl XII or Carolus Rex, the Alexander of the North, nicknamed in Turkish as Demirbas Sarl (Charles the Habitu?, was a King of Sweden from 1697 until his death in 1718. He was the fourth king of the Wittelsbach dynasty in Sweden. As a child, many people thought he was going to be sickly. This was proved to be wrong, though: he hardened his body for war by riding on horseback and hunting the wolves of Sweden's fir forests. When his father died, he was ready. He came to the throne at the age of fifteen and left the country three years later to embark on a series of battles overseas, that briefly made Sweden the predominant power in Northern Europe. These battles were part of the Great Northern War, and many of them were fought against Peter the Great, Emperor of Russia. His youth gave other nations a decent pretext with which to invade Sweden; Saxony, Denmark-Norway, Poland and Russia joined in a coalition to attack Sweden, beginning the Great Northern War. Charles XII turned out to be more astute than the other powers imagined, a great tactician, defeating all of the invaders. However, his strong tactical abilities were not accompanied by strategic and political wisdom. He is quoted by Voltaire as saying upon the outbreak of the Great Northern War, "I have resolved never to start an unjust war but never to end a legitimate one except by defeating my enemies." He took this resolution to an extreme level, which eventually resulted in the end of the Swedish Empire and its dominance of the southern Baltic Sea.[PARAGRAPH:2]Charles's first campaign was against Denmark, ruled by his cousin Frederick IV of Denmark, which threatened a Swedish ally, Frederick IV of Holstein-Gottorp (another cousin of Charles XII, and married to his sister Hedvig Sophia). Denmark's defeat, however, and Sweden's ensuing rise to prominence in the Baltic region was viewed suspiciously by two powerful neighbors, King August II of Poland (cousin to both Charles XII and Frederick IV of Denmark) and Peter the Great of Russia. Russia responded by occupying the Swedish territories of Livonia and Estonia. Charles countered this by attacking the Russian garrison at Battle of Narva. From the very beginning, this seemed to be a headstrong move. The Swedish army of ten thousand men was outnumbered four to one by the Russians. Still, Charles attacked under cover of a blizzard, and effectively split the Russian army in two. Many of Peter's troops that fled the battlefield drowned in the Narva River and the battle was a crushing Swedish victory.[PARAGRAPH:2]Charles, despite advice from his advisors, didn't pursue the Russian army. Instead, he then turned against Poland-Lithuania, which was formally neutral at this point, disregarding Polish negotiation proposals, supported by the Swedish parliament. Charles defeated Polish king Augustus II and his Saxon allies at the Battle of Kliszow in 1702 and captured many important cities of the Commonwealth. After the deposition of the king of Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, Charles XII filled the void with his own man, Stanislas Leszczynski .[PARAGRAPH:2]Meanwhile, while Charles enjoyed easy victories in the Commonwealth, the Russian Tsar Peter the Great embarked on a giant military reform plan that soon begun to bear fruit. The new Russian army was a much tougher one than the one defeated at Narva. Russian forces had managed to retake Livonia and even established a new city Saint Petersburg there. This prompted Charles to make the fatal decision to attack the Russian heartland with an assault on Moscow, allying himself with Ivan Mazepa, ataman of the Cossacks. Peter the Great managed to cripple Swedish forces near the Baltic coast before Charles managed to combine his forces, and Charles' Polish ally, Stanislaw Leszczynski, was facing internal problems of his own. Charles expected the support of a massive Cossack rebellion led by Mazepa in Ukraine but the Russians destroyed the rebel army before they could aid the Swedes. The harsh climate took its toll as well, as Charles marched his troops through Ukraine. By the time of the decisive Battle of Poltava, Charles had been wounded, one-third of his infantry was dead, and his vulnerable supply train destroyed. The king himself, incapacitated by a coma resulting from his injuries, was unable to rally the Swedish forces. The battle was a disaster, and Charles fled south to the Ottoman Empire, where he set up camp at Bender with about 1000 men who were called Caroleans ("Karoliner" in Swedish). The Poltava Swedish disaster marked both the end of the Swedish Empire and the rise of Russian Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Turks initially welcomed the Swedish king, who managed to incite a war between the Ottomans and the Russians. However the sultan Ahmed III eventually tired of Charles' endless scheming and ordered his arrest. Meanwhile, the king's old enemies Russia and Poland took advantage of his absence to regain and even expand their lost territories. England, an ally of the Swedes, defected from their alliance obligations while the Prussians also attacked Swedish holdings in Germany. Russia seized Finland and Augustus II regained the Polish throne.[PARAGRAPH:2]Seeing his very kingdom threatened, Charles fled the Ottoman Empire and rode across Europe in just fifteen days to return to Swedish Pomerania. His efforts to reestablish his lost empire failed, however, when he was killed by a bullet during his second siege of the fortress Fredriksten in Danish-controlled Norway. There has been some speculations that he was not killed by a stray bullet but by one fired from the Swedish side, making his death an assassination (at the time he was not very popular in Sweden due to the hardships the people suffered because of the constant wars) but a conclusion has never been reached. He was succeeded to the Swedish throne by his sister, Ulrika Eleanora.[PARAGRAPH:2]His death is one of countless trivial disagreements between Norway and Sweden, both sides claiming the kill. It is not uncommon for the Norwegian media to end articles concerning Sweden with the line PS: We shot Charles XII![PARAGRAPH:2]Exceptional for abstaining from alcohol and women, he felt most comfortable during warfare. Contemporaries report of his seemingly inhuman tolerance for pain and his utter lack of emotion. The king brought Sweden to its pinnacle of prestige and power through his brilliant campaigning. However, his over-ambitious invasion of Russia coupled with the overwhelming power of a revived anti-Swedish coalition brought Sweden's downfall as a Great Power.[PARAGRAPH:2]Apart from being a monarch, the King's interests included mathematics, and anything that would be beneficial to his warlike purposes. He is attributed to having invented an octal numeral system, which he considered more suitable for war purposes because of all cubic boxes used for materials such as gunpowder. According to a report by contemporary scientist Emanuel Swedenborg, the King had sketched down a model of his thought on a piece of paper and handed it to him at their meeting in Lund in 1716. The paper was reportedly still in existence a hundred years later, but has since been lost. Several historians of science suspect that either the multi-talented Emanuel Swedenborg or the brilliant inventor Christopher Polhem also present at the meeting in Lund 1716 may have been the true inventor behind this feat, or at least a main contributor.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The original Wembley Stadium, officially known as the Empire Stadium, was a football stadium in Wembley, London, England, standing on the site now occupied by the New Wembley Stadium that opened in 2007.[PARAGRAPH:1]It was famous for hosting the annual FA Cup finals, five European Cup finals, the 1948 Summer Olympics, the 1966 World Cup Final, the final of Euro 96, Queen's Magic Tour, the 1985 Live Aid concert, and both the 1992 and 1995 Rugby League World Cup Finals. Of Wembley Stadium, Pelé said, "Wembley is the cathedral of football. It is the capital of football and it is the heart of football" in recognition of its status as the world's best-known football stadium.[PARAGRAPH:1]The stadium's first turf was cut by King George V, and it was first opened to the public on 28 April 1923.
TEXT.Chinese: [Tab]原始的温布利体育场，正式称为帝国体育场，是英国伦敦文布利的一个足球场，站在2007开办的新温布利体育场的场地上。[段：1 ]它以举办年度足总杯、五欧洲杯决赛、1948夏季奥运会而闻名于世。1966年世界杯决赛，96年欧洲杯决赛，女王魔术巡回赛，1985年现场援助音乐会，以及1992年和1995年橄榄球联盟世界杯决赛。在温布利体育场，贝利说：“温布利是足球的大教堂。它是足球的首都，也是足球的心脏，“它承认了它作为世界上最著名的足球场的地位。”（1段）体育场的第一个草坪是由乔治五世国王砍的，它是在1923年4月28日首次向公众开放的。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Free Enterprise (also referred to as Laissez-faire economic policy) is an economic system in which transactions between private parties are free from government intervention such as regulation, privileges, tariffs, and subsidies. The doctrine of laissez-faire became an integral part of nineteenth-century European liberalism. Just as liberals supported freedom of thought in the intellectual sphere, so were they equally prepared to champion the principles of free trade and free competition in the sphere of economics. The state was to be merely a passive policeman, protecting private property and administering justice, but not interfering with the affairs of its citizens. Businessmen, and particularly British industrialists, were quick to associate these principles with their own economic interests.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]自由企业（也称为自由放任经济政策）是一种经济制度，在这种制度中，私营方之间的交易不受政府的干预，如监管、特权、关税和补贴。放任主义成为19世纪欧洲自由主义的一个组成部分。正如自由主义者在知识领域支持思想自由一样，他们也同样准备在经济领域捍卫自由贸易和自由竞争的原则。国家只是一个被动的警察，保护私有财产和司法，但不干涉公民的事务。商人，特别是英国工业家，很快就把这些原则与他们自己的经济利益联系起来。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services.[PARAGRAPH:1]Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sanghas, alternately also called Viharas, were originally created to provide places for the wandering Buddhist monks to make their annual retreats. Some Buddhist monks stay indoors during the three-month rainy season to avoid damaging new plant growth (and to avoid being stranded during inclement weather). In the past, wealthy supporters donated plots of land where the monks could retreat; over time these have evolved into monasteries, often large and wealthy structures where monks can live year round.
TEXT.Chinese: 修道院是那些希望远离尘世，追求圣洁生活的宗教僧侣们的静修场所。通常修道院都规定有严格的行为准则，确保修道者免受外来的骚扰和诱惑。有的修道院要求人人保持静默；有的完全禁止访问者入内。僧侣们每日都须在修道院中举行宗教仪式。[PARAGRAPH:1]在古代，修道院往往也成为学术研究的中心。在边远地区，僧侣可能是当地仅有的有文化者。僧侣们经常担任抄写工作，负责传抄本宗教的经书文献。修道院通常会附有图书馆，用于存放神学、科学、医学和哲学书籍。[PARAGRAPH:1]佛教修道院起初是为云游四方的佛教僧侣提供休憩之所。在持续三个月的雨季中，僧侣们会留在佛院之内，避免此时外出会踏伤新生的小草（而且这样的气候也不便出行）。富裕的施主也会向佛院赠送土地作为供奉；使佛院的规模不断扩大，僧侣们也开始长年居住其中而不再出外云游了。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The original walls of Constantinople were built in the 8th century BC when Byzantium was founded by Greek colonists from Megara. At the time the city consisted of an acropolis and little more. The colony was relatively unimportant by the Roman period, but Septimius Severus built a new set of walls during his reign, bringing more land into the city. When Constantine moved the capital of the empire to Byzantium, which he renamed Constantinople, he greatly expanded the walls of the city, incorporating even more territory.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 412 the Roman emperor Theodosius II surrounded Constantinople with a wall that stretched 6.5 kilometers between the Sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn. Although named after Theodosius, they were actually constructed under the direction of Anthemius, Praetorian prefect of the Eastern Empire.[PARAGRAPH:1]The walls were built of stone and brick in two lines of defense which adjoined a ditch 20 meters wide and 10 meters deep. The inner wall had was 5 meters thick and 12 meters high. It was strengthened with 96 unapproachable towers 18-20 meters tall. The thickness of the external wall was 2 meters, and its height was 8.5 meters. The wall contained the Belgrad, Silivrikapi, Mevlevihane, Topkapi, Edirnekapi, Egrikapi and Yedikule gates. Yedikule Gate was also known as the "Porta Aurea" or "Golden Gate", and was the most magnificent, consisting of three archways. As the state entrance into the capital, the Golden Gate was architecturally splendid, and was built of large square blocks of polished marble fitted together without cement, and flanked by two great towers of the same material. Upon the gates were placed sculpted elephants.[PARAGRAPH:1]The inner walls had massive square or hexagonal towers. The southern end of the walls, at the Sea of Marmara, was the location of the Marble Tower. There were ten gates, the four major ones being the Golden Gate at the southern end, the Selymbria Gate leading to the Forum of Constantine and Hagia Sophia, the Adrianople Gate connecting Constantinople's Mese (the main street) with the city of Adrianople and the Via Egnatia, and the Blachernae Gate in the north.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 439 the first sea walls were built. In 447 the wall was damaged by an earthquake, but was quickly restored in time to stop Attila's army. In the northwestern corner of the city, in the suburb of Blachernae, the Theodosian walls were relatively weaker, but were expanded by Leo I. The northern coast of the city, along the Golden Horn, also had a separate set of walls.[PARAGRAPH:1]These walls were almost inpenetrable, saving the city during sieges from the Bulgars, Arabs, and Rus', among others. The first attackers to break through the walls were the knights of the Fourth Crusade, who managed to scale the lower sea walls and also break the Wall of Leo in the northwestern Blachernae section of the city.[PARAGRAPH:1]The second and final time the walls were breached was during the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, by the Ottomans; however, they did not break through by force, but entered through the Kerkoporta Gate, which happened to be open, apparently accidentally but possibly through treachery. A large plaque today marks the spot where the Ottomans entered. Mehmed had the walls repaired in short order among other massive public works projects. Within a few years, due to the renewed importance of the city as the new Ottoman capital, the population started to soar again.[PARAGRAPH:1]Under the Ottomans, the Golden Gate, known to them as Yedikule ("the Seven Towers"), was used as a prison. Many parts of the walls are still standing today and are a testament to the extraordinary longevity of the empire. They have been damaged by recent earthquakes, but many sections have also been restored. The wall runs through the suburbs of modern Istanbul, with a belt of parkland flanking their course. The walls are pierced at intervals by modern roads leading westwards out of the city.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]君士坦丁堡的原始城墙建于公元前8世纪，当时拜占庭是由来自迈格拉的希腊殖民者建造的。当时这座城市由一座卫城和一些其他地方组成。殖民地在罗马时期相对来说并不重要，但塞普蒂米乌斯·西弗勒斯在其统治时期修建了一组新的城墙，为城市带来了更多的土地。当Constantine把帝国的首都迁到拜占庭，他把君士坦丁堡改名为“君士坦丁堡”时，他大大地扩大了城墙，把更多的领土合并起来。[段：1 ] 412罗马皇帝西奥多西斯二世围绕君士坦丁堡，在马尔马拉海和金角之间延伸了6.5公里的城墙。虽然他们以Theodosius命名，但实际上是在东帝王的Anthemius的指导下建造的。〔段落：1〕墙是由两条防线砌成的石头和砖块，毗连一条20米宽10米深的沟。内壁厚5米，高12米。它由96座18-20米高的高塔加固而成。外墙厚2米，高8.5米。城墙上有贝尔格勒、西里夫里卡皮、梅夫列维汉、托普卡皮、埃迪尔内卡皮、埃格里卡皮和耶迪库勒城门。耶迪库勒门也被称为“奥里亚门”或“金门”，是最宏伟的，由三个拱门组成。作为进入首都的国家入口，金门在建筑上非常华丽，由大块的抛光大理石砌成，无需水泥，两侧是两座同样材质的高塔。大门上摆放着雕刻的大象。[段落：1 ]内壁有巨大的正方形或六边形的塔。墙的南端，在马尔马拉海，是大理石塔的位置。有十个门，四个主要的是南端的金门，塞尔米布里亚门通向君士坦丁和Hagia Sophia的论坛，这是一个连接君士坦丁堡的MeSE（主要街道）与亚得里安诺尔和伊夫纳提亚的城市的亚门，以及北部的布莱克纳城门。[第一段：1 ]在第一个海上。筑墙了。447年，这堵墙被地震破坏，但很快被及时修复，以阻止阿提拉的军队。在城市的西北角，在布莱克纳市郊，西奥多西安的城墙相对较弱，但被Leo I.市北部的海岸扩张，沿着金色的号角，也有一组独立的墙。[第1段]这些墙几乎无法穿透，在保加利亚、阿拉伯人和罗斯的围攻中拯救了这座城市。在其他中。第一批攻破城墙的攻击者是第四次十字军东征的骑士们，他们设法缩小了城墙的下层，同时也打破了城市西北部布莱克纳河段的雷欧城墙。[段：1 ]第二次也是最后一次被突破的时间是在奥斯曼王朝1453年的君士坦丁堡围攻期间。他们并没有强行突破，而是从克尔科波塔大门进入，这扇门碰巧是开着的，显然是偶然的，但可能是因为背叛。今天，一块巨大的匾额标志着奥斯曼人进入的地方。在其他大型公共工程项目中，穆罕默德让人在短时间内修复了这些墙。几年后，由于新奥托曼首都的重要性再次出现，人口开始再次腾飞。[段：1 ]在奥斯曼帝国下，金门被称为叶迪酷乐（“七塔”），被用作监狱。城墙的许多部分至今仍屹立不倒，是帝国非凡长寿的见证。它们已被最近的地震破坏，但许多地段也已恢复。这堵墙贯穿现代伊斯坦布尔的郊区，两边是一片绿地。城墙每隔一段时间就被通往城外西边的现代化道路穿破。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A windmill is a machine which converts the energy of wind into rotational motion by means of adjustable vanes called sails or blades. The main use was originally for a grinding mill powered by the wind, reducing a solid or coarse substance into pulp or minute grains, by crushing, grinding, or pressing. Windmills have also been used to power sawmills and other industrial processes and as windpumps for obtaining fresh water from underground or for drainage of land.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]风车是一种通过称为风帆或叶片的可调节叶片将风能转化为旋转运动的机器。主要用途最初是用于一个由风驱动的磨坊，通过粉碎、研磨或压榨将固体或粗物质还原成纸浆或微小颗粒。风车还被用来为锯木厂和其他工业过程提供动力，并用作从地下获取淡水或排水的风车。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Modern western drama was created in Greece around 530 BC, evolving from the "dithyramb," a fertility ritual of songs, poems and dances offered to the Greek god Dionysus. An "Odeon" is a large, open-aired structure in which such performances were held. The audience sat in a semicircle of seats around a central paved "dancing square" (orchestra). The first row of seats was reserved for important officials or priests. There was usually an altar dedicated to Dionysus somewhere in the odeon. The "logeion" was a small raised platform where the performers acted (the original dramas had at most three or four actors; the size of the stage would increase as later plays required bigger casts).
TEXT.Chinese: 西方现代戏剧的诞生可以追溯到约公元前530年时的古希腊，由“酒神赞歌”（dithyramb）逐渐演化而来——这是为庆祝丰收、向酒神狄俄尼索斯献祭而举行的一种表演仪式，包括歌唱、诗朗颂和舞蹈等等。古希腊的“露天剧场”（odeon）是一种大型开放式建筑，专门用于举行这类演出。听众坐在四周的看台之上，中间是演出的舞台。看台的第一排座位是为重要的官员和祭司准备的。在歌剧院里面有专门用于祭拜酒神的祭坛。“舞台”是一块高起的小平台，用于演员演出（最初的戏剧最多只有三四个演员；随着后来的发展，需要的演职人员也越来越多。）

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Seven Kingdoms were also called momboares in the 17th century text of the Portuguese Jesuit priest, Mateus Cardoso, which offers an extensive description of the region. The term momboares certainly derives from the Kikongo, or Congo language, word mbwadi, meaning seven. Cardoso noted that the region was famous in his day for the large amount of cloth that it produced, some of which was exported to the Portuguese colonial city of Luanda, Angola. Reports of the early 17th century suggest that the Seven Kingdoms exported as much as 100,000 meters of cloth annually to that market alone, suggesting that its total production must have been several times higher, putting in on a par with other major textile centers in the world, including areas of equivalent size in Europe and India.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]在17世纪葡萄牙耶稣会牧师马特乌斯·卡多索的著作中，这七个王国也被称为蒙博阿，该书对该地区进行了广泛的描述。momboares这个词当然来源于Kikongo，或者刚果语mbwadi，意思是7。卡多佐指出，该地区在他那个时代以生产大量布料而闻名，其中一些布料出口到葡萄牙殖民地城市安哥拉罗安达。17世纪早期的报告显示，仅这一个市场，七国每年就向该市场出口多达10万米的布料，表明其总产量肯定高出数倍，与世界上其他主要纺织中心不相上下，包括欧洲和印度同等规模的地区。

TEXT.English: [H1]Harun al-Rashid[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Caliph of the Abbasid Caliphate[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 763 - 809 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Harun al-Rashid, "Harun the Orthodox", the fifth of the Abbasid caliphs of Bagdad, and the second son of the third caliph Mahdi. His full name was Harun ibn Muhammad ibn Abdallah ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Abdallah ibn Abbas. He was born at Rai (Rhagae) on the 20th of March AD 763, according to some accounts, and according to others on the 15th of February AD 766. Harun al-Rashid was twenty-two years old when he ascended the throne. His father Mahdi just before his death conceived the idea of superseding his elder son Musa (afterwards known as Hadi, the fourth caliph) by Harun. But on Mahdi's death Harun gave way to his brother.[PARAGRAPH:2]Rashid owed his succession to the throne to the prudence and sagacity of Yahya bin Khalid the Barmecide, his secretary, whom on his accession he appointed his lieutenant and grand vizier. Under his guidance the empire flourished on the whole, in spite of several revolts in the provinces by members of the old Alid family. Successful wars were waged with the rulers of Byzantium and the Khazars. In 803, however, Harun became suspicious of the Barmecides, whom with only a single exception he caused to be executed. Henceforward the chief power was exercised by Fadl bin Rabi, who had been chamberlain not only under Harun himself but under his predecessors, Mansur, Madhi and Hadi. In the later years of Harun's reign troubles arose in the eastern parts of the empire. These troubles assumed proportions so serious that Harun himself decided to go to Khorasan. He died, however, at Tus in March 809.[PARAGRAPH:2]The reign of Harun was one of the most brilliant in the annals of the caliphate, in spite of losses in northwest Africa and Transoxiana. His fame spread to the West, and Charlemagne and he exchanged gifts and compliments as masters respectively of the West and the East. No caliph ever gathered around him so great a number of learned men, poets, jurists, grammarians, cadis and scribes, to say nothing of the wits and musicians who enjoyed his patronage. Harun himself was a scholar and poet, and was well versed in history, tradition and poetry. He possessed taste and discernment, and his dignified demeanor is extolled by the historians. In religion he was extremely strict; he prostrated himself a hundred times daily, and nine or ten times made the pilgrimage to Mecca. At the same time he cannot be regarded as a great administrator. He seems to have left everything to his viziers Yahya and Fadl, to the former of whom especially was due the prosperous condition of the empire. Harun is best known to Western readers as the hero of many of the stories in the Arabian Nights; and in Arabic literature he is the central figure of numberless anecdotes and humorous stories. Of his incognito walks through Bagdad, however, the authentic histories say nothing. His Arabic biographers are unanimous in describing him as noble and generous, but there is little doubt that he was in fact a man of little force of character, suspicious, untrustworthy and on occasions cruel.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1] AbasialCalpHAT[ [Brut] ] [NBOLY] [Brut]的Harun al Rashid [\H1] [Brut] KalIPh：[\BOLD ] 763到809 AD [NealLe] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[段落：1 ] Harun al Rashid，“哈伦正统”，Bagdad ABBASID哈里发的第五，和第三哈里发马赫迪的第二个儿子。他的全名是哈伦伊本穆罕默德伊本阿卜杜拉伊本穆罕默德伊本阿里伊本阿卜杜拉伊本阿巴斯。据一些记载，他于公元763年3月20日出生在拉伊（拉盖），另一些则于公元766年2月15日出生。哈伦·拉希德登基时22岁。他的父亲马赫迪在临死前就想出了哈伦接替他的长子穆萨（后来被称为第四哈里发哈迪）的主意。但是在马赫迪死后，哈伦让位给了他的兄弟。（段落：2）Rashid把他的继承权归于王位继承人雅加宾哈立德的谨慎和睿智，他的秘书巴米西德，在他加入时，任命他为中尉和大维齐尔。在他的领导下，尽管阿利德家族的成员在各省发动了几次叛乱，但帝国总体上还是兴旺发达。与拜占庭和哈扎尔的统治者进行了成功的战争。然而，在803年，哈伦开始怀疑巴梅吉兹一家，除了一个例外，他导致巴梅吉兹被处决。从此，法德尔·本·拉比行使了最高权力，他不仅在哈伦的统治下，而且在他的前任曼苏尔、马迪和哈迪的统治下都是管家。哈伦统治后期，帝国东部地区出现了麻烦。这些麻烦太严重了，哈伦自己决定去呼罗珊。然而，他于809三月死于图斯。[段：2 ]哈伦的统治是哈里发时代最辉煌的一次，尽管在非洲西北部和Transoxiana都有损失。他的名声传到了西方，查理曼大帝和他分别作为西方和东方的主人交换礼物和赞美。哈里发从来没有像他这样聚集过这么多有学问的人，诗人、法学家、语法学家、卡迪斯和文士，更不用说那些享受他的庇护的才智和音乐家了。哈伦本人是一位学者和诗人，精通历史、传统和诗歌。他有鉴赏力和鉴别力，他端庄的举止受到历史学家的赞扬。在宗教上，他非常严格；他每天跪拜一百次，朝圣麦加朝圣九、十次。同时，他也不能被视为伟大的管理者。他似乎把一切都留给了他的大臣叶海亚和法德尔，尤其是由于帝国的繁荣昌盛，前者更是如此。哈伦是西方读者最为熟知的《天方夜谭》中许多故事的主人公；在阿拉伯文学中，他是无数轶事和幽默故事的中心人物。然而，他隐姓埋名走遍巴格达，真实的历史却一言不发。他的阿拉伯传记作家们一致认为他高贵大方，但毫无疑问，他实际上是一个性格不强、多疑、不可信、有时残忍的人。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Karolins were soldiers of the Swedish kings Charles XI and Charles XII. They were part of the yearly Swedish allotment system. The Karolins' tactics were to attack fiercely and remain unafraid. The soldiers also sustained stern discipline, which over the extensive course of a twenty-year-long war would prove vital. The Swedish army tactics of the time did not teach retreat, so the soldiers were known to never withdraw from battle.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]The Karolins were soldiers of the Swedish kings Charles XI and Charles XII. They were part of the yearly Swedish allotment system. The Karolins' tactics were to attack fiercely and remain unafraid. The soldiers also sustained stern discipline, which over the extensive course of a twenty-year-long war would prove vital. The Swedish army tactics of the time did not teach retreat, so the soldiers were known to never withdraw from battle.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Candis were Hindu and Buddhist temples built in Indonesia mostly between the 8th and 15th century AD. The term "candi" itself derived from Candika, one of the manifestation of the goddess Durga as the goddess of death. This suggested in ancient Indonesia the "candi" has mortuary function as well as attributed with the afterlife. The association of the name "candi", candika or durga with Hindu-Buddhist temples is unknown in India and other of Indonesia's Southeast Asian neighbours such as Cambodia, Thailand, or Burma. The historians suggested that temples of ancient Java also used to store the ashes of cremated deceased kings or royalties. This is also in-line with buddhist concept of stupa as the structure to store buddhist relicts including the ashes and remnants of holy buddhist priest or the buddhist king, the patron of buddhism. The statue of god stored inside the garbhagriha (main chamber) of the temple often modelled after the deceased king and considered as deified self of the king portrayed as Vishnu or Shiva. The example is the statue of king Airlangga from Belahan temple portrayed as Vishnu riding Garuda.[PARAGRAPH:1]Some of the more famous Candis are Borobudur, a Mahayana Buddhist monument in Central Java and the large Prambanan, dedicated to the Hindu god Trimurti, both built in the 9th century.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]坎迪是印度教和佛教寺庙，大多建于公元8至15世纪之间。坎迪一词本身来源于坎迪卡，是杜尔加女神作为死亡女神的表现之一。这表明在古代印度尼西亚，“坎迪”有太平间的功能，也与来世有关。“candi”、candika或durga这个名字与印度佛教寺庙的联系在印度和其他东南亚邻国如柬埔寨、泰国或缅甸是未知的。历史学家认为，古爪哇的寺庙也用来存放火化的已故国王的骨灰或版税。这也符合佛塔的概念，佛塔是用来存放佛教遗物的结构，包括圣佛或佛教赞助人佛王的骨灰和遗物。神像存放在神庙的加尔巴格里哈（主厅）内的神的雕像，常仿照已故国王，被认为是被描绘成毗湿奴或湿婆神的国王的神化的自我。例如，Belahan寺的国王阿朗加雕像被描绘为毗瑟奴骑马的加鲁达。[段落：1 ]一些更著名的Candis是婆罗浮屠，一个大中佛教寺庙，位于java爪哇和大的普兰巴南，致力于印度教神三木，都建于九世纪。

TEXT.English: [TAB]At the height of its power, the Mali Empire had a trading empire that stretched across Africa and into Europe, the Middle East, and Asia; the great wealth of the Mali Empire in large came from the rich gold mines of Bumbuk and Bure.[PARAGRAPH:1]Once the gold was extracted from the mine and purified, it needed to be shaped into a size and form that was easy for the Malinese to transport and to trade. Gold could be formed into large blocks or bars, but these were extremely heavy and cumbersome, and quite awkward to transport on horse/camelback. They were also so expensive that only governments and the very rich would be able to afford them, and so that form was usually reserved for large quantities of gold that were to be transported by ship. For smaller and more convenient uses, gold was formed into coins.[PARAGRAPH:1]A place where money is created is called a "mint." At a mint, the gold is melted and poured into a standardized coin form - or, in earlier times, it might be manually pounded and cut into shape. The coin is usually decorated with the ruler's head or some other recognizable symbol. The value of the gold coin is dependent upon the purity of the metal in the coin, and its weight. Throughout history the unscrupulous have attempted to pass off light or impure coins to unsuspecting purchasers. If widespread, this practice can seriously damage trade and cripple a nation's entire economy. To maintain a reputation for honest dealing, the Malinese needed to use fairly sophisticated measuring tools to ensure that their coins maintained a consistent value. This in turn spurred advancements in science and technology.
TEXT.Chinese: 在其权力的高度，马里帝国有一个贸易帝国，它横跨非洲，延伸到欧洲、中东和亚洲；马里帝国的巨大财富来自于班布克和布雷的富金矿。[段落：1 ]一旦从金矿中提炼出黄金并加以提纯，就需要将其成形为大小和形式。对马里人来说，这很容易运输和贸易。黄金可以形成大块或条块，但它们极其沉重和笨重，用马或骆驼背运输相当困难。它们的价格也非常昂贵，只有政府和非常富有的人才能负担得起，因此这种形式通常是为大量的黄金保留下来，这些黄金将通过船只运输。为了更小、更方便的使用，黄金被制成硬币。[段落：1 ]一个钱被创造的地方被称为“薄荷”。在薄荷中，黄金被熔化并倒入标准的硬币形式——或者，在更早的时候，它可以被手工捣碎和切割成形状。硬币通常用统治者的头或其他可识别的符号装饰。金币的价值取决于金币中金属的纯度和重量。纵观历史，肆无忌惮的人一直试图向毫无戒心的购买者假冒伪劣钱币。如果这种做法蔓延开来，会严重损害贸易，损害一个国家的整个经济。为了保持诚实交易的声誉，马里人需要使用相当复杂的测量工具，以确保他们的硬币保持一致的价值。这反过来又刺激了科学技术的进步。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Nationalism is the belief that the affairs of the nation are the primary concern of its citizens. A recent political phenomenon (the first major application taking place after the French Revolution), it has nonetheless become the overriding paradigm for modern world politics. It is important to know that nationalism can come in a variety of forms, some permutations bearing little resemblance to each other. Many early nationalistic leaders preached the superiority of their country over all others. While this type isn't extinct today (as evidenced by the ethnocentric nationalism in the former Yugoslavia), most promote national determinism. Sanctioned by the United Nations, this is the belief that each nation should be responsible for its own growth and independence.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]民族主义的主旨在于国家事务应当作为人民心中的第一要务而存在。作为一种近代以来世界政治的一个普遍现象（民族主义思潮最早兴起于法国大革命之后），它已成为现代世界政治体系中一个令人头疼的问题。值得注意的是，民族主义往往以截然不同的方式体现出来。许多早期的民族主义领袖喜欢鼓吹本民族的优越性。到今天此种理念仍未消失（例如前南斯拉夫地区的民族主义浪潮），甚至演化为民族决定论。但正如联合国相关决议所指出的：民族主义应当只发挥推动民族独立和发展的作用。

TEXT.English: [H1]Sejong the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Joseon[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1397 - 1450 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Sejong the Great was the fourth king of Joseon-dynasty Korea. Born with family name Yi. He was the third son of King Taejong and Queen consort Min. He was designated as heir-apparent, Crown Prince, after his older brother Jae was stripped of his title. He ascended to the throne in 1418. During the first four years of his reign, Taejong governed as regent, after which his father-in-law, Sim On, and his close associates were executed.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sejong reinforced Confucian policies and executed major legal amendments. He also created the Korean alphabet Hangul, encouraged advancements of scientific technology, and instituted many other efforts to stabilize and improve prosperity. He dispatched military campaigns to the north and instituted the Samin Policy to attract new settlers to the region. To the south, he subjugated Japanese raiders and captured Tsushima Island.[PARAGRAPH:2]During his reign from 1418 to 1450, he governed from 1422 to 1442 and governed as regent with his son Crown Prince MoonJong until his death in either 1442 or 1450.[PARAGRAPH:2]Although the appellation "the Great" was given posthumously to almost every ruler of Goryeo and Joseon, this title is usually associated to Gwanggaeto, and Sejong.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1] Jeaeon [Brut]国王Sejong [新加坡] [Brang]：[DBOLL] 1397（1450）Ad [新行] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[BARD] [段落：1 ] Sejong大帝是朝鲜王朝的第四位国王。出生于彝族。他是大宗国王和敏皇后的第三个儿子，在他的哥哥被剥夺爵位后，他被指定为王储。他于1418年登基。在他统治的前四年，太宗统治了摄政时期，此后他的岳父、Sim On和他的亲密伙伴被处决。[段：2 ]世宗加强了儒家政策并执行了重大的法律修正案。他还创造了朝鲜文字母，鼓励科学技术的进步，并为稳定和改善繁荣作出了许多其他努力。他向北方发动了军事行动，并制定了萨明政策，以吸引新的定居者到该地区定居。在南部，他征服了日本突击队并占领了对岛。[段：2 ]在1418至1450年间，他从1422岁到1442岁，以他的儿子Crown Prince MoonJong统治着摄政王，直到他在1442或1450年去世。[段：2 ]虽然“伟大”的称谓被遗赠给几乎每一位Goryeo和Joseon的统治者，但这个头衔通常与Gwanggaeto和世宗特别自治市有关。

TEXT.English: [TAB]In geography, a plain is a flat region. Plains occur as lowlands and at the bottoms of valleys but also on plateaus or uplands at high elevations. In a valley, a plain is enclosed on two sides but in other cases a plain may be delineated by a complete or partial ring of hills, by mountains or cliffs. Where a geological region contains more than one plain, they may be connected by a pass (sometime termed a gap). Plains may have been formed from flowing lava, deposited by water, ice, wind, or formed by erosion by these agents from hills and mountains.[PARAGRAPH:1]Plains in many areas are important for agriculture because where the soils were deposited as sediments they may be deep and fertile, and the flatness facilitates mechanization of crop production; or because they support grasslands which provide good grazing for livestock.
TEXT.Chinese: [选项卡]在地理上，平原是平坦的地区。平原作为低地出现在山谷的底部，但也出现在高原或高地的高海拔地区。在山谷中，平原是两边围起来的，但在其他情况下，平原可以由一个完整的或部分的环形山丘、山脉或悬崖划定。当一个地质区域包含多个平原时，它们可以通过一个山口（有时称为山口）连接起来。平原可能是由流动熔岩形成的，由水、冰、风沉积，或由这些物质从山和山侵蚀而形成。[段落：1 ]平原在许多地区对农业很重要，因为土壤被沉积为沉积物，它们可能是深的和肥沃的，平坦度有利于作物生产的机械化；或者因为他们支持为牲畜提供良好放牧的草地。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Turtle ship, also known as Geobukseon or Kobukson, was a type of large warship belonging to the Panokseon class in Korea that was used intermittently by the Royal Korean Navy during the Joseon Dynasty from the early 15th century up until the 19th century.[PARAGRAPH:1]The first references to older, first generation turtle ships, known as Gwiseon, come from 1413 and 1415 records in the Annals of the Joseon Dynasty, which mention a mock battle between a gwiseon and a Japanese warship. However, these early turtle ships soon fell out of use as Korea's naval preparedness decreased during a long period of relative peace.[PARAGRAPH:1]Turtle ships participated in numerous victories against Japanese naval forces that supported Toyotomi Hideyoshi's attempts to conquer Korea from 1592-1598, inflicting heavy losses. However, their historical role may have been exaggerated since "the entire Korean fleet probably did not have more than half a dozen turtleboats in action at any one time". Korean admiral Yi Sun-sin is credited with designing the ship while one of his lieutenants, Na Dae Yong, was in charge of building it. His turtle ships were equipped with at least five different types of cannon. Their most distinguishable feature was a fully covered deck that was shielded to deflect cannon fire, and with iron spikes to discourage enemy men from attempting to board the ship.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAP]海龟船，也被称为GeoBukson或Kobkkon，是一种大型军舰，属于韩国的PANOKSEON级，在十五世纪初至十九世纪期间被朝鲜皇家海军间歇性地使用。[段落：1 ]第一次提及老一代的甲鱼船，被称为格维森，来自1413年和1415年的记录，其中提到了一个格维森和日本战舰之间的模拟战争的约森王朝。然而，这些早期的甲鱼船很快就失效了，因为韩国的海军准备在长期的相对和平时期减少了。[段落：1 ]甲鱼船参加了无数次对抗日本海军的胜利，支持了丰臣秀吉从1592年至1598年征服韩国的努力，造成了巨大的损失。然而，他们的历史角色可能被夸大了，因为“整个韩国舰队可能在任何时候都没有超过6艘的高领套头衫船”。韩国海军上将孙正义（Yi Sun sin）被认为设计了这艘船，而他的一名中尉Na Dae Yong负责建造这艘船。他的海龟船至少装备了五种不同类型的大炮。他们最显著的特点是一个完全覆盖的甲板，用以抵挡炮火，并用铁钉阻止敌人试图登船。

TEXT.English: [H1]el-Haj Mohammed Soeharto[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Indonesia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1921 - 2008 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Haji Mohammad Soeharto, more commonly referred to as simply Soeharto (General Suharto in the English-speaking world), is a former Indonesian military and political leader. He served as a military officer in the Indonesian National Revolution, but is better known as the long-reigning second President of Indonesia, holding the office from 1967 to 1998.[PARAGRAPH:2]Suharto seized power from his predecessor, the first president of Indonesia Sukarno, through a mixture of force and political maneuvering against the backdrop of foreign and domestic unrest. Over the three decades of his "New Order" regime, Suharto constructed a strong central government along militarist lines. An ability to maintain stability and an avowedly anti-Communist stance won him the economic and diplomatic patronage of several Western governments in the era of the Cold War. For almost all of his three-decade rule, Indonesia experienced rapid industrialization and economic growth.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Suharto regime had won the favour of Western governments and institutions, however, in 1990's, its increasingly authoritarian and corrupt practices became a source of much discontent. After the 1990s brought end of the Cold War, Western concern over communism waned, and Suharto's human rights record came under greater international scrutiny. In 1991, the murder of East Timorese civilians in a Dili cemetery, also known as the "Santa Cruz Massacre", caused American attention to focus on its military relations with the Suharto regime and the question of Indonesia's occupation of East Timor. In 1992,this attention resulted in the Congress of the United States passing limitations on IMET assistance to the Indonesian military, over the objections of President George H.W. Bush. In 1993, under President Bill Clinton, the U.S. delegation to the UN Human Rights Commission helped pass a resolution expressing deep concern over Indonesian human rights violations in East Timor. The Indonesian invasion and occupation of East Timor has been called the worst instance of genocide (relative to population) since the Holocaust.[PARAGRAPH:2]His almost unquestioned authority over Indonesian affairs slipped dramatically when the Asian financial crisis lowered Indonesians' standard of living and fractured his support among the nation's military, political and civil society institutions. After internal unrest and diplomatic isolation sapped his support in the mid-to-late 1990s, Suharto was forced to resign from the presidency in May 1998.[PARAGRAPH:2]After serving as the public face of Indonesia for over 30 years, Suharto then lived his post-presidential years in virtual seclusion. His legacy remains hotly debated and contested both in Indonesia and in foreign-policy debates in the West. Since his resignation, Suharto retired to a family compound in Central Jakarta, making few public appearances. Efforts to prosecute Suharto have mostly centered around alleged mismanagement of funds, and their force has been blunted due to health concerns. In january 2008, Suharto was taken to the Pertamina hospital, Jakarta, with complications arising from a weak heart, swelling of limbs and stomach, and partial renal failure. He died there at 27th of January at 1:10 pm.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]穆罕默德HeJ SoaHalto [NealLe] [Brd]印度尼西亚总统[Brut] [NealLe] [Brut]生活：[\BOLD ] 1921到2008 Ad [新行] [NurLe] [Brut]背景：[Brut]（段落：1）Haji Mohammad Soeharto，更通常被称为Soeharto（一般在英语世界中的苏哈托），是印尼前军事和政治领袖。他曾在印尼国民革命中担任过军事官员，但更被称为印度尼西亚执政的第二任总统，从1967岁到1998岁。[段：2 ]苏哈托从他的前任、印度尼西亚第一总统苏卡诺手中夺取政权。在国内外动荡的背景下，通过武力和政治手段的混合。在其“新秩序”政权的三十年中，苏哈托按照军国主义路线建立了一个强大的中央政府。维持稳定的能力和公开的反共立场为他赢得了冷战时期几个西方国家政府的经济和外交支持。在他长达三年的统治中，印度尼西亚几乎经历了工业化和经济的快速增长。[段落：2 ]苏哈托政权赢得了西方政府和机构的青睐，然而，在1990年代，其日益独裁和腐败的行为成了许多不满的根源。20世纪90年代冷战结束后，西方对共产主义的担忧减弱，苏哈托的人权记录受到国际社会更大的关注。1991年，在帝力公墓杀害东帝汶平民的事件，也被称为“圣克鲁斯大屠杀”，引起了美国的注意，集中在它与苏哈托政权的军事关系和印度尼西亚占领东帝汶的问题上。1992年，这一关注导致美国国会通过了限制IMT对印尼军方的援助，而不是乔治H.W.布什总统的反对。1993年，在克林顿总统的领导下，美国驻联合国人权委员会代表团帮助通过了一项决议，对印度尼西亚在东帝汶侵犯人权的行为深表关切。印尼入侵和占领东帝汶被称为大屠杀以来（与人口有关的）最糟糕的例子。[第2段]，当亚洲金融危机降低了印尼人的生活水平，破坏了他对印尼事务的支持时，他对印尼事务的几乎无庸置疑的权威大大地滑落。国家的军事、政治和民间社会机构。在上世纪90年代中后期，内部动荡和外交孤立削弱了他的支持后，苏哈托被迫在1998年5月辞去了总统职位。[段：2 ]在印度尼西亚公开露面超过30年之后，苏哈托在虚拟隐居状态下度过了后总统时代。无论是在印尼还是在西方的外交政策辩论中，他的遗产仍然受到激烈的辩论和争议。苏哈托辞职后，隐居雅加达市中心的一个家庭大院，很少公开露面。起诉苏哈托的努力主要集中在所谓的资金管理不善，他们的力量由于健康问题而被削弱。2008年1月，苏哈托被送往雅加达Pertamina医院，因心脏虚弱、四肢和胃肿胀以及部分肾功能衰竭而出现并发症。他于一月二十七日下午一点十分在那里去世。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Prussia made early use of the title "fusilier" for various types of infantry. In 1705, the Foot Guards (Leibgarde zu Fuss) were designated as Fusilier Guards. By 1837, low-quality infantry raised from garrison companies also were named fusiliers. These latter units were dressed in blue with low mitre caps. Between 1740 and 1743 on Frederick the Great raised 14 separate Fusilier Regiments (numbers 33-40, 41-43 and 45-48). Except for the mitre caps, these new regiments were identical in appearance, training and role to the existing line infantry (musketeers).[PARAGRAPH:2]Subsequently, Prussia and several other German states used the designation Fusilier to denote a type of light infantry, dressed in green, that acted as skirmishers. In the Prussian Army, they had been formed in 1787 as independent battalions, with many of the Officers having had experience in the American Revolutionary War. The Prussian reforms of 1808 absorbed the fusiliers as the third battalion of each line infantry regiment. Now wearing the same Prussian blue uniforms as standard musketeers, they were distinguished by black leather belts, and a slightly different arrangement of cartridge pouch.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the Prussian Army of 1870, Infantry Regiments 33 to 40 plus Regiments 73 (Hanover), 80 (Hesse-Kassel or Hesse-Cassel) and 86 (Schleswig-Holstein) were all designated as fusiliers, as was the Guard Fusilier Regiment. In addition, the third battalions of all guard, grenadier and line infantry regiments retained the designation 'Fusilier Battalion'. They were armed with a slightly shorter version of the Dreyse rifle (Füsiliergewehr), that took a sword bayonet (Füsilier-Seitengewehr) rather than the standard socket bayonet. Although still theoretically skirmishers, in practice they differed little from their compatriots, as all Prussian infantry fought in a style that formed a dense 'firing' or 'skirmish' line.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]普鲁士很早就把“引信”这个名称用于各种类型的步兵。1705年，步兵（Leibgarde zu Fuss）被指定为引信守卫。到1837年，由驻军连培养出来的低质量步兵也被命名为引信兵。后面的部队穿着蓝色的低头帽。1740年至1743年间，腓特烈大帝在腓特烈建立了14个独立的引信团（编号33-40、41-43和45-48）。除了军衔帽之外，这些新团在外观、训练和角色上与现存的线步兵（枪手）相同。[段：2 ]随后，普鲁士和其他几个德国国家使用指定的燧发枪来表示一种轻步兵，他们穿着绿色，充当小冲突。在普鲁士军队中，他们于1787年组成独立营，许多军官都有过美国革命战争的经验。1808年普鲁士的改革吸收了引信兵作为每一个步兵团的第三营。现在穿着同样的普鲁士蓝制服作为标准的枪手，他们以黑色的皮带，和稍微不同的弹药袋排列来区分。[段落：2 ]在普鲁士军队的1870，步兵团33到40加团73（汉诺威），80人（黑森·卡塞尔或黑森·卡塞尔）和86人（施莱斯维格·荷尔斯坦）都被指定为引信部队，警卫团也被指定为引信部队。此外，所有警卫、榴弹兵和直线步兵团的第三营保留了“引信营”的名称。他们装备了一种稍微短一点的德雷西步枪（Füsiliergewehr），这种步枪使用的是剑刺刀（Füsilier Seitengewehr），而不是标准的套筒刺刀。尽管理论上仍然是小规模战斗者，但实际上他们与同胞的差别不大，因为所有普鲁士步兵的战斗方式都形成了密集的“射击”或“小规模战斗”线。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Castillo de Chapultepec (translated as "Castle of Chapultepec") is a castle built on top of Chapultepec Hill (Chapultepec comes from the náhuatl and means "grasshopper hill"), located in the middle of Chapultepec Park in Mexico City at a height of 2,325 meters above sea level. The building has been used for several purposes during its history, including Military Academy, Imperial and Presidential residence, observatory and museum. It currently houses the Mexican National Museum of History. It is the only castle in North America that was occupied by sovereigns.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]查普尔特佩克城堡（Castillo de Chapultepec，简称“查普尔特佩克城堡”）是一座建在查普尔特佩克山（Chapultepec Hill）之上的城堡（查普尔特佩克来自纳瓦特，意为“蚱蜢山”），位于墨西哥城查普尔特佩克公园的中部，海拔2325米。这座建筑在历史上曾被用于多种用途，包括军事学院、皇家和总统官邸、天文台和博物馆。它现在是墨西哥国家历史博物馆的所在地。它是北美唯一被君主占领的城堡。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The arquebus is an early muzzle-loaded firearm. They were used against enemies that were often protected by steel-plate armor, which a bullet could pierce only at close range. The arquebus was unable to match the accuracy of a bow in the hands of a highly-skilled archer. However, it had a faster rate of fire than the most powerful crossbow, and a much shorter learning curve than a longbow. Once the methods were developed, powder and shot were relatively easy to mass-produce, while arrow making was a genuine craft requiring highly skilled labor.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]arquebus是一种早期的枪口式武器。它们被用来对付通常由钢板装甲保护的敌人，这种装甲只有在近距离才能被子弹穿透。在一位技艺高超的弓箭手手中，这架火箭炮的精度无法与弓媲美。然而，它的射速比最强大的弩快，学习曲线比长弓短得多。一旦这些方法被开发出来，粉末和子弹相对容易大量生产，而制箭是一项真正的工艺，需要高度熟练的劳动力。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Espionage is often part of an institutional effort by a government or commercial concern. However, the term is generally associated with state spying on potential or actual enemies primarily for military purposes. Spying involving corporations is known as industrial espionage.[PARAGRAPH:1]One of the most effective ways to gather data and information about the enemy (or potential enemy) is by infiltrating the enemy's ranks. This is the job of the spy (espionage agent). Spies can bring back all sorts of information concerning the size and strength of an enemy army. They can also find dissidents within the enemy's forces and influence them to defect. In times of crisis, spies can also be used to steal technology and to sabotage the enemy in various ways. Counterintelligence operatives can feed false information to enemy spies, protecting important domestic secrets, and preventing attempts at subversion. Nearly every country has very strict laws concerning espionage, and the penalty for being caught is often severe. However, the benefits that can be gained through espionage are generally great enough that most governments and many large corporations make use of it to varying degrees.
TEXT.Chinese: 【TAB】间谍活动通常是政府或商业机构机构努力的一部分。然而，这一术语通常与国家主要出于军事目的对潜在或实际敌人进行间谍活动有关。涉及企业的间谍活动被称为工业间谍活动。[段落：1 ]收集敌人（或潜在敌人）的数据和信息的最有效的方法之一是渗透敌人的队伍。这是间谍（间谍）的工作。间谍可以带回有关敌军规模和兵力的各种情报。他们还可以在敌人的军队中找到持不同政见者，并影响他们叛变。在危机时期，间谍还可以用来窃取技术和以各种方式破坏敌人。反间谍人员可以向敌方间谍提供虚假情报，保护重要的国内机密，防止颠覆企图。几乎每个国家对间谍活动都有非常严格的法律，被抓的惩罚往往很严厉。然而，通过间谍活动所能获得的好处通常是巨大的，以至于大多数政府和许多大公司都不同程度地利用了它。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Colosseum or Coliseum, situated in Rome and originally known as the Flavian Amphitheatre (Latin: Amphitheatrum Flavium), is the largest amphitheatre built in the Roman Empire. Originally capable of seating 50,000 spectators, it was used for gladiatorial combat. Construction of the Flavian Amphitheatre began under the rule of Emperor Vespasian in 72 AD. It was completed by his son, Titus, in 80 AD, with later improvements by Domitian.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]古罗马城的科洛塞姆大竞技场（“Colosseum”或“Coliseum”）原名“弗拉维姆竞技场”，是罗马帝国最大的竞技场建筑，建成时可容纳5万名观众观赏角斗。大竞技场是在公元72年维斯帕西安皇帝时代开始兴建的，由他的儿子泰图斯于公元80年完成，后在多米提安皇帝统治时期曾进行重修。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Itsukushima Shrine is a Shinto shrine on the island of Itsukushima (popularly known as Miyajima) in the city of Hatsukaichi in Hiroshima Prefecture in Japan. The shrine complex is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site and the Japanese government has designated several buildings and possessions as National Treasures.[PARAGRAPH:2]The shrine is dedicated to the three daughters of Susano-o no Mikoto, Shinto deity of seas and storms and brother of the great sun deity, Amaterasu (tutelary deity of the Imperial Household). Because the island itself has been considered sacred, in order to maintain its purity commoners were not allowed to set foot on Miyajima through much of its history. In order to allow pilgrims to approach, the shrine was built like a pier over the water, so that it appeared to float, separate from the land, and therefore existed in a liminal state between the sacred and the profane. The shrine's signature red entrance gate, or torii, was built over the water for much the same reason. Commoners had to steer their boats through the torii before approaching the shrine.[PARAgraph:2]Retaining the purity of the shrine is so important that since 1878, no deaths or births have been permitted near the shrine. To this day, pregnant women are supposed to retreat to the mainland as the day of delivery approaches, as are terminally ill or the very elderly whose passing has become imminent. Burials on the island are still forbidden.[PARAGRAPH:2]The first shrine buildings were probably erected in the 6th century, and the shrine has been destroyed many times. The present shrine dates from the mid-16th century, and follows the earlier 12th century design. That design was established in 1168, when funds were provided by the warlord Taira no Kiyomori. The shrine was designed and built on pier-like structures over the bay so that it would appear to be floating on the water, separate from the sacred island, which could be approached by the devout. Near the main shrine is a noh stage, funded by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the late 16th century. Noh theater performances have long been used to pay honor to the gods, and ritually act out key events in the mythic history of Shinto belief.[PARAgraph:2]The dramatic gate, or torii, of Itsukushima Shrine is one of Japan's most popular tourist attractions, and the most recognizable and celebrated feature of the Itsukushima shrine, and the view of the gate in front of the island's Mount Misen is classified as one of the Three Views of Japan (along with the sand bar Amanohashidate, and Matsushima Bay). Although a gate has been in place since 1168, the current gate dates back to 1875. The gate, built of decay-resistant camphor wood, is about 16 metres high and was built in a four-legged style to provide additional stability.[PARAgraph:2]The torii only appears to be floating at high tide; when the tide is low, it is approachable by foot from the island. It is common practice for visitors to place coins in the cracks of the legs of the gate and make a wish. Gathering shellfish near the gate is also popular at low tide. Many locals add the shellfish they gather to their miso soup. At night, powerful lights on the shore illuminate the torii.[PARAgraph:2]On September 5, 2004, the shrine was severely damaged by Typhoon Songda. The boardwalks and roof were partially destroyed, and the shrine was temporarily closed for repairs.
TEXT.Chinese: [资料图]大岛神社是日本广岛县鸠山由纪夫市大岛岛（俗称宫岛由纪夫）的神社。靖国神社综合体被列为联合国教科文组织世界遗产地，日本政府已将一些建筑物和财物指定为国宝。[第2段]圣殿是献给苏珊诺-不Mikto，海和风暴的神道神和太阳神的兄弟的三个女儿，阿玛特拉苏（皇室的守护神）。因为岛本身被认为是神圣的，为了保持岛上的纯洁，平民在岛上的许多历史上都不允许踏上宫岛。为了让朝圣者靠近，神龛像一个水上的码头，所以它看起来像漂浮在水面上，与陆地分离，因此存在于神圣与世俗之间的边缘状态。神龛标志性的红色入口大门，或称都灵，也是出于同样的原因而建在水面上的。平民必须在到达靖国神社前驾驶他们的船穿过牌坊。〔第2段〕保留靖国神社的纯度是如此重要，自1878以来，在神龛附近没有死亡或出生许可。到今天为止，孕妇应该随着分娩日的临近而撤退到大陆，临终的病人或即将去世的高龄者也应该如此。岛上的墓葬仍然被禁止。[段落：2 ]第一座神龛建筑可能是在六世纪建造的，靖国神社已经被摧毁了很多次。现在的神龛建于16世纪中叶，沿用了12世纪早期的设计。这种设计是在1168年建立的，当时军阀Taira no Kiyomori提供了资金。神龛的设计和建造都是在海湾上方的码头状结构上，这样看起来就像漂浮在水面上，与虔诚的人们可以接近的圣岛分离。在主神社附近有一个诺亚舞台，由丰臣秀吉在16世纪末资助。Noh戏剧表演长期以来被用来祭祀众神，并在神道信仰神话史上扮演重要的角色。[段落：2 ] ItkkuSua神庙的戏剧性之门，或牌坊，是日本最受欢迎的旅游景点之一，也是义岛神社最著名和最著名的特色。岛上米森山前的大门被列为日本的三大景观之一（连同沙洲天皇岛和松岛湾）。虽然从1168年起就有了一个门，但现在的门可以追溯到1875年。该门由耐腐樟木制成，高约16米，以四条腿的形式建造，以提供额外的稳定性。[段落：2 ] Turi只有在高潮时才浮出水面；当潮汐很低时，它可以从岛上徒步接近。游客通常在门腿的缝隙里放硬币许愿。在低潮时，在闸门附近采集贝类也很受欢迎。许多当地人在味噌汤中加入他们采集的贝类。晚上，岸上的强光照亮了牌坊。2004年9月5日第2段，靖国神社被Typhoon Songda严重破坏。木板路和屋顶部分被毁，神殿暂时关闭维修。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A river is a natural flowing watercourse, usually freshwater, flowing towards an ocean, a lake, a sea, or another river. In some rare cases a river could flow into the ground and dry up completely at the end of its course, without reaching another body of water. Small rivers may be called by several other names, including stream, creek, brook, rivulet, and rill. There are no official definitions for generic terms, such as river, as applied to geographic features, although in some countries or communities a stream may be defined by its size. Many names for small rivers are specific to geographic location; examples are "run" in some parts of the United States, "burn" in Scotland and northeast England, and "beck" in northern England. Sometimes a river is defined as being larger than a creek, but not always: the language is vague.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rivers are part of the hydrological cycle. Water generally collects in a river from precipitation through a drainage basin from surface runoff and other sources such as groundwater recharge, springs, and the release of stored water in natural ice and snowpacks (e.g. from glaciers). Potamology is the scientific study of rivers while limnology is the study of inland waters in general.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]河流是自然流动的水道，通常是淡水，流向海洋、湖泊、海洋或其他河流。在一些罕见的情况下，一条河流可能会流入地面，并在河道末端完全干涸，而不会到达另一个水体。小河可以用其他几个名字来称呼，包括小溪、小溪、小溪、小河和小河。虽然在一些国家或社区，河流的大小可以定义为一般性术语，如河流，但没有官方定义适用于地理特征。许多小河的名字都是根据地理位置而定的；例如在美国的一些地方“奔流”，在苏格兰和英格兰东北部“燃烧”，在英格兰北部“贝克”。有时河流被定义为比河流更大，但并不总是如此：语言是模糊的。[段落：1 ]河流是水文循环的一部分。水通常从地表径流和其他来源（如地下水补给、泉水和天然冰和雪堆（如冰川）中储存的水的释放）通过流域从降水中收集到河流中。马铃薯学是对河流的科学研究，而湖沼学则是对内陆水域的一般研究。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Indian people are remarkably sturdy and hard-working. Their compact, wiry frames can stand up to the most difficult labor in some of the world's most difficult climates - of which there is a remarkable abundance in the Indian subcontinent, including desert, jungle, and perilously high mountains. Yet across all of this terrain can be found temples, shrines, and fortresses - monuments to the strength and determination of the hardy Indian people.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]印度人民非常健壮，工作勤奋。在世界上最困难的气候条件下，印度次大陆（包括沙漠、丛林和险峻的高山）蕴藏着丰富的资源，而在这些气候条件下，它们紧凑、结实的框架可以经得起最艰苦的劳动。然而，在这片土地上，到处都可以看到寺庙、神殿和要塞，这些都是印度顽强人民的力量和决心的纪念碑。
