TEXT.English: [TAB]The Mongol tribes entered into history with the birth of Temujin, born in c.1167 AD in the wild steppe-land of Mongolia, which is bordered by modern China and Russia. When Temujin was nine years old, tribal rivals poisoned and murdered his father Yesugei, creating a power vacuum in the tribe that resulted in the exile of young Temujin and his family as fugitives. In time Temujin would return to claim his inheritance, forge political alliances, and vanquish old rivals. In 1204 AD he summoned a kuriltai war council and proceeded to unite all local nomad tribes by force, becoming the first man ever to unite the Mongols. It was at this time he received the title 'Genghis Khan', meaning 'Great Ruler'.[PARAGRAPH:2]China, at the time, was divided into three parts: the Ch'in, who were the most powerful, reigned in the north at Beijing; the Sung occupied the South; and the Hsi-Hsia, the weakest of the 3, inhabited the western flank of the Great Wall. The Mongol conquest against China began in 1211 when the consolidated tribes of the Great Khan struck at the Hsi-Hsia, with tremendous success. Not impressed with the defeat of his weaker neighbor, the new Emperor of Ch'in insisted on a public display of servitude from Temujin. Temujin reacted by ordering a general advance against the Ch'in Empire. The resulting war lasted for approximately 23 years, and ended in the complete destruction of the Ch'in. Although the Mongols began the war as nomadic horsemen, by the time they defeated the Ch'in they had learned how to use advanced siege weaponry to capture cities. During this campaign Temujin ensured that the epic war upon the Ch'in did not occupy all of his resources and time; there were older enemies to address.[PARAGRAPH:2]Amid the war against the Ch'in the Mongols also rallied against the Kara-Khitay, one of the original Kuchlug tribes that had fled from defeat during Temujin's war of unification. Victory over the Kara-Khitay provided the Mongols a common frontier with the Shah of Khwarizm, who ruled a large Muslim state that stretched from modern day Iran to southern Russia as far as the Caspian and Aral Seas. Temujin initially attempted to establish friendly relations with the Shah Ala-al-Din, but he was contemptuously rebuffed, and the Mongol emissary killed. That was a mistake. In 1219 a Mongol horde estimated at 100,000 horsemen invaded Khwarizm and the other cities that lay along the rich Silk Way. Due to their stubborn resistance, the cities of Khwarizm were destroyed, their populations slaughtered or enslaved, and the area almost completely depopulated. Ala-al-Din fled in exile and died shortly thereafter. In many respects, this area today still has not recovered from the Mongol invasion.[PARAGRAPH:2]After destroying Khwarizm, the Mongols had access to Russia. Not content with remaining a peaceful neighbor, Temujin's successor Ogodai permitted his generals to lead an extraordinary campaign into southern Russia, which would be staged largely in the winter months. In a series of campaigns between 1237-40, the Mongols completely subjected the various principalities of Russia, destroying anyone who opposed them. From Russia, the Mongols continued their western advance by invading Poland, Silesia, and Hungary. They easily defeated the armies of Poland, Germany, and Hungary, and appeared poised to erupt into Western Europe. But the death of Ogodai, the great khan, caused the armies to retreat in order to seek new orders, thus sparing most of Europe from destruction. Less fortunate was the Muslim world, as Baghdad was sacked in 1258 by yet another Mongol army and the Caliph executed by being trampeled to death beneath Mongol horses. The destruction of Baghdad and slaughtering of its population was a blow that the Arab Empire of the Caliphs never fully recovered from. The Mongols were finally turned back for the first time by the Mameluks of Egypt in 1260.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mongol children were taught to ride on horseback from the age of three, and were given bow and arrows to use for hunting at the age of five. Horseback riding became a natural way for the Mongols to conduct war. When speed was essential, a Mongol rider could even sleep while in the saddle; and by using a system that consisted of approximately four remounts, Temujin's army was capable of traversing 130 miles in two days, with no breaks for food. Another defining characteristic of a Mongolian army was the speed and voracity with which it was able to accept and prepare for battle. The Mongols' harsh, nomadic lifestyle had prepared them well for the rigors of war; and they often thrived in conditions that would be considered intolerable by any other military of its time. When the need arose they could last up to ten days at a time without cooking food, during which they would sustain themselves by drinking the blood of their horses. Their primary weapon consisted of horse archers called Keshiks, who could fire with great speed and incredible accuracy from the back of a saddle. The mobility of the Mongol forces gave them a great tactical advantage within battles that Mongol generals would exploit over and over again.[PARAGRAPH:2]Every victory wrought by the Mongols was followed by slaughters of incredible scale. No citizens, with the exception of those who were useful to the Mongol war effort, were spared in these attacks. In 1221, the Islamic city of Merv was captured; 700,000 were murdered (this number is almost certainly exaggerated but still amazing), and a rearguard was assembled to dispatch any citizens who were fortunate enough to have escaped the original slaughter - this was routine work for the Mongol army. It is said that Temujin planned to depopulate northern China for use as a pasture for his livestock, until being told that subjects would pay more in taxes than cattle.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the end of the 13th century Mongol armies had been involved in action in countries including: Poland, Japan, Korea, Hungary, Russia, Palestine, Egypt, Persia, India, China, Cambodia, Burma, Vietnam, and Indonesia. After Temujin's death in 1227 five more Khans would follow, including Kublai Khan, whose triumph was the union of all of China under his rule. However, the death of Kublai Khan in 1294 AD marked the end of an era for Mongol conquests, and the march of Mongol armies began to decline. While many of the khanates founded by the Mongols lasted for several more centuries, the age of the great nomadic forces was over. Although their era was brief in duration, the Mongols conquered the largest empire the world has ever seen and terrorized virtually the entire Eurasian continent.
TEXT.Chinese: 随着铁木真1167年诞生于被现今中俄边界所围绕着的蒙古大草原，蒙古民族的历史才真正开始。在铁木真八岁时，他的父亲也速该被敌人毒死，造成部族的权力真空和内部争斗，年幼的铁木真及其家人被迫过着悲惨的流亡生活。但最终铁木真卷土重来夺回继承权，联合盟友消灭仇敌，至1204年统一了蒙古高原。1206年他召集蒙古各部在斡难河源召开忽里台大会，并被推举为“成吉思汗”，即“伟大的统治者”。[PARAGRAPH:2]而当时的中国本部正处于三个政权分立的局面：统治北方，力量最强的金朝；偏安江南，经济繁荣的宋朝；以及占据长城西翼，力量最弱的西夏。成吉思汗在1209年迫使西夏归附之后，又于1211年率军南下，意欲逐鹿中原。新继位的金朝皇帝对弱小邻国的战败并不以为然，仍坚持要求铁木真向他称臣。铁木真乃下令对金帝国发动全面进攻。这场战争持续了23年，最后以金朝的灭亡而告终。起初的蒙古军队只是精于骑射，但到他们战胜金朝之时，已经掌握了重型武器的使用和攻打城池的技术。而除了金朝进行的漫长战争，铁木真还要同时面对更多的对手。[PARAGRAPH:2]在攻打金朝的同时，蒙古人还与西辽（哈剌契丹）作战，因为在蒙古统一战争中失败的乃蛮部王子屈出律逃亡至此并夺取了西辽帝位。灭亡西辽之后的蒙古开始与信奉伊斯兰教的花剌子模接壤，当时的花剌子模国王统治着包括今伊朗及原苏联中亚里海和咸海地区的广阔土地。起初铁木真曾试图与花剌子模国王阿拉-阿尔-丁建立友好关系，但被对方轻蔑地拒绝了，蒙古的使臣也被斩杀。花剌子模国王犯下了一个巨大的错误。1219年，十万蒙古大军发动了对花剌子模及其他丝绸之路沿线城市的入侵。由于在围攻时遇到强烈抵抗，蒙古人完全摧毁了花剌子模城作为报复，所有市民被屠杀或卖为奴隶，原本的繁华城市从此成为一片废墟。阿拉-阿尔-丁本人也在不久之后死于流亡途中。可以说这片地区直到今天都还未能从蒙古人的蹂躏下恢复过来。[PARAGRAPH:2]灭亡花剌子模使蒙古人打开了通向俄罗斯大草原的通道。继铁木真之后成为大汗的窝阔台不希望与任何邻国保持和平，于是派遣部下率军入侵基辅罗斯并大获全胜，而且这场战役还是在严寒的冬季进行的。历经三年征战（1237-1240），蒙古人消灭或臣服了各个罗斯公国，随即又从俄罗斯大草原出发继续向西入侵波兰、西里西亚和匈牙利。蒙古人轻松击败了波兰、日耳曼和匈牙利各国联军，大有横扫整个欧洲之势。但窝阔台却在此时因酗酒而意外暴亡，各路蒙古大军匆忙撤退回国以推举新的大汗，欧洲才得以免遭毁灭的命运。但穆斯林世界就没有这么幸运了，另一支蒙古大军于1258年攻陷巴格达，阿拔斯朝的末代哈里发被塞进布袋，用马蹄践踏而死。强盛一时的阿拉伯帝国从此一蹶不振。此后蒙古人继续向西进攻，但于1260年被埃及马穆鲁克王朝军队击退。[PARAGRAPH:2]蒙古小孩三岁就开始骑马，五岁就要拿起弓箭去狩猎。蒙古人可以说是天生的骑兵。如果时间紧迫，蒙古骑手甚至可以在马鞍上睡觉；每个蒙古骑兵都有至少二匹甚至三四匹马，可以在行进中轮流骑乘以节省马力，这使铁木真的军队可以几乎不停顿地在两天内行进130英里。蒙古军队最大的特点就是高速机动与疯狂掠夺，对战斗充满渴求。蒙古人习惯于艰苦的游牧生活，非常适应严酷的战争环境，他们往往能够在同时期的其他军队感到无法忍受的条件下保持高昂的斗志。必要时他们可以连续十天不生火做饭，而只靠饮用马血维生。蒙古骑射手是这支大军的主力，他们能在马背上连续而精准地射击。蒙古骑射手的高度的灵活性和机动性使他们在任何情况下都能够占据主动赢得优势。[PARAGRAPH:2]蒙古人获得的每一场胜利都伴随着规模惊人的屠杀。蒙古人所俘获的人口，只有能为军队出力者才能够幸免于难。公元1221年穆斯林城市马鲁被攻陷后，70万居民全部被屠杀（虽然这个数字应该有所夸大），蒙古人专门安排了预备队。以追捕有幸在最初的杀戳中逃脱的人——这对蒙古军队来说就像例行公事。传说铁木真曾经计划屠尽中国北部的居民，并将所有农田改为牧场，直到下属告诉他征收赋税比放牧牛羊更为合算时才作罢。[PARAGRAPH:2]到13世纪末期曾经遭受过蒙古大军入侵的国家和地区包括：波兰、日本、朝鲜、匈牙利、俄罗斯、巴勒斯坦、埃及、波斯、印度、中国、柬埔寨、缅甸、越南和爪哇等。1227年铁木真去世，其后的五位大汗继续他的扩张政策，他的孙子忽必烈汗取得了征服整个中国的业绩。但1294年忽必列汗的去世标志着蒙古大征服时代的结束，蒙古大军的征战从此停止，虽然蒙古人所建立的各大汗国继续存在了几个世纪的时间，但游牧民族强盛的时代已逐渐成为历史。虽然持续的时间很短暂，但蒙古人所建大帝国的疆域之广阔是人类历史上空前绝后的，几乎囊括了整个亚欧大陆。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Christian cathedrals are considered among the most beautiful buildings in the world. Many of the most imposing were built during the Middle Ages. Lofty buildings with beautiful stained glass, the early Christian cathedrals tended to collapse suddenly, with unfortunate results for those inside, until the invention of the flying buttress.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]基督教大教堂被认为是世界上最美丽的建筑之一。许多最宏伟的建筑都是在中世纪建造的。早期的基督教大教堂都是用漂亮的彩色玻璃建造的高楼大厦，它们往往会突然倒塌，给里面的人带来不幸的后果，直到发明了飞扶壁。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Feitoria is a Portuguese trading post. During the colonial era Feitorias were essential to the Portuguese in expanding their trade network between Europe, the Far East, and eventually the Americas. They afforded ships with limited range a safe port of call to refill depleted supplies and give their crews much needed rest.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]费托利亚是一个葡萄牙贸易站。殖民地时期，菲多利亚对葡萄牙人在欧洲、远东乃至美洲之间扩大贸易网络至关重要。它们为航程有限的船只提供了一个安全的停靠港，以补充耗尽的补给，并为船员提供急需的休息。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Under Ögedei and his successors, Karakorum became a major site for world politics. Möngke Khan had the palace enlarged, and the great stupa temple completed. They had the Parisian goldsmith, Guillaume Bouchier, design the Silver Tree of Karakorum for the city centre. A large tree sculpted of silver and other precious metals rose up from the middle of the courtyard and loomed over the palace, with the branches of the tree extended into the building. Silver fruit hung from the limbs and it had four golden serpents braided around the trunk, while within the top of the tree was placed a trumpet angel, all as automata performing for the emperor's pleasure. When the khan wanted to summon the drinks for his guests, the mechanical angel raised the trumpet to his lips and sounded the horn, whereupon the mouths of the serpents began to gush out a fountain of alcoholic beverages into the large silver basin arranged at the base of the tree.
TEXT.Chinese: 在厄格迪及其继任者的领导下，喀喇昆仑成为世界政治的主要场所。明克汗扩建了宫殿，完成了大佛塔寺。他们让巴黎金匠纪尧姆·布奇尔为市中心设计了喀喇昆仑银树。一棵由银和其他贵金属雕刻而成的大树从院子中央升起，隐约出现在宫殿的上空，树枝伸进了大楼。树枝上挂着银色的果实，树干上缠着四条金蛇，树顶上放着一个喇叭天使，所有的一切都像是为了皇帝的快乐而表演的自动机。当汗想为他的客人召唤饮料时，机械天使把喇叭举到嘴边，吹响了喇叭，于是蛇的嘴开始向树底的大银盆里喷出一股酒精饮料。

TEXT.English: [TAB]In 1598, when Shah Abbas decided to move the capital of his empire from the north-western city of Qazvin to the central city of Isfahan, he initiated what would become one of the greatest programmes in Persian history; the complete remaking of the city. By choosing the central city of Isfahan, fertilized by the Zāyande roud ("The life-giving river"), lying as an oasis of intense cultivation in the midst of a vast area of arid landscape, he distanced his capital from any future assaults by the Ottomans, the arch rival of the Safavids, and the Uzbeks, and at the same time gained more control over the Persian Gulf, which had recently become an important trading route for the Dutch and British East India Companies.[PARAGRAPH:2]The chief architect of this colossal task of urban planning was Shaykh Bahai (Baha' ad-Din al-`Amili), who focused the programme on two key features of Shah Abbas's master plan: the Chahar Bagh avenue, flanked at either side by all the prominent institutions of the city, such as the residences of all foreign dignitaries, and the Naqsh-e Jahan Square ("Exemplar of the World"). Prior to the Shah's ascent to power, Persia had a decentralized power-structure, in which different institutions battled for power, including both the military (the Qizilbash) and governors of the different provinces making up the empire. Shah Abbas wanted to undermine this political structure, and the recreation of Isfahan, as a Grand capital of Persia, was an important step in centralizing the power. The ingenuity of the square, or Maidān, was that, by building it, Shah Abbas would gather the three main components of power in Persia in his own backyard; the power of the clergy, represented by the Masjed-e Shah, the power of the merchants, represented by the Imperial Bazaar, and of course, the power of the Shah himself, residing in the Ali Qapu Palace.
TEXT.Chinese: 【TAB】1598年，当沙阿阿巴斯决定将其帝国的首都从西北部城市加兹温迁至伊斯法罕中心城市时，他发起了一项将成为波斯历史上最伟大的计划之一的计划：彻底改造这座城市。他选择了伊斯法罕这座由Zāyande roud（“赋予生命的河流”）肥沃的中心城市，作为一个在广阔的干旱地区中进行密集耕种的绿洲，从而使首都远离了萨非王朝和乌兹别克人的主要竞争对手奥斯曼人未来的任何进攻，同时获得了更多的控制权波斯湾，最近成为荷兰和英国东印度公司的重要贸易路线。[第2段]，城市规划这项艰巨的任务的总设计师是Shaykh Bahai（巴哈·阿丁-阿米利），他把这个计划集中在Shah Abbas的总体计划的两个主要特点：Chahar Bagh大道上，两边是该市所有著名的机构，如所有外国政要的住所，以及纳克什-伊贾汗广场（“世界典范”）。在沙阿上台之前，波斯的权力结构是分散的，不同的机构争夺权力，包括军队（齐齐尔巴什）和组成帝国的不同省份的统治者。阿巴斯想破坏这一政治结构，重建伊斯法罕，作为波斯的首都，是中央集权的重要一步。广场或女仆ān的巧妙之处在于，通过修建广场，沙阿阿巴斯将波斯权力的三个主要组成部分聚集在自己的后院；神职人员的权力，以玛斯吉德沙阿为代表；商人的权力，以帝国集市为代表；当然，沙阿自己的权力，住在阿里卡普宫。

TEXT.English: [H1]Stability[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The stability system from Rhye's and Fall has been replaced in Dawn of Civilization, which features a completely redesigned stability mechanic. The main principle of the new system are that there is no permanent stability score. Instead, every civilization has a stability level: Collapsing, Unstable, Shaky, Stable, or Solid. [PARAGRAPH:2]During the game, a number of events (see below) can trigger a stability check. During the check, a score is calculated that reflects the current stability of your empire on a variety of factors in the areas of expansion, economic, domestic, foreign and military. If the score is consistent with your stability level, it remains unchanged. But with exceedingly high or low scores, the stability can either drop or increase a level. However, stability only becomes threatening once it has been reduced all the way to Collapsing, and stability can only decrease or increase by one level by check. This means that higher stability levels provide a buffer against collapse. But even after falling all the way down to Collapsing, your civilisation is not doomed yet. If the next stability check results in the same or a higher stability score, even if it does not improve your stability level to Unstable, your civilisation will remain intact. Otherwise however, it will descend into total collapse and you lose the game. [H2]Stability Levels[\H2]Stability levels represent the overall stability of your empire. Stability levels are persistent and should not be confused with the stability score which is calculated on stability checks according to the rules described below, and then discarded. There are five stability levels from best to worst: [ICON_BULLET]Solid [ICON_BULLET]Stable [ICON_BULLET]Shaky [ICON_BULLET]Unstable [ICON_BULLET]Collapsing Your stability level can change during a stability check. As long it is higher than Collapsing, your empire is safe. High stability levels provide more protection from collapse, since every check can reduce your stability by at most one level. [H2]Stability Checks[\H2]A stability check is when the game determines the current stability score of your civilisation. The following events can trigger a stability check: [ICON_BULLET]losing a city [ICON_BULLET]razing a city (human only) [ICON_BULLET]discovering a technology [ICON_BULLET]becoming a vassal [ICON_BULLET]acquiring a vassal (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a war [ICON_BULLET]making peace (+) [ICON_BULLET]changing civics or state religion [ICON_BULLET]moving your capital [ICON_BULLET]building a wonder (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a golden age (+) [ICON_BULLET]receiving a great person (+) [NEWLINE]Events marked with a (+) are positive stability checks. These checks can never reduce your stability level, no matter how bad your stability score is. [NEWLINE]During a check, your stability score is calculated according to the rules described under Stability Influence Factors. This score is compared to the stability threshold. Based on this comparison, the stability check can have three possible outcomes: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability score exceeds the threshold by more than 10 points [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] The stability score is equal to or greater than the threshold (but by not more than 10 points) [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability score is less than the threshold [NEWLINE]The threshold itself depends on your situation. In particular, it depends on the current stability level: [ICON_BULLET]on solid: +20 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: +10 [ICON_BULLET]on shaky: 0 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: -10 [ICON_BULLET]on collapsing: -20 [NEWLINE]Due to the different thresholds, it becomes progressively harder to drop to a lower level, and easier to increase your level again. This means that unless something about your civilisation changes to affect your stability score, your stability level will ultimately settle on the level that reflects it. [NEWLINE]The threshold is lower during a Golden Age. This means that Golden Ages can save you from situations that would otherwise lead to collapse, and are the perfect time to increase stability levels again. [NEWLINE]The consequences of the outcome of a stability check are as follows: [BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability level increases by one. [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] The stability level remains unchanged. [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability level decreases by one. If the stability level already was on Collapsing, and the stability score is lower than at the last check, a complete collapse occurs.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]稳定度[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]稳定度是本模组最富特色的概念之一，是导致许多文明衰落的关键因素。当你的帝国扩张超过一定限度时，边远地区将会寻求独立，甚至导致爆发内战。本节内容将帮助你更好地了解稳定度的概念，以免你的帝国“莫名其妙地”解体。[PARAGRAPH:2]在内政顾问界面(F2)中添加了5个新显示区。显示区使用星级表示不同领域对稳定度的影响等级。3星为平均稳定度，所有文明初始时各领域的等级均为3星。3星级可使你的文明处于“安定”状态，国家不会发生分裂。处于“动荡”状态时，新文明可能在你的领土上诞生。如果是“极其动荡”状态，你将无法维持统治。连续数回合的“极其动荡”状态将导致爆发内战，仅剩首都还在你的控制之下。在“稳固”和“极其稳固”状态下，你可以放心地扩张帝国。你要时时注意本文明和其他文明的稳定度（在积分列表上以小图标表示）。“山顶”表示“动荡”或“极其动荡”，“平地”表示“安定”或“脆弱”，“山谷”表示“稳固”或“极其稳固”。[PARAGRAPH:2]5个显示区代表不同领域的稳定度等级。“城市”反映城市发展的影响；“内政法令”反映无政府状态持续时间及所选政策组合相配程度的影响。“经济因素”主要基于本文明的国民生产总值――包括商业、产能、食物及其他一些数值因素。“扩张因素”反映你的扩张是否超出“本土”（即在真实历史中的控制区域）以及是否实行“扩张主义”法令。“国外因素”反映别国的态度和外交关系水平。[PARAGRAPH:2]事实上稳定度的影响因素还有很多。你可以根据常识知道什么会带来稳定，什么会导致内战。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kingdom of Mapungubwe was a pre-colonial Southern African state located at the confluence of the Shashe and Limpopo rivers. It marked the centre of a pre-Shona kingdom, which covered parts of modern-day Botswana and Zimbabwe. The Kingdom was the first stage in a development that would culminate in the creation of the Kingdom of Great Zimbabwe. The history of Zimbabwe is vague; during the colonial-era Europeans went out of their way to warp the Kingdoms history for many reasons, such as the Great Zimbabwe ruins, which they intended to claim as their own. [PARAGRAPH:1]The date to which the Kingdom was found is unclear, with foundation placed anywhere from the fourth-century to the tenth. Though it is possible that it started wen earlier. Bantu migrants would settle in the area during the Great Bantu Expansion, there they merged with the other African societies already thriving there. The Bantu, together with the other African peoples, would develop the most complex civilisation in southern Africa, they would develop culture and kingship and the Kingdom of Mapungubwe would be born. The kingdom would thrive for centuries, constructing marvellous stone buildings and conducting trade with other kingdoms as far as Persia, Egypt, India and even China., It's lands full of rich resources, especially ivory and gold. Evidence of such trade with far away nations indicated that Mapungubwe had developed a complex financial system rather early, for Chinese artefacts dating back centuries were discovered in the ruins of Great Zimbabawe.[PARAGRAPH:1]Over time the traditional, family oriented Kingdom would expand northwards and grow into the medieval Kingdom of Great Zimbabwe, famous for it's majestic capital, Great Zimbabwe (of which the Kingdom takes it's name) the largest stone structure in African until recent times. But the Kingdom would also be known for it's vast riches in gold which it had in abundance and which would eventually bring it's downfall by the hands of greedy Imperialists. [PARAGRAPH:1] During the reign of the Kingdom of ZImbabwe, stone buildings and walls reached their apex, being grand architecture in the area, the kingdom would also expand it's rule to reach far and wide over the vast area of which they lay claim. The Kingdom of Zimbabwe controlled the ivory and gold trade from the interior to the southeastern coast of Africa. Asian and Arabic goods could be found in abundance in the Kingdom. Though, because the Kingdom was so inland and rather Isolationistic, it grew completely independent of any outside influence, that even when the coast was being infested by foreigners whom brought their own culture of destruction, the Kingdom of Zimbabwe would not even notice and thus grew to greatness with the foreign corruption by Arabs or Europeans. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Kingdom would continue to evolve, expanding north where they would become known as the Mutapa Kingdom of which quickly established rule of a vast area of Southern Africa, that by the time the first European Imperialists made contact, Mutapa would rule most of Southern Africa as the premier state in the whole region. Over time though, the Imperialistic Portuguese would come to dominate much of southeast Africa's coastline, laying waste to the peaceful Swahili city states of Sofala and Kilwa by the sixteenth century. Their main goal was to dominate the trade with India; however, they unwittingly became mere carriers for luxury goods between the Great Mutapa and the Orient. Mutapa proved invulnerable to attack and even economic manipulation due to the mwenemutapa's strong control over gold production. What posed the greatest threat to the Empire was infighting among different factions which led to opposing sides calling on the Portuguese for military aid. In 1629 the mwenemutapa attempted to throw out the Portuguese blight, but he failed and was overthrown, leading to the Portuguese installation of Mavura Mhande Felipe on the Throne. Under this Portuguese puppet, Mutapa signed treaties making it a Portuguese vassal and ceding gold mines to the Imperialists, however none of these concessions were ever put into effect and Mutapa managed to maintain nominal independence. All the while, Portugal increased control over much of southeast Africa with the beginnings of a wicked colonial system and the fall of Mutapa, of Zimbabwe, was under way. [PARAGRAPH:1]However the collapse of Mutapa to a Protuguese vassal would not go smoothly. Although rough progression afterwards, the legacy of Great Zimbabwe would live on free for years to come. The Rozwi not long after the initial fall of Mutapa, would move in and beat back the Portuguese, driving them far back only to retain a nominal presence at one of the fairs in the eastern highlands. The Rozwi would reestablish Zimbabwean rule of the area, over the years the Rozwi Empire would engage in battles with the Portugueses many times to fight for freedom, peace and liberty in Africa and the region would continue independence from the European Scourge that would bring about hell to the peoples of Africa. The Rozwi chiefs would carry on the traditions of the Great Zimbabweans, building in stone and constructing impressive cities throughout the southwest. The economic power of the Rozwi Empire was based on cattle wealth and farming while significant gold mining continued with less dominance on the Rozwi Economy. The Trade was established with Arab traders, metals such as gold and copper and ivory were exchanged for luxury goods. Records form the Portuguese account have shown that the Rozwi were expert military strategists and that they had used the cow-horn formation years before the Great Zulu leader Shaka had. Without the use of guns and cannons, but spears and bows and arrows, the belligerent Rozwi took over the plateau from the Imperialist European. However, despite complex political systems and bast wealth and culture, the Kingdom of Rozwi would eventually fall the imperialist they fought so hard to fend their people from. Over time, more Europeans would join forces with the Portuguese against the Rozwi and use trickery and deceit to turn brother against brother, and despite the Rozwi's mighty martial prowess, bows and arrows simple could not best guns and cannons and the determination of imperialistic ambition all the time. And thus, in the nineteenth century, the Great Zimbabwe legacy would come to an end.
TEXT.Chinese: 马本古布韦王国是殖民前的南部非洲国家，位于沙什河和林波波河的交汇处。它标志着前肖纳王国的中心，覆盖了现代博茨瓦纳和津巴布韦的部分地区。王国是发展的第一阶段，最终将建立大津巴布韦王国。津巴布韦的历史是模糊的；在殖民地时代，欧洲人出于许多原因，不遗余力地歪曲了王国的历史，例如他们打算声称自己拥有的津巴布韦大废墟。[段落：1Kingdom被发现的日期还不清楚，基金会从四世纪到第十日都在哪里。虽然它有可能是更早开始的。班图移民在班图大扩张期间定居在该地区，他们在那里与其他已经在那里繁荣昌盛的非洲社会融合在一起。班图人和其他非洲民族一起，将发展南部非洲最复杂的文明，他们将发展文化和王权，马邦古布韦王国将诞生。这个王国将繁荣昌盛几个世纪，建造奇形怪状的石头建筑，并与其他王国进行贸易往来，远至波斯、埃及、印度甚至中国，那里资源丰富，尤其是象牙和黄金。与遥远国家进行这种贸易的证据表明，马邦古布韦很早就发展了一个复杂的金融体系，因为在伟大的津巴布韦废墟中发现了几个世纪前的中国工艺品[段落：1]随着时间的推移，以家庭为中心的王国将向北扩张，发展成为中世纪的大津巴布韦王国，以其雄伟的首都而闻名，大津巴布韦是非洲直到近代为止最大的石头建筑。但是，这个王国也因其丰富的黄金财富而闻名，这些财富最终会被贪婪的帝国主义者所毁灭。[段落：1]在津巴布韦王国统治期间，石头建筑和城墙达到了顶峰，作为该地区的宏伟建筑，津巴布韦王国也将其统治范围扩大到他们所宣称的广大地区。津巴布韦王国控制着从非洲内陆到东南沿海的象牙和黄金贸易。亚洲和阿拉伯国家的商品在沙特王国随处可见。即使是外来的外来文化的影响，他们也完全独立了，因为他们的文化受到了外来的破坏，津巴布韦王国甚至不会注意到阿拉伯人或欧洲人的外国腐败，并因此而变得伟大起来。王国将继续发展，向北扩张，在那里他们将成为著名的穆塔帕王国，很快建立了对南部非洲广大地区的统治，到欧洲帝国主义者第一次接触时，穆塔帕将统治南部非洲大部分地区，成为整个地区的首要国家。然而，随着时间的推移，帝国主义的葡萄牙人将统治非洲东南部的大部分海岸线，到16世纪时，索法拉和基尔瓦这两个斯瓦希里人的和平城邦遭到破坏。他们的主要目标是主导与印度的贸易；然而，他们无意中变成了伟大的穆塔帕和东方之间的奢侈品运输公司。由于穆塔帕对黄金生产有着强大的控制力，穆塔帕在攻击甚至经济操纵方面都无懈可击。对帝国构成最大威胁的是不同派系之间的内讧，导致对立双方要求葡萄牙提供军事援助。1629年，姆韦内穆塔帕（mwenemutapa）试图推翻葡萄牙人的统治，但他失败并被推翻，导致葡萄牙人将马武拉·姆汉德·费利佩（Mavura Mhande Felipe）安置在皇位上。在这个葡萄牙傀儡统治下，穆塔帕签署了条约，使其成为葡萄牙的附庸，并将金矿拱手让给帝国主义者，但这些让步都没有生效，穆塔帕设法维持了名义上的独立。一直以来，随着邪恶的殖民体系的开始，葡萄牙加强了对非洲东南部大部分地区的控制，津巴布韦的穆塔帕（Mutapa）的垮台正在进行之中。[段落：1]然而，穆塔帕沦陷为普罗图人的附庸并不顺利。尽管后来进展很艰难，但伟大的津巴布韦的遗产将在未来几年里免费生活。在穆塔帕第一次沦陷后不久，罗兹维人就会进驻并击退葡萄牙人，把他们远远赶回去，只是为了在东部高地的一个集市上保留一个名义上的存在。罗兹维人将重新建立津巴布韦对该地区的统治，多年来，罗兹维帝国将多次与葡萄牙人交战，为非洲的自由、和平与自由而战，该地区将继续独立于给非洲人民带来地狱的欧洲灾祸。罗兹维酋长们将继承伟大的津巴布韦人的传统，在整个西南部建造令人印象深刻的城市。罗兹维帝国的经济实力是建立在牛的财富和农业的基础上的，而大量的金矿开采仍在继续，在罗兹维经济中的主导地位有所下降。这种贸易是与阿拉伯商人建立的，黄金、铜和象牙等金属被用来交换奢侈品。葡萄牙人的记录显示，罗兹维人是专家级的军事战略家，他们在伟大的祖鲁族领导人沙卡之前几年就使用了牛角阵。好战的罗兹维没有使用枪支和大炮，而是使用长矛和弓箭，从帝国主义的欧洲人手中接管了高原。然而，尽管政治制度复杂，财富和文化底蕴深厚，罗兹维王国最终还是会倒下，成为帝国主义者，他们奋力抵抗人民。随着时间的推移，越来越多的欧洲人会与葡萄牙人联手对抗罗兹维人，用诡计和欺骗手段来反目成仇，尽管罗兹维人有着强大的军事实力，但弓箭并不总是最好的武器和大炮以及帝国主义野心的决心。因此，在十九世纪，伟大的津巴布韦遗产将终结。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Clergy refers to a hierarchical and institutional structure within a religion. In particular, the clergy itself is the religious leadership present in various organised religions. The names of members of the clergy vary from religion to religion, but their duties are often similar: interpreting existing religious texts and traditions, resolving open religious questions, and administering the religious organisation itself. Since religion is often an important aspect in the legitimisation of secular power, clergy can often be involved in worldly government or even hold such power itself. The various Christian denominations are the most prominent examples here. The leader of Catholic Christianity, the Pope, once exercised control over much of Italy, and bishops and monastic orders used to rule regions of Europe without any dependence on a higher monarch.
TEXT.Chinese: 【TAB】神职人员是指宗教内部的等级和制度结构。特别是，神职人员本身就是各种有组织宗教中的宗教领袖。神职人员的姓名因宗教而异，但他们的职责往往相似：解释现有的宗教文本和传统，解决公开的宗教问题，以及管理宗教组织本身。由于宗教往往是世俗权力合法化的一个重要方面，神职人员往往可以参与世俗政府，甚至拥有这种权力本身。各种基督教教派是这里最突出的例子。天主教的领袖，教皇，曾经控制了意大利的大部分地区，主教和僧侣们曾经统治欧洲的一些地区，而不依赖于一个更高的君主。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Dromons were the most important warships of the Byzantine navy from the 6th to 12th centuries CE. They were indirectly developed from the ancient trireme and were usually propelled by both oars and sails, a configuration that had been used by navies in the Mediterranean Sea for centuries. Literary sources and accounts reveal that there were at least three varieties of dromon, while the exact relation of the dromon proper with the chelandion, a term with which it is often used interchangeably, somewhat unclear. These were, firstly the ousiakon which took its name from one company or ousia of 100 men. This was a two-banked galley with the lower rank rowing only, and the upper rank rowing or disengaging to fight when required. Secondly the slightly larger pamphylos with a crew of between 120 and 160. Thirdly the dromon proper, which had a crew of 200: 50 on the lower bank, and 100 on the upper bank in two files, together with 50 marines.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Dromons had a central tower (xylokastron: "wooden castle") near the main mast, from which the marines could use their bows and arrows or throw spears and other projectiles. Dromons were frequently equipped with flamethrowers (siphons) that discharged Greek fire and catapults capable of hurling 10kg projectiles up to 250 meters.
TEXT.Chinese: 德罗蒙是公元前6至12世纪拜占庭海军最重要的战舰。它们间接地从古代的三棱体发展而来，通常由桨和帆推动，这种结构已经被地中海的海军使用了几个世纪。文献来源和记载表明，dromon至少有三个变种，而dromon本体与chelandion的确切关系，这一术语经常被互换使用，有些不清楚。这些人，首先是从一个公司或100人的乌西亚肯取了它的名字。这是一个只有低级划艇的双排厨房，高级划艇或脱离需要时战斗。其次是稍大一点的潘菲洛斯，船员人数在120到160人之间。第三，dromon本体，它有一个200:50的船员在下岸，100在上岸两个文件，连同50名海军陆战队。[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]dromon有一个中心塔（xylokastron:“木制城堡”）靠近主桅，从那里海军陆战队可以使用他们的弓箭或投掷长矛和其他炮弹。机器人经常配备喷火器（虹吸管），喷火器可以释放希腊的火焰，弹射器可以发射10公斤的炮弹，射程可达250米。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Central planning represents an economy completely controlled, owned and planned by the government, otherwise known as state capitalism. Under a centrally planned economy, all labor, capital, production, agriculture, utilities, and finances are run by the government, and all service businesses are owned by the government. Because there are no private companies, no trade exists. Centrally planned economies are able to concentrate their resources on major projects such as world wonders and world projects, but are very costly to maintain.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]中央计划经济是指完全由政府控制、拥有和计划的经济，即国家资本主义。在中央计划经济体制下，所有的劳动力、资本、生产、农业、公用事业和财政都由政府管理，所有的服务业都归政府所有。因为没有私人公司，就没有贸易。中央计划经济体能够将资源集中在世界奇观和世界工程等重大项目上，但维护成本非常高。

TEXT.English: [H1]Brennus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Celtic Chieftain[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] ? - 279 BC[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Other than that he was a fearsome and successful warrior, little is known about the Celtic chieftain named Brennus. In 279 BC, he led an army of Celtic warriors on an invasion of Macedonia and northern Greece. They turned the Greek defense at the pass of Thermopylae and sacked the famous Oracle at Delphi - Brennus was wounded in the fighting. From there, the Celts penetrated into Epirus (roughly modern Albania) and looted the treasures stored at the temples of Zeus at Dodona and Olympia. After those triumphs the Greek resistance stiffened. Brennus retreated to Macedonia, where he died of his wounds. Without the leadership of their chieftain, the Celtic warriors split up and went in separate directions. Most of them returned to their homes in Gaul along with the treasure they had pillaged, while a few others headed east and settled in Asia Minor. This group came to be called the Galatians, and remained distinct from their surrounding neighbors for at least two centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]The name "Brennus" is more likely a title than a proper name - in fact the same title was later given to another Celtic chieftain who sacked Rome in 390 BC. It is very likely that the Welsh word "Brenin," meaning king, derived from that title.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]布雷努斯[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]凯尔特首领[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]背景:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]对于这位凯尔特人的首领布雷努斯，我们只知道他是一位令人敬畏的不败勇士。在公元前279年，他率领一支凯尔特人大军入侵马其顿与希腊北部。他们在温泉关突破希腊人的防御，并占领了著名的特尔斐神谕宣示所——布雷努斯本人在这场战斗中受伤。随后凯尔特人又攻入伊庇鲁斯（今属阿尔巴尼亚），洗劫了多东那和奥林匹亚的宙斯神庙。连续获得几场胜利后，希腊人的抵抗越来越强烈。布雷努斯因而退回到马其顿，并在那里伤重身死。失去了首领的凯尔特大军随即发生分裂，各自散去。大部分人带着他们劫掠的财宝返回高卢老家，也有一部分人继续向东，最终定居于小亚细亚。这部分凯尔特人后来又被称为迦拉太人，他们在此后两个世纪仍然保持着自己独特的文化。[PARAGRAPH:2:1]“布雷努斯”很可能并不是真正的名字，而是一个称号——事实上在公元前390年攻陷罗马城的另一位凯尔特人首领也被称为布雷努斯。威尔士语中的“布雷宁”（国王）一词很可能就源自于这个称号。[PARAGRAPH:2:1]

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Brooklyn Bridge is a hybrid cable-stayed/suspension bridge in New York City. It connects the boroughs of Manhattan and Brooklyn, spanning the East River. The Brooklyn Bridge has a main span of 1,595.5 feet (486.3 m) and a height of 276.5 ft (84.3 m) above mean high water. It is one of the oldest roadway bridges in the United States and was the world's first steel-wire suspension bridge, as well as the first fixed crossing across the East River.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Brooklyn Bridge started construction in 1869 and was completed fourteen years later in 1883. It was originally called the New York and Brooklyn Bridge and the East River Bridge, but it was later dubbed the Brooklyn Bridge, a name coming from an earlier January 25, 1867 letter to the editor of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle and formally so named by the city government in 1915. Over the years, the Brooklyn Bridge has undergone several reconfigurations; it formerly carried horse-drawn vehicles and elevated railway lines, but now carries vehicular, pedestrian, and bicycle traffic. Commercial vehicles are banned from the bridge.[PARAGRAPH:2]Since opening, the Brooklyn Bridge has become an icon of New York City, ranking among the city's most popular tourist attractions. It was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1964 and a National Historic Civil Engineering Landmark in 1972.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]布鲁克林大桥是纽约市的一座混合式斜拉/悬索桥。它连接曼哈顿和布鲁克林两个行政区，横跨东河。布鲁克林大桥的主跨为1595.5英尺（486.3米），高出平均高水位276.5英尺（84.3米）。它是美国最古老的公路桥梁之一，是世界上第一座钢丝悬索桥，也是第一条横跨东河的固定交叉口。〔2〕布鲁克林大桥于1869开始建造，十四年后于1883竣工。它最初被称为纽约和布鲁克林大桥和东河大桥，但后来被称为布鲁克林大桥，这个名字来源于1867年1月25日写给《布鲁克林每日鹰报》编辑的一封信，1915年被市政府正式命名。多年来，布鲁克林大桥经历了几次重组；它以前承载马车和高架铁路线，但现在承载车辆、行人和自行车交通。商业车辆被禁止进入大桥。[段：2 ]自开放以来，布鲁克林大桥已经成为纽约的一个标志，成为城市最受欢迎的旅游景点之一。1964年被定为国家历史地标，1972年被定为国家历史土木工程地标。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Duarte Barbosa reported that the ships from Java, which have four masts, are very different from Portuguese ships. A Javanese ship is made of very thick wood, and as it gets old, the Javanese fix it with new boards. The rope and the sail is made with osier. The Javanese junks were made using jaty/jati wood (teak) at the time of his report (1512), at that time Chinese junks were still using softwood as their main material. The Javanese ship's hull is formed by joining planks to the keel and then to each other by wooden dowels, without using either a frame (except for subsequent reinforcement), nor any iron bolts or nails. The vessel was similarly pointed at both ends, and carried two oar-like rudders and lateen-rigged sails. It differed markedly from the Chinese vessel, which had its hull fastened by strakes and iron nails to a frame and to structurally essential bulkheads which divided the cargo space. The Chinese vessel had a single rudder on a transom stern, and (except in Fujian and Guangdong) they had flat bottoms without keels.[7] Historical engravings also depict usage of bowsprits and bowsprit sails, with deckhouse above the upper deck, and the appearance of stemposts and sternposts.[PARAGRAPH:2]Barbosa also reported various goods carried by these ships, which include rice, meat of cows, sheep, pigs, and deer, dried and salted, many chickens, garlic, and onions. Traded weapons include lances, dagger, and swords, worked in inlaid metal and very good steel. Also brought with them cubebs and yellow die called cazumba (kasumba) and gold which is produced in Java. Barosa mention places and route in which these ships visited, which include Malacca, China, Molucca Islands, Sumatra, Tenasserim, Pegu, Bengal, Palicat, Coromandel, Malabar, Cambay, and Aden. The passenger brought their wives and children, even some of them never leave the ship to go on shore, nor have any other dwelling, for they are born and die in the ship.[PARAGRAPH:2]The size and special requirements of the djong demanded access to expertise and materials not available everywhere. Consequently, the djong was mainly constructed in two major shipbuilding centres around Java: north coastal Java, especially around Rembang-Demak (along the Muria strait) and Cirebon; and the south coast of Borneo (Banjarmasin) and the adjacent islands. A common feature of these places was their accessibility to forests of teak, as this wood was highly valued because of its resistance to shipworm. Southern Borneo's supply of teak would have come from north Java, whereas Borneo itself would supply ironwood. Pegu, which is a large shipbuilding port at the 16th century, also produced jong, built by Javanese who resided there.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]Duarte Barbosa报告说，爪哇岛的船只有四个桅杆，与葡萄牙的船只有很大不同。爪哇人的船是用很厚的木头做的，当它变旧时，爪哇人用新的木板把它修好。绳子和帆是用柳条做的。在他的报告（1512）中，爪哇帆船是用日本柚木（jaty/jati wood，柚木）制造的，当时中国帆船仍以软木为主要材料。爪哇船的船体是由木板连接到龙骨上，然后用木销钉相互连接而成，不使用框架（除了随后的加固），也不使用任何铁螺栓或钉子。这艘船的两头同样是尖的，上面有两个桨状的舵和拉蒂安式的帆。它明显不同于中国船只，中国船只的船体是用边条和铁钉固定在一个框架上的，而结构上是必不可少的舱壁将货舱隔开。中国船在船尾艉部有一个舵，（除了福建和广东），它们有平底无龙骨。（7）历史雕刻还描述了船首斜桅和船首帆的使用，甲板上方甲板甲板，船尾柱和艉柱的出现。〔段落：2〕巴博萨也报告了各种货物。这些船包括大米、牛肉、绵羊、猪和鹿、干的和腌制的、许多鸡、大蒜和洋葱。交易的武器包括长矛，匕首，和剑，镶嵌金属和非常好的钢。他们还带来了小熊崽和被称为卡祖巴（kasumba）的黄色骰子，以及用爪哇语生产的黄金。巴罗萨提到了这些船只访问的地点和路线，其中包括马六甲、中国、莫卢卡群岛、苏门答腊、特纳塞林、佩古、孟加拉、帕利卡特、科罗曼德尔、马拉巴、坎贝和亚丁。乘客带着他们的妻子和孩子，甚至他们中的一些人从不离开船上岸，也没有任何其他住所，因为他们在船上出生和死亡。[段落：2 ] Dung的尺寸和特殊要求要求不到任何地方都能获得专业知识和材料。因此，djong主要建造在爪哇岛周围的两个主要造船中心：爪哇岛北部沿海，特别是Rembang Demak（沿Muria海峡）和井里汶；婆罗洲南海岸（班加马辛）和邻近岛屿。这些地方的一个共同特点是可以进入柚木森林，因为这种木材由于对海虫的抵抗力而受到高度重视。婆罗洲南部的柚木供应将来自北爪哇，而婆罗洲本身将供应铁木。佩古是16世纪的一个大型造船港口，也生产了居住在那里的爪哇人建造的钟。

TEXT.English: [TAB]An artist is a person engaged in one or more of any of a broad spectrum of activities related to creating art, practicing the arts, and/or demonstrating an art. The common usage in both everyday speech and academic discourse is a practitioner in the visual arts only. The term is often used in the entertainment business, especially in a business context, for musicians and other performers (less often for actors). "Artiste" (the French for artist) is a variant used in English only in this context. Use of the term to describe writers, for example, is certainly valid, but less common, and mostly restricted to contexts like criticism.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]艺术家是指从事一项或多项与创造艺术、实践艺术和/或展示艺术有关的广泛活动的人。日常言语和学术话语中的普遍用法只是视觉艺术的实践者。这个词经常用于娱乐业，特别是在商业环境中，指音乐家和其他表演者（较少用于演员）“Artiste”（法语中的“Artister”）是仅在这种情况下使用的英语变体。例如，用这个词来形容作家，当然是有效的，但不太常见，而且大多局限于批评等语境。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Leopard (Panthera pardus) is one of the five "big cats" in the genus Panthera. It is a member of the Felidae family with a wide range in some parts of sub-Saharan Africa, West Asia, the Middle East, South and Southeast Asia to Siberia.[PARAGRAPH:1]Compared to other members of the Felidae, the leopard has relatively short legs and a long body with a large skull. It is similar in appearance to the jaguar, but is smaller and more slightly built. Its fur is marked with rosettes similar to those of the jaguar, but the leopard's rosettes are smaller and more densely packed, and do not usually have central spots as the jaguars do. Both leopards and jaguars that are melanistic are known as black panthers.[PARAGRAPH:1]The species' success in the wild is in part due to its opportunistic hunting behavior, its adaptability to habitats, its ability to run at speeds approaching 58 kilometres per hour (36 mph), its unequaled ability to climb trees even when carrying a heavy carcass, and its notorious ability for stealth. The leopard consumes virtually any animal that it can hunt down and catch. Its habitat ranges from rainforest to desert terrains.[PARAGRAPH:1]It is listed as Near Threatened on the IUCN Red List because it is declining in large parts of its range due to habitat loss and fragmentation, and hunting for trade and pest control. It is regionally extinct in Hong Kong, Singapore, Kuwait, Syria, Libya and Tunisia.
TEXT.Chinese: 豹（Panthera pardus）是Panthera属的五种“大猫”之一。它是Felidae家族的一员，在撒哈拉以南非洲、西南亚、中东、南部和南洋至西伯利亚的一些地区有广泛的分布。[段落：1 ]与Felidae的其他成员相比，豹子的腿相对短，身体长，头骨大。它在外观上与捷豹相似，但体积更小，结构更为小巧。它的皮毛上有与美洲虎相似的玫瑰花结，但美洲豹的玫瑰花结更小，更密集，通常没有美洲虎那样的中心斑点。黑豹和美洲豹都被称为黑豹。[段落：1 ]该物种在野外的成功部分是由于它的机会主义狩猎行为，其对栖息地的适应性，其运行速度接近每小时58公里（36英里/小时），它有着无与伦比的爬树能力，即使身上带着一具沉重的尸体，还有它臭名昭著的隐身能力。豹子几乎会吃掉任何它能猎捕到的动物。它的栖息地范围从雨林到沙漠地形。[段落：1 ]它被列为濒临灭绝的IUCN红色名单，因为它在大范围的范围内，由于栖息地的丧失和破碎化，狩猎贸易和害虫控制。它在香港、新加坡、科威特、叙利亚、利比亚和突尼斯都是区域性灭绝的。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Skilled horsemen dwelling in the northern steppes of the Black and Caspian Sea regions, the Cossack hosts had a tradition of fierce independence and, after decades of conflict, finally received privileges from the Russian government in return for military services. In the 16th century there were six major Cossack hosts: the Don, the Greben (in Caucasia), the Yaik (along the Ural River), the Volga, the Dnieper and the Zaporozhian (west of the Dnieper). Under the Russian umbrella, the Cossacks expanded eastward from their settlements in the Don and were early colonizers of Siberia. From the 18th through the 20th centuries, the Czars used Cossacks extensively to suppress revolutionary activities and conduct foreign wars.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the Russian Civil War (1918-20), the Cossacks in southern Russia formed the core of the White armies there and suffered extensively. Under Soviet rule, the Cossack communities ceased to function as distinctive entities.
TEXT.Chinese: 哥萨克东道主是居住在黑海和里海地区北部草原上的熟练骑兵，他们有着强烈的独立传统，经过几十年的冲突，最终获得了俄罗斯政府的特权，以换取军事服务。在16世纪有六个主要的哥萨克东道主：唐、格雷本（高加索）、亚克（沿乌拉尔河）、伏尔加、第聂伯河和扎波罗齐（第聂伯河以西）。在俄罗斯的保护伞下，哥萨克人从他们在唐的定居点向东扩张，是西伯利亚早期的殖民者。从第十八到第二十世纪，沙皇广泛地使用哥萨克来压制革命活动和进行外国战争。[段：1 ]在俄国内战期间（1918-20），俄罗斯南部的哥萨克形成了白人军队的核心，遭受了广泛的折磨。在苏联的统治下，哥萨克社区不再作为独特的实体发挥作用。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Dog Soldiers were the elite of the Cheyenne warriors and some of the most feared fighters in the American West. Members of a prestigious fraternal society, the Dog Soldiers each received a "Dog Sash" upon entrance into the group. While at first merely emblems of membership, the "Dog Sash" soon became a symbol of iron will in combat. This reputation stemmed from the Dog Soldier habit of, during particularly brutal combat, staking themselves to the ground by way of their "Dog Sash" and not moving from the spot until victory or death had overtaken them.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]狗兵是夏延勇士的精英，也是美国西部最令人畏惧的战士。作为一个著名的兄弟会成员，狗兵们在进入这个组织时每人都会收到一个“狗腰带”。虽然最初只是会员的象征，但“狗腰带”很快成为战斗中钢铁意志的象征。这种名声源于狗兵的习惯，在特别残酷的战斗中，他们用“狗腰带”把自己拴在地上，直到胜利或死亡超过他们才离开现场。

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the Arabian Peninsula, cavalrymen ride on either horse or camel. While horses are somewhat easier to train than camels, camels are the obvious choice for forces operating in the deep desert. Arab tribesmen such as the Bedouin have always been fearsome warriors, and their prowess with bow and arrow (and later, rifle) from atop a mount has become the stuff of legend.
TEXT.Chinese: 在阿拉伯半岛，骑兵骑的不是马就是骆驼。虽然马比骆驼更容易训练，但骆驼显然是在沙漠深处作战的部队的首选。像贝多因人这样的阿拉伯部落一直是可怕的战士，他们在山顶上用弓和箭（后来用步枪）的威力已经成为传奇。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Santa Maria del Fiore was built on the site of Florence's second cathedral dedicated to Saint Reparata; the first was the Basilica di San Lorenzo di Firenze whose first building was consecrated as a church in 393 by St. Ambrose of Milan. The ancient structure, founded in the early 5th century and having undergone many repairs, was crumbling with age, according to the 14th-century Nuova Cronica of Giovanni Villani, and was no longer large enough to serve the growing population of the city. Other major Tuscan cities had undertaken ambitious reconstructions of their cathedrals during the Late Medieval period, such as Pisa and particularly Siena where the enormous proposed extensions were never completed.[PARAGRAPH:2]The new church was designed by Arnolfo di Cambio and approved by city council in 1294. Di Cambio was also architect of the church of Santa Croce and the Palazzo Vecchio. He designed three wide naves ending under the octagonal dome, with the middle nave covering the area of Santa Reparata. The first stone was laid on 9 September 1296, by Cardinal Valeriana, the first papal legate ever sent to Florence. The building of this vast project was to last 140 years; Arnolfo's plan for the eastern end, although maintained in concept, was greatly expanded in size.[PARAGRAPH:2]After Arnolfo died in 1310, work on the cathedral slowed for thirty years. When the relics of Saint Zenobius were discovered in 1330 in Santa Reparata, the project gained a new impetus. In 1331, the Arte della Lana, the guild of wool merchants, took over patronage for the construction of the cathedral and in 1334 appointed Giotto to oversee the work. Assisted by Andrea Pisano, Giotto continued di Cambio's design. His major accomplishment was the building of the campanile. When Giotto died on 8 January 1337, Andrea Pisano continued the building until work was halted due to the Black Death in 1348.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1349, work resumed on the cathedral under a series of architects, starting with Francesco Talenti, who finished the campanile and enlarged the overall project to include the apse and the side chapels. In 1359, Talenti was succeeded by Giovanni di Lapo Ghini (1360-1369) who divided the center nave in four square bays. Other architects were Alberto Arnoldi, Giovanni d'Ambrogio, Neri di Fioravante and Andrea Orcagna. By 1375, the old church Santa Reparata was pulled down. The nave was finished by 1380, and by 1418, only the dome remained incomplete.[PARAGRAPH:2]On 18 August 1418, the Arte della Lana announced an architectural design competition for erecting Neri's dome. The two main competitors were two master goldsmiths, Lorenzo Ghiberti and Filippo Brunelleschi, the latter of whom was supported by Cosimo de Medici. Ghiberti had been the winner of a competition for a pair of bronze doors for the Baptistery in 1401 and lifelong competition between the two remained sharp. Brunelleschi won and received the commission.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ghiberti, appointed coadjutator, drew a salary equal to Brunelleschi's and, though neither was awarded the announced prize of 200 florins, was promised equal credit, although he spent most of his time on other projects. When Brunelleschi became ill, or feigned illness, the project was briefly in the hands of Ghiberti. But Ghiberti soon had to admit that the whole project was beyond him. In 1423, Brunelleschi was back in charge and took over sole responsibility.[PARAGRAPH:2]Work started on the dome in 1420 and was completed in 1436. The cathedral was consecrated by Pope Eugene IV on 25 March 1436, (the first day of the year according to the Florentine calendar). It was the first 'octagonal' dome in history to be built without a temporary wooden supporting frame. It was one of the most impressive projects of the Renaissance. During the consecration in 1436, Guillaume Dufay's motet Nuper rosarum flores was performed. The structure of this motet was strongly influenced by the structure of the dome.[PARAGRAPH:2]The decoration of the exterior of the cathedral, begun in the 14th century, was not completed until 1887, when the polychrome marble façade was completed with the design of Emilio De Fabris. The floor of the church was relaid in marble tiles in the 16th century.[PARAGRAPH:2]The exterior walls are faced in alternate vertical and horizontal bands of polychrome marble from Carrara (white), Prato (green), Siena (red), Lavenza and a few other places. These marble bands had to repeat the already existing bands on the walls of the earlier adjacent baptistery the Battistero di San Giovanni and Giotto's Bell Tower. There are two side doors: the Doors of the Canonici (south side) and the Door of the Mandorla (north side) with sculptures by Nanni di Banco, Donatello, and Jacopo della Quercia. The six side windows, notable for their delicate tracery and ornaments, are separated by pilasters. Only the four windows closest to the transept admit light; the other two are merely ornamental. The clerestory windows are round, a common feature in Italian Gothic.[PARAGRAPH:2]During its long history, this cathedral has been the seat of the Council of Florence (1439), heard the preachings of Girolamo Savonarola and witnessed the murder of Giuliano di Piero de' Medici on Sunday, 26 April 1478 (with Lorenzo Il Magnifico barely escaping death), in the Pazzi conspiracy.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]圣玛利亚教堂建于佛罗伦萨第二座圣里帕拉塔大教堂的遗址上；第一座是圣洛伦佐大教堂，其第一座建筑于393年被米兰圣安布罗斯奉为教堂。据14世纪乔瓦尼·维拉尼（Giovanni Villani）的努瓦·克罗尼卡（Nuova Cronica）说，这座建于5世纪初并经过多次修缮的古老建筑随着时间的推移而逐渐坍塌，已经不足以满足这座城市不断增长的人口。其他主要的托斯卡纳城市在中世纪后期进行了雄心勃勃的重建教堂，例如比萨，特别是锡耶纳，那里的巨大扩建提议从未完成。〔2〕新教堂是由阿诺尔福迪坎比奥设计的，并于1294由市议会批准。迪坎比奥也是圣克罗齐教堂和维奇奥宫的建筑师。他设计了三个宽的中殿，在八角形穹顶下结束，中间的中殿覆盖了圣雷帕拉塔地区。第一块石头是1296年9月9日，由红衣主教瓦莱利亚纳，第一位教皇使节派往佛罗伦萨。这项浩瀚工程的建设已经持续了140年，Arnolfo的东端计划虽然在概念上保持了很大的发展，但在1310年阿诺尔福去世后，大教堂的工作放缓了三十年。1330年，圣泽诺比乌斯的遗迹在圣雷帕拉塔被发现，这项工程获得了新的动力。1331年，羊毛商协会（Arte della Lana）接管了大教堂建设的赞助权，1334年任命乔托监督这项工作。在安德里亚·皮萨诺的协助下，乔托继续设计迪坎比奥的作品。他的主要成就是建造了帐篷。当沢田家康于1337年1月8日去世时，Andrea Pisano继续建筑，直到1348黑死病停止工作。（1349段：2），在一系列建筑师的带领下，大教堂开始恢复工作，Francesco Talenti完成了钟楼并扩大了整个工程，包括了APSE和侧礼拜堂。1359年，塔伦蒂被乔瓦尼·迪·拉波·吉尼（1360-1369）继承，他将中殿分为四个方形隔间。其他建筑师有阿尔贝托·阿诺迪、乔瓦尼·德安布罗乔、尼里·迪菲奥拉万特和安德里亚·奥卡尼亚。1375年，圣里帕拉塔老教堂被拆毁。中殿于1380完工，到1418为止，只有圆顶保持不完整。1418年8月18日，Arte della Lana宣布了一个建筑设计竞赛，以建造Neri的穹顶。两位主要竞争对手是两位金匠大师洛伦佐·吉贝蒂和菲利波·布鲁内莱斯基，后者得到了科西莫·德梅迪奇的支持。吉贝蒂曾在1401年的一场洗礼会铜门比赛中获胜，两人的终身竞争依然激烈。布鲁内列奇赢得并获得了该委员会。[段：2 ]吉贝尔蒂，任命的协调员，得到了与布鲁内列斯奇相等的薪水，尽管两人都没有获得200弗洛林斯的宣布奖，但他承诺了同样的荣誉，尽管他把大部分时间都花在了其他项目上。当布鲁内莱斯基生病，或假装生病时，这个项目就在吉贝蒂手中。但吉贝蒂很快不得不承认，整个项目超出了他的能力范围。1423，Brunelleschi重新掌权，承担了唯一的责任。[段：2 ]在1420号圆顶上开始工作，并于1436完成。教皇尤金四世于1436年3月25日（根据佛罗伦萨历法，这是一年中的第一天）将大教堂神圣化。这是历史上第一个没有临时木制支撑框架的“八角形”穹顶。这是文艺复兴时期最令人印象深刻的工程之一。在1436年的献祭中，纪尧姆·杜菲的《努珀·罗莎姆·弗洛雷斯汽车旅馆》演出。这一节的结构受穹顶结构的影响很大。[段落：2 ]十四世纪开始的大教堂外部的装饰，直到1887，当彩饰大理石面漆是用Emilio De Fabris的设计完成的时候才损坏。教堂的地板在十六世纪的大理石瓷砖中被复制。[段落：2 ]外墙是由Carrara（白）、Prato（绿）、锡耶纳（红）、Lavenza和其他一些地方交替的垂直和水平的多色大理岩带构成的。这些大理石镶边必须重复先前相邻的洗礼院巴蒂斯特罗圣乔瓦尼和乔托钟楼墙壁上已有的镶边。有两扇侧门：Canonici（南面）门和Mandorla（北面）门，门上有Nanni di Banco、Donatello和Jacopo della Quercia的雕塑。六扇侧窗以其精致的窗花和装饰而著名，由壁柱隔开。只有最靠近耳堂的四扇窗户可以采光；另外两扇只是装饰性的。教堂的窗户是圆的，是意大利哥特式的一个共同特征。[段：2 ]在其悠久的历史中，这座大教堂一直是佛罗伦萨议会（1439）的所在地，听取了萨伏那洛拉的传言，并目睹了星期日吉利亚诺·迪·皮耶罗·德梅第奇的谋杀案。1478年4月26日（洛伦佐·伊尔·马菲尼科勉强逃脱死亡），在帕齐阴谋中。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Babylonian Empire was, rather than a new idea, a reinvigoration of the old Sumerian Empire, which had also occupied what is today Southern Iraq. Babylonia was formed from a collection of roughly a dozen city states and was named for its capital city of Babylon. Originally a disorganized region, Babylon and Babylonia began to grow as a center for culture, trade, and religion under the rule of Hammurabi in 1728BC. Location of one of the seven ancient wonders - the Hanging Gardens - Babylonia became the jewel of the ancient world.[PARAGRAPH:2]Hammurabi was the first known ruler of united Babylonia as well as its greatest lawgiver. Hammurabi's Code of Laws regulated Babylonian life in such a way as to make the consequences of most criminal acts publicly known. Citizens could then structure their behavior based on these laws leading to a more organized society. So comprehensive was the Babylonian Code that little about its laws or governmental system changed in the entirety of its 1,200 years of existence. Babylon was so revered for this system that cities and states as far as the Mediterranean would emulate it for centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the death of Hammurabi (1750 BC), the empire slowly declined in power and influence until it was eventually conquered by the Kassites (around 1600 BC) from what are now the mountains of Iran. The Kassites ruled over Babylonia for 576 years, reinvigorating the empire under their reign. Although Hammurabi ruled over Babylonia as a series of interconnected city states, the Kassites were the first rulers of Babylonia to transform the country into an organized territory. The Kassites created trade routes to countries as far away as Greece, Armenia and Turkey. Trade with these nations brought further wealth and status to Babylonia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Towards the end of the Kassite era of rule, Babylonia once again began to fall into decline, in part due to external political and military pressure. In 627 BC, the last Kassite ruler died, and Babylonia revolted under the command of a new leader, Nabopolassar. Nabopolassar's son, Nebuchadnezzar II, ruled Babylonia and brought about another golden era. During his rule, Babylonia became a military power, invading and taking territory in Egypt and Assyria. Not long afterwards, in 539 BC, Cyrus of Persia invaded Babylonia, conquering it, and forever ending Babylonia's existence as an independent territory.[PARAGRAPH:2]Despite numerous regime changes, education reached exceptional heights among the Babylonians. Technical achievements such as the creation of a base 60, "sexigesimal," system of mathematics, are still used to this day. Sixty seconds per minute, sixty minutes per hour: modern time, is in fact, Babylonian time.[PARAGRAPH:2]Much like the Sumerian Empire from which they were descended, Babylonia was a nation of fanatical record-keepers. Starting with Hammurabi and continuing down until the empire's dissolution at the hands of Cyrus and the great Persian emperors, every financial transaction, every court verdict, every contract, and just about anything that could be written down, was - on clay tablets. With laws pertaining to almost every aspect of daily living, a significant amount of data was recorded, and much of this has been uncovered and excavated during the modern era. Researchers have even found several optical devices, similar to magnifying glasses, which were used to allow record keepers to write in smaller cuneiform, in order to fit more information on each clay tablet.[PARAGRAPH:2]Babylonia played an important role in the development of law throughout the world. The creation of Hammurabi's Code of Laws, and the zeal with which his successors, both blood-related and not, upheld those laws, demonstrated for all of history how successful and wealthy a nation could become by following an organized system of government.
TEXT.Chinese: 巴比伦帝国不是一个新的概念，而是旧苏美尔帝国的复兴，旧苏美尔帝国也占领了今天的伊拉克南部。巴比伦尼亚由十几个城邦组成，以其首都巴比伦命名。巴比伦和巴比伦尼亚最初是一个无组织的地区，在1728年汉谟拉比的统治下，开始发展成为文化、贸易和宗教中心。七个古代奇迹之一——悬空花园——Babylonia成为古世界的宝石。[段落：2 ] Hammurabi是巴比伦联合国的第一位统治者，也是最伟大的立法者。汉谟拉比的法律规范了巴比伦人的生活，使大多数犯罪行为的后果公之于众。公民可以根据这些法律来构建自己的行为，从而形成一个更有组织的社会。巴比伦法典如此全面，以至于在其1200年的历史中，其法律或政府制度几乎没有发生任何变化。巴比伦对这一制度非常崇敬，几个世纪以来，地中海沿岸的城市和国家将仿效它。〔2〕在Hammurabi逝世后（公元前1750年），帝国在权力和影响力上慢慢衰落，直到最终被卡西派（公元前1600年左右）从现在的伊朗山脉征服。卡西特人统治巴比伦长达576年，在他们的统治下重振了帝国。尽管汉谟拉比作为一系列相互联系的城邦统治着巴比伦，但卡西特人是巴比伦第一个将国家转变为有组织领土的统治者。卡斯特人开辟了通往希腊、亚美尼亚和土耳其等国的贸易路线。与这些国家的贸易给Babylonia带来了更多的财富和地位。[段落：2 ]在卡西特统治时代结束时，Babylonia再次开始衰落，部分原因是由于外部政治和军事压力。公元前627年，最后一位卡斯特统治者去世，巴比伦尼亚在一位新领袖纳波普拉萨尔的指挥下起义。拿伯拉萨的儿子尼布甲尼撒二世统治巴比伦，带来了另一个黄金时代。在他统治期间，巴比伦成为一个军事强国，入侵并占领了埃及和亚述的领土。此后不久，公元前539年，波斯的赛勒斯入侵Babylonia，征服了它，并永远结束了Babylonia作为一个独立领土的存在。[段：2 ]，尽管有许多政权的变化，教育在巴比伦人之间达到了异常的高度。科技成果，如创建60个基数的数学系统“sexigesimal”，至今仍沿用至今。每分钟六十秒，每小时六十分钟：事实上，现代时间，实际上是巴比伦时期。[段落：2 ]很像苏美尔帝国，从那时起，Babylonia是一个狂热的记录守护者的国家。从汉谟拉比开始，一直到帝国在赛勒斯和伟大的波斯皇帝手中解体，每一笔金融交易，每一个法庭判决，每一份合同，以及几乎任何可以写下来的东西，都在泥板上。随着法律几乎涉及到日常生活的方方面面，大量的数据被记录下来，其中大部分是在现代被发现和挖掘出来的。研究人员甚至发现了几种类似放大镜的光学装置，它们用来让记录保管员以较小的楔形文字书写，以适应更多的关于每一块粘土片的信息。[段落：2 ] Babylonia在全世界的法律发展中发挥了重要作用。汉谟拉比法典的制定，以及他的继任者，无论是否与血缘有关，都支持这些法律的热情，在历史上证明了一个国家通过遵循一个有组织的政府体系可以变得多么成功和富有。

TEXT.English: [H1]Kanmu[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of Japan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 737 - 806 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Kammu's personal name (imina) was Yamabe. He was the eldest son of Prince Shirakabe (later known as Emperor Konin), and was born prior to Shirakabe's ascension to the throne. According to the Shoku Nihongi, Yamabe's mother, Yamato no Niigasa (later called Takano no Niigasa), was a descendant of King Muryeong of Baekje.[PARAGRAPH:2]After his father, Konin, became emperor, Kammu's half-brother Prince Osabe was appointed to the rank of crown prince. His mother Princess Inoe was a daughter of Emperor Shomu; but instead of Prince Osabe, it was Kammu who was later named to succeed their father. After Princess Inoe and Prince Osabe were confined and then died in 775, Prince Osabe's sister - Kammu's half-sister Princess Sakahito - became Kammu's wife. Later, when he ascended to the throne in 781, Kammu appointed his young brother, Prince Sawara, whose mother was Takano no Niigasa, as crown prince. Hikami no Kawatsugu, a son of Emperor Temmu's grandson Prince Shioyaki and Shomu's daughter Princess Fuwa, attempted to carry out a coup d'état in 782, but it failed and Kawatsugu and his mother were sent into exile. In 785, Prince Sawara was expelled and died in exile.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kammu had 16 empresses and consorts, and 32 imperial sons and daughters. Among them, three sons would eventually ascend to the imperial throne: Emperor Heizei, Emperor Saga and Emperor Junna. Some of his descendants (known as the Kammu Taira or Kammu Heishi) took the Taira hereditary clan title, and in later generations became prominent warriors. Examples include Taira no Masakado, Taira no Kiyomori, and (with a further surname expansion) the Hojo clan. The waka poet Ariwara no Narihira was one of his grandsons.[PARAGRAPH:2]Emperor Kammu is traditionally venerated at his tomb; the Imperial Household Agency designates Kashiwabara no Misasagi, Kashiwabara Imperial Mausoleum), in Fushimi-ku, Kyoto, as the location of Kammu's mausoleum.[PARAGRAPH:2]Earlier Imperial sponsorship of Buddhism, beginning with Prince Shotoku (574-622), had led to a general politicization of the clergy, along with an increase in intrigue and corruption. In 784 Kammu shifted his capital from Nara to Nagaoka in a move that was said to be designed to edge the powerful Nara Buddhist establishments out of state politics-while the capital moved, the major Buddhist temples, and their officials, stayed put. Indeed there was a steady stream of edicts issued from 771 right through the period of Kukai's studies which, for instance, sought to limit the number of Buddhist priests, and the building of clan temples. However the move was to prove disastrous and was followed by a series of natural disasters including the flooding of half the city. In 785 the principal architect of the new capital, and royal favourite, Fujiwara no Tanetsugu, was assassinated.[PARAGRAPH:2]Meanwhile, Kammu's armies were pushing back the boundaries of his empire. This led to an uprising, and in 789 a substantial defeat for Kammu's troops. Also in 789 there was a severe drought and famine-the streets of the capital were clogged with the sick, and people avoiding being drafted into the military, or into forced labour. Many disguised themselves as Buddhist priests for the same reason. Then in 794 Kammu suddenly shifted the capital again, this time to Heian-kyo, which is modern day Kyoto. The new capital was started early the previous year, but the change was abrupt and led to even more confusion amongst the populace.[PARAGRAPH:2]Politically Kammu shored up his rule by changing the syllabus of the university. Confucian ideology still provided the raison d'etre for the Imperial government. In 784 Kammu authorised the teaching of a new course based on the Annals of Spring and Autumn based on two newly imported commentaries: Kung-yang, and Ku-liang. These commentaries used political rhetoric to promote a state in which the Emperor, as "Son of Heaven," should extend his sphere of influence to barbarous lands, thereby gladdening the people. In 798 the two commentaries became required reading at the government university.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kammu also sponsored the travels of the monks Saicho and Kukai to China, from where they returned to found the Japanese branches of, respectively, Tendai and Shingon Buddhism.

TEXT.English: [H1]Corporations in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Corporation headquarters and executives have been removed in Dawn of Civilization. Instead, corporations spread on their own to cities that can attract them. To be able to attract a corporation, you need to have the associated technology and control at least one of the consumed resources. The chance increases by acquiring more resources, constructing appropriate buildings or adopting the Free Market civic. The number of cities per corporation is limited, so corporations can also leave one city and move to another that fulfills its requirements better. Certain corporations also compete with each other, reducing the chance of being present in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Silk Route and Trading Company corporations behave differently from the others. They don't require the Corporation technology to spread to your cities, but are limited to certain historical regions of the map. Also, they expire after a certain date and start to leave your cities.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]“文明的曙光”中的公司[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]“文明的曙光”中已经剔除了公司总部和公司经理。然而， 公司可以自己在城市之间推广。为了吸引公司，你需要拥有相关科技以及控制至少一种所需资源。尽可能多的资源，合适的建筑以及自由市场体制，能够增加公司的出现几率。每座城市能够入驻的公司名额是有限的，所以公司也可以从一座城市搬迁到另一座城市以满足它的需求。某些公司也会互相竞争，所以某些公司出现在同一座城市的机会降低。[PARAGRAPH:2]丝绸之路和贸易公司的运作方式与其他公司不同。它们不需要特定的科技，但是它们的传播范围被严格限制在特定的历史区域内。并且，它们会在指定的某个日期离开你的城市。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mars is the focus of much scientific study about possible human colonization. Mars's surface conditions and past presence of liquid water make it arguably the most hospitable planet in the Solar System besides Earth. Other than Venus, Mars requires less energy per unit mass (delta-v) to reach from Earth than any planet.[PARAGRAPH:2]Permanent human habitation on other planets, including Mars, is one of science fiction's most prevalent themes. As technology advances, and concerns about humanity's future on Earth increase, arguments favoring space colonization gain momentum. Other reasons for colonizing space include economic interests, long-term scientific research best carried out by humans as opposed to robotic probes, and sheer curiosity.[PARAGRAPH:2]Both private and public organizations have made commitments to researching the viability of long-term colonization efforts and to taking steps toward a permanent human presence on Mars. Space agencies engaged in research or mission planning include NASA, Roscosmos, and the China National Space Administration. Private organizations include SpaceX, Lockheed Martin, and Boeing.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]火星是许多关于人类可能殖民的科学研究的焦点。火星的表面条件和过去液态水的存在，使它可以说是太阳系中除了地球之外最适宜居住的行星。除了金星之外，火星需要更少的单位质量能量（ΔV）从地球到达比任何行星。[段：2 ]永久性人类居住在其他行星，包括Mars，是科幻小说中最流行的主题之一。随着技术的进步，人们对人类在地球上的未来的担忧与日俱增，支持太空殖民的论调愈演愈烈。开拓太空的其他原因包括经济利益、人类最好进行的长期科学研究，而不是机器人探测器，和纯粹的好奇心。[段落：2 ]私人组织和公共组织都致力于研究长期殖民努力的可行性，并采取措施在Mars上建立永久性的人类存在。从事研究或任务规划的航天机构包括美国国家航空航天局（NASA）、俄罗斯宇宙航空公司（Roscosmos）和中国国家航天局（China National Space Administration）。私人组织包括SpaceX、洛克希德马丁公司和波音公司。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Teotihuacan was a major city in the Valley of Mexico during the classical period of Mesoamerica. Established sometime between 200 and 100 BC, it reached its apex in power, culture and size around 450 AD. It was then the largest city in the Americas and at least the sixth largest in the world, with over 125,000 inhabitants, and multi-floor apartment complexes to house the large population. The identity of the cultural group who built the city is not known, and neither is its original name (it has been called Puh by the Maya, and Tollan or Teotihuacan by Nahuatl speakers). It has been conjectured that the city was multi-ethnic, with residential areas reserved for the various groups.[PARAGRAPH:2]It is not known for certain whether Teotihuacan was the center of an empire, but traces of its influence, either military or cultural, have been found all over Mesoamerica, notably in the Maya areas. Teotihuacan was known for its artisanry, obsidian industry and trade, and monumental architecture. Its Pyramid of the Sun is one of the largest pyramids in the world; other major monuments include the Pyramid of the Moon and Pyramid of the Feathered Serpent. The religion of the Tehuaticanos shared many common traits with other Mesoamerican mythology, such as a feathered serpent god, but its primary deity was a Great Goddess.[PARAGRAPH:2]Teotihuacan was sacked and partly destroyed around 550 AD, and concurrently experienced a decline in population. By the 7th or 8th century, its civilization had collapsed, and the center of power in the region moved to other cities such as Tula, the capital of the Toltecs. Later, the Aztecs considered the ruins of the city as a holy place and pilgrimage site; the name 'Teotihuacan' was given by them and means 'birthplace of the gods'. Today, Teotihuacan is a major tourist destination in the Mexico City area.
