TEXT.English: [TAB]Longbowmen were highly skilled archers capable of firing up to six arrows a minute over long distances into massed enemy formations. Using bows constructed from a type of wood called Yew, they used arrows specifically designed to penetrate chainmail armor - even plate if close enough. Frequently they would comprise approximately four-fifths of an army, and their devastating attacks helped to reverse the dominance of knights in warfare. Only lightly-armored, they enjoyed a great mobility advantage should their opponents survive their barrages.[PARAGRAPH:1]Once gunpowder began to find applications in the military, their use began to wane. Guns allowed foot soldiers the same effectiveness against knights, but without the decades of training required to be proficient with the longbow.
TEXT.Chinese: 长弓手是非常训练有素的射手，他们每分钟能发射六支箭，在很远的距离攻击敌人的密集军阵。长弓是用紫杉木制作的，箭也是特制的，可以穿透链甲，如果距离足够近，甚至还能穿透片甲。在中世纪军队中，长弓手的比例往往占到五分之四，他们毁灭性的攻击力抵销了骑士在战争中的优势。由于身穿轻便护甲，长弓手部队相当机动灵活，能够及时与侥幸冲过箭雨的敌人脱离接触。[PARAGRAPH:2]但是当火药开始应用于军事时，长弓手开始退出历史的舞台。火器使得步兵能象长弓手一样有效地对抗骑士，而且不用再象长弓手那样长年苦练了。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Hanging Gardens were a distinctive feature of ancient Babylon. They were a great source of pride to the people, and were often described in accounts written by visitors to the city. Possibly built by King Nebuchadnezzar II in 600 BC, the gardens are believed to have been a remarkable feat of engineering: an ascending series of tiered gardens containing all manner of trees, shrubs, and vines. The gardens were said to have looked like a large green mountain constructed of mud bricks, rising from the center of the city.
TEXT.Chinese: 空中花园是古巴比伦的一个特色。他们是人民骄傲的源泉，经常被到城里来的人写在帐上。这些花园可能是由尼布甲尼撒二世于公元前600年建造的，据信是一项非凡的工程壮举：一系列由各种树木、灌木和藤蔓组成的阶梯式花园。据说这些花园看起来像是一座由泥砖砌成的绿色大山，从市中心拔地而起。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A floodplain, or flood plain, is a flat or nearly flat land adjacent to a stream or river that stretches from the banks of its channel to the base of the enclosing valley walls and experiences flooding during periods of high discharge. It includes the floodway, which consists of the stream channel and adjacent areas that carry flood flows, and the flood fringe, which are areas covered by the flood, but which do not experience a strong current.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]漫滩，或漫滩，是指与河流或河流相邻的平坦或接近平坦的土地，从其河道的河岸延伸到封闭的谷壁底部，在高流量期间经历洪水。它包括由河道和承载洪水的邻近区域组成的防洪道，以及被洪水覆盖但不经历强流的洪水边缘区域。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Old Synagogue is an Orthodox Jewish synagogue in the Kazimierz district of Kraków, Poland, in Yiddish it was referred to as the Alta Shul. It is the oldest synagogue building still standing in Poland, and one of the most precious landmarks of Jewish architecture in Europe. Until the German invasion of Poland in 1939, it was one of the most important synagogues in the city as well as the main religious, social, and organizational centre of the Kraków Jewish community. In 1794 General Tadeusz Kościuszko spoke from the synagogue to gain the Jewish support in the struggle for Polish independence. A plaque in the entrance hall commemorates this event:[PARAGRAPH:2]The Synagogue was built in 1407 or 1492; the date of building varies with several sources. The original building was rebuilt in 1570 under the watchful eye of an Italian architect Mateo Gucci. The rebuilding included the attic wall with loopholes, windows placed far above ground level, and thick, masonry walls with heavy buttressing to withstand siege, all features borrowed from military architecture. There was further reconstruction work in 1904 and in 1913The Old synagogue is a rare, surviving example of a Polish Fortress synagogue.[PARAGRAPH:2]The synagogue was completely devastated and ransacked by the Germans during World War II. Its artwork and Jewish relics, looted. During the occupation, the synagogue was used as a magazine. In 1943, 30 Polish hostages were executed at its wall. The Old Synagogue was renovated from 1956 to 1959 and currently operates as a museum. It is a Division of the Historical Museum of Kraków, with particular focus on Kraków's Jews. The exhibits are divided into themes dealing with birth, prayer rituals, diet, divorce and death. "The beautiful women's prayer room, which dates from the 17th century, is often used to hold temporary exhibitions."
TEXT.Chinese: 老犹太教堂是一个正统的犹太教堂，位于波兰克拉科夫的卡齐米尔兹区，在意第绪语中被称为阿尔塔舒尔。它是波兰现存最古老的犹太教堂建筑，也是欧洲犹太建筑最珍贵的地标之一。直到1939年德国入侵波兰，它一直是该市最重要的犹太教堂之一，也是克拉科夫犹太社区的主要宗教、社会和组织中心。1794年，塔德乌斯将军在犹太教堂发表讲话，争取犹太人在争取波兰独立的斗争中的支持。入口处的牌匾纪念这一事件：[段落：2 ]犹太教会堂建于1407或1492；建筑的日期有多种来源。1570年，在意大利建筑师马蒂奥·古奇（Mateo Gucci）的监视下，重建了这座原始建筑。重建工程包括有漏洞的阁楼墙，远远高于地面的窗户，以及厚的砖墙和坚固的扶壁以抵御围攻，这些都是从军事建筑中借来的。在1904和1913年有进一步的重建工作。旧犹太教会堂是波兰堡垒犹太教堂的一个罕见的幸存例子。[第2段]第二次世界大战期间，犹太会堂被德国彻底摧毁并洗劫一空。它的艺术品和犹太文物被洗劫一空。在占领期间，犹太教堂被用作杂志。1943年，30名波兰人质在柏林墙被处决。旧犹太教堂从1956年到1959年进行了翻修，目前是一个博物馆。它是克拉科夫历史博物馆的一个分部，特别关注克拉科夫的犹太人。展品分为出生、祈祷仪式、饮食、离婚和死亡等主题。”美丽的女性祈祷室始建于17世纪，经常用来举办临时展览。”

TEXT.English: [TAB]The University of Sankore was located in the city of Timbuktu during the height of the Empire of Mali. Founded in the late tenth century AD, the main building was located in Sankore Mosque, a spectacular pyramid-shaped work of architecture. During the sixteenth century AD, the University of Sankore stood at the heart of a great Islamic center of learning. Scholars traveled across the Islamic world from as far away as India and Persia to visit the famed school.[PARAGRAPH:1]The organization of the University of Sankore was very different from that of medieval European universities. It had no central administration, student registers, or prescribed courses of study: instead, it was composed of many entirely independent colleges, each run by a single "imam" (scholar). Students associated themselves with an imam (rather than with a subject or department) and instruction was often carried out on an individual basis. Anyone could establish a college if he so wished; not surprisingly, the quality of the different schools was said to be very uneven.[PARAGRAPH:1]Courses took place in the open courtyards of mosques or in private homes. The primary focus of the university was study of the Qur'an, although some imams gave lessons in history, astronomy, and logic. Scholars were encouraged to write their own books because it was profitable to do so - in the Islamic world at that time, books commanded a much higher price than gold or slaves. Among the most famous scholars at the University of Sankore was Ahmed Baba, a highly-distinguished historian quoted often in Islamic scholarship.[PARAGRAPH:1]Unfortunately, the best scholars left the school during the Moroccan invasion of Mali in the 1590s and did not return later. Sankore was never able to recover its former glory.
TEXT.Chinese: 桑科雷大学在马里帝国全盛时期创立，位于庭巴克图古城。其主体建筑即桑科雷清真寺，建于公元10世纪晚期，外形类似金字塔。在16世纪，桑科雷大学是伊斯兰学术的中心。伊斯兰世界各地学者——有的来自遥远的印度和波斯——都集中到这里参观学习。[PARAGRAPH:2]桑科雷大学的教学组织形式与中世纪的欧洲大学有很大差异。它没有集中管理体制，学生也无须注册，也没有预设的课程：整个大学是由许多独立的学院组成的，每个学院由一位“依玛目”（学者）主持。学生从属于某一位学者（而不是某一个专业或系），教学活动往往是个别进行的。任何学者都可以建立自己的学院，当然，不同的学院之间教学水平相差很大。[PARAGRAPH:2]教学是在清真寺的庭院或是私人住宅中进行的。桑科雷大学最主要的学习科目就是《古兰经》，也有许多学者教授历史、天文和逻辑学。学者撰写著作受到鼓励，而且收益不菲——在当时的伊斯兰世界，书籍的价格同黄金或奴隶一般高。桑科雷大学最著名的学者之一是优秀的历史学家艾哈迈德·巴巴，在伊斯兰世界拥有很高的声誉。[PARAGRAPH:2]不幸的是，在16世纪90年代摩洛哥人入侵马里期间，大批优秀的学者被迫离开，此后的桑科雷大学再也未能重现昔日的辉煌。[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Las Lajas Sanctuary in southwest Colombia has made a name for its stunning architecture and a series of legends involving the appearance of the Holy Virgin and a mysterious mural of which nobody knows the origins. Located in the southwestern Colombian state of Nariño, the Las Lajas Sanctuary sits on a 130 feet tall bridge built over the Guaitara river at less than seven miles from the Ecuadorian border. The neo-Gothic church was erected by worshipers between 1916 and 1953 and replaced a shrine first built in the mid-18th century.[PARAGRAPH:2]According to popular belief, the Virgin Mary appeared to a woman and her deaf-mute daughter in 1754 at exactly the same place where the church is now standing. The woman, Maria Meneses de Quiñones, and her daughter, Rosa, were passing by the Guaitara river when they found themselves hiding from a storm. At that moment, Rosa shouted "Mum, the Virgin is calling me!" and pointed to the appearing virgin. The woman kept quiet about the miracle until something even more incredible happened. When Rosa died, Mueces returned to the place where they had seen Virgin Mary to pray for her daughter's soul. The virgin then miraculously revived Rosa, and mother and daughter could no longer keep the miracle a secret. The first shrine in the honor of Jesus's mother was built a few years after the alleged appearance, according to the journal of a friar who was traveling the region between 1756 and 1764. Half a century later, in 1802, a bigger shrine was built and worshipers erected the first version of the bridge that now allows access to the church.[PARAGRAPH:2]The miraculous appearing of the virgin is only the first of a number of legends and mysteries linked to the Las Lajas Sanctuary. For example, nobody knows who made the image of the Virgin Mary that is at the end of the church, behind the altar. According to some, the image was seen first when Mueces wanted to show a priest and other locals where her daughter had been revived. On arrival, the worshipers saw the image of the Virgin Mary and Jesus carved in a stone wall. The image attracts thousand of pilgrims every year. Las Lajas received canonical coronation from the Vatican in 1952 and was made a minor basilica in 1994.
TEXT.Chinese: 哥伦比亚西南部的拉斯拉哈斯圣殿以其令人惊叹的建筑和一系列传说而闻名，其中包括圣母玛利亚的出现和一幅神秘的壁画，没有人知道它的起源。拉斯拉哈斯保护区位于哥伦比亚西南部的纳里尼奥州，坐落在瓜伊拉河上一座130英尺高的桥梁上，距离厄瓜多尔边境不到7英里。新哥特式教堂是在1916至1953年间由崇拜者竖立起来的，取代了建于18世纪中叶的一座神龛。[段落：2 ]根据大众的信仰，处女玛丽在1754岁时出现在一个女人和她聋哑的女儿面前。这名妇女玛丽亚·梅内塞斯·德奎尼奥斯和她的女儿罗莎在经过瓜伊拉河时发现自己躲过了暴风雨。这时，罗莎喊道：“妈妈，处女在叫我！”指着那个出现的处女。这个女人对奇迹保持沉默，直到发生了更不可思议的事情。罗莎死后，穆埃塞斯回到他们见到圣母玛利亚的地方，为她女儿的灵魂祈祷。于是，圣母奇迹般地复活了罗莎，母女俩再也不能保守这个奇迹的秘密了。据1756年至1764年间游历该地区的一位修士的日记记载，第一座纪念耶稣母亲的圣殿是在据称出现的几年后建造的。半个世纪以后，在1802，建造了一座更大的神龛，礼拜者竖起了第一座桥，现在允许进入教堂。[段落：2 ]处女的神奇出现只是传说中的第一个，与拉斯拉贾斯圣殿相连。例如，没有人知道圣母玛利亚是谁在教堂的尽头，圣坛的后面塑造的。据一些人说，这张照片是在Mueces想向牧师和其他当地人展示她女儿复活的地方时第一次看到的。到达时，崇拜者看到了刻在石墙上的圣母玛利亚和耶稣的形象。这一形象每年吸引成千上万的朝圣者。拉斯拉哈斯于1952年接受梵蒂冈的加冕礼，并于1994年成为一个小教堂。

TEXT.English: [H1]Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios Ponte y Blanco[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Gran Colombia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1783 - 1830 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Simon Bolivar was one of South America's greatest generals. His victories over the Spaniards won independence for Bolivia, Panama, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Venezuela. He is called El Liberator (The Liberator) and the "George Washington of South America."[PARAGRAPH:2]Bolivar was born in July 24, 1783, at Caracas, Venezuela. His parents died when he was a child and he inherited a fortune. As a young man, he traveled in Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]As he returned to Venezuela, Bolivar joined the group of patriots that seized Caracas in 1810 and proclaimed independence from Spain. He went to Great Britain in search of aid, but could get only a promise of British neutrality. When he returned to Venezuela, and took command of a patriot army, he recaptured Caracas in 1813 from the Spaniards.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Spaniards forced Bolivar to retreat from Venezuela to New Granada (now Colombia), also at war with Spain. He took command of a Colombian force and captured Bogota in 1814. The patriots, however, lacked men and supplies, and new defeats led Bolivar to flee to Jamaica. In Haiti he gathered a force that landed in Venezuela in 1816, and took Angostra (now Ciudad Bolivar). He also became dictator there.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bolivar marched into New Granada in 1819. He defeated the Spaniards in Boyar in 1819, liberating the territory of Colombia. He then returned to Angostura and led the congress that organized the original republic of Colombia (now Ecuador, Colombia, Panama, and Venezuela). Bolivar became its first president on December 17, 1819.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bolivar crushed the Spanish army at Carabobo in Venezuela on June 24, 1821. Next, he marched into Educador and added that territory to the new Colombian republic. After a meeting in 1822 with another great liberator, Bolivar became dictator of Peru. His army won a victory over the Spaniards at Auacucho in 1824, which needed Spanish power in South America. Upper Peru became a separate state, named Bolivia in Bolivar's honor, in 1825. The constitution, which he drew up for Bolivia, is one of his most important political pronouncements.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]安东尼奥·D·La桑特Sima特立尼达Palyvar Palacios Ponte Yy布兰科[\H1] [Brang] Grand哥伦比亚总统[Brut] [NealLe] [Brd]：[\BOLD ] 1783到1830 Ad [新行] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[ Brd]（段落：1）Simon Bolivar是南美洲最伟大的将军之一。他战胜西班牙人为玻利维亚、巴拿马、哥伦比亚、厄瓜多尔、秘鲁和委内瑞拉赢得了独立。他被称为El Liberator（解放者）和“美国南部的乔治华盛顿”（段落：2）玻利瓦尔出生于1783年7月24日，在委内瑞拉的加拉加斯。他小时候父母去世了，他继承了一笔财产。作为一个年轻人，他在欧洲旅行。[段：2 ]当他回到委内瑞拉时，Bolivar加入了爱国者集团，在1810占领加拉加斯并宣布脱离西班牙独立。他去英国寻求援助，但只能得到英国中立的承诺。当他回到委内瑞拉并指挥一支爱国者军队时，他在1813从西班牙人手中夺回了加拉加斯。[第2段]西班牙人强迫Bolivar从委内瑞拉撤退到新格拉纳达（现在的哥伦比亚），也和西班牙作战。1814年，他指挥哥伦比亚军队占领了波哥大。然而，爱国者缺乏人手和补给，新的失败导致玻利瓦尔逃到牙买加。1816年，他在海地集结了一支军队，登陆委内瑞拉，占领了安哥拉（现为Ciudad玻利瓦尔）。他也成为了独裁者。[段：2 ]玻利瓦尔在1819进入了新格拉纳达。1819年，他在博亚尔击败西班牙人，解放了哥伦比亚的领土。然后，他回到安哥斯图拉，领导了组织哥伦比亚共和国（现为厄瓜多尔、哥伦比亚、巴拿马和委内瑞拉）的国会。1819年12月17日，Bolivar成为第一任总统。[段：2 ]玻利瓦尔于1821年6月24日在委内瑞拉卡拉沃沃粉碎西班牙军队。下一步，他进军埃杜卡多，并将该领土添加到新的哥伦比亚共和国。在1822年与另一位伟大的解放者会面后，玻利瓦尔成为秘鲁的独裁者。1824年，他的军队在奥阿库乔战胜了西班牙人，那里需要西班牙在南美洲的力量。1825年，上秘鲁成为一个独立的国家，以玻利维亚的名义命名为玻利维亚。他为玻利维亚起草的宪法是他最重要的政治宣言之一。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A sejmik was a name of various local parliaments throughout the history of Poland. The first sejmiks were regional assemblies in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, and earlier in the Kingdom of Poland. Sejmiks existed until the end of the Commonwealth in 1795 following the partitions of the Commonwealth. In a limited form, some sejmiks existed in partitioned Poland, and later, in the Second Polish Republic. In modern Poland, since 1999, the term has been revived as a voivodeship sejmik (sejmik województwa), referring to the elected council of each of the 16 voivodeships.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]议会是波兰历史上各种地方议会的名称。第一届议会是波兰-立陶宛联邦和波兰王国的地区议会。在1795年英联邦分裂之后，塞米克一直存在到英联邦结束。在一个有限的形式，一些Sejmik存在于分裂的波兰，后来，在第二个波兰共和国。在现代波兰，自1999年以来，这一术语被重新命名为“voivodeship sejmik”（sejmik województwa），指的是16个voivodeships中每一个的民选理事会。

TEXT.English: [H1]Atlatl Cauac[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of Teotihuacan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 364 - 439 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Atlatl Cauac, translated as Spearthrower Owl, is the name given to a 4th and 5th century figure known from Maya inscriptions. He is thought to have ruled Teotihuacan during the height of its power. He may have been responsible for introducing some features of Teotihuacan culture in the Maya lands, and have installed a warlord named Siyaj K'ak' to rule Maya cities such as Tikal.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]Atlatl Cauac[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of Teotihuacan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 364 - 439 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Atlatl Cauac, translated as Spearthrower Owl, is the name given to a 4th and 5th century figure known from Maya inscriptions. He is thought to have ruled Teotihuacan during the height of its power. He may have been responsible for introducing some features of Teotihuacan culture in the Maya lands, and have installed a warlord named Siyaj K'ak' to rule Maya cities such as Tikal.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Artificial satellites are spacecraft that maintain an orbit around a celestial body. What differentiates an orbit from other types of space flight is it doesn't require any additional propulsion. Satellites can hold a number of different orbits. One type is a polar orbit, which causes the spacecraft to pass over the north and south poles. Another is an equatorial orbit, which causes the satellite to circle the Earth's equator. The farther the orbit from the surface of the earth, the longer it takes to complete a circuit of the earth. If the vessel uses an equatorial orbit at a distance of 22,300 miles from Earth, it can achieve geo-synchronous orbit, which causes the satellite to remain stationary over a specific area.
TEXT.Chinese: 人造卫星是维持绕天体轨道的航天器。轨道与其他类型的太空飞行的区别在于它不需要任何额外的推进力。卫星可以保持许多不同的轨道。一种是极轨，它使航天器越过南北极。另一个是赤道轨道，它使卫星绕地球赤道运行。轨道离地球表面越远，绕地球一圈所需的时间就越长。如果飞船使用距地球22300英里的赤道轨道，它可以实现地球同步轨道，从而使卫星在特定区域保持静止。

TEXT.English: [H1]Afonso Henriques[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Portugal[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.1109 - 1185 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Afonso I of Portugal, more commonly known as Afonso Henriques and also known as the Conqueror (o Conquistador), was the first King of Portugal, declaring his independence from Leon. He fought several successful campaigns against the Moors and, on July 26, 1139, he obtained an overwhelming victory in the Battle of Ourique, and straight after was unanimously proclaimed King of Portugal by his soldiers. This meant that Portugal was no longer a vassal county of Leon-Castile, but an independent kingdom in its own right. Next, he assembled the first assembly of the estates-general at Lamego, where he was given the crown from the archbishop of Braga, to confirm the independence.[PARAGRAPH:2]Independence, however, was not a thing a land could choose on its own. Portugal still had to be acknowledged by the neighbouring lands and, most importantly, by the Roman Catholic Church and the Pope. Afonso wedded Mafalda of Savoy, daughter of Count Amadeo III of Savoy, and sent Ambassadors to Rome to negotiate with the Pope. In Portugal, he built several monasteries and convents and bestowed important privileges to religious orders. In 1143, he wrote to Pope Innocent II to declare himself and the kingdom servants of the Church, swearing to pursue driving the Moors out of the Iberian peninsula. Bypassing any king of Castile or Leon. Afonso declared himself the direct liegeman of the Papacy. Thus, Afonso continued to distinguish himself by his exploits against the Moors, from whom he wrested Santarém and Lisbon in 1147. He also conquered an important part of the land south of the Tagus River, although this was lost again to the Moors in the following years.[PARAGRAPH:2]Meanwhile, King Alfonso VII of Castile (Afonso's cousin) regarded the independent ruler of Portugal as nothing but a rebel. Conflict between the two was constant and bitter in the following years. Afonso became involved in a war, taking the side of the Aragonese king, an enemy of Castile. To ensure the alliance, his son Sancho was engaged to Dulce Berenguer, sister of the Count of Barcelona, and princess of Aragon. Finally, in 1143, the Treaty of Zamora established peace between the cousins and the recognition by the Kingdom of Castile and Leon that Portugal was an independent kingdom.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1179 the privileges and favours given to the Roman Catholic Church were compensated. In the papal bull "Manifestis Probatum", Pope Alexander III acknowledged Afonso as King and Portugal as an independent land with the right to conquer lands from the Moors. With this papal blessing, Portugal was at last secured as a country and safe from any Castilian attempts of annexation.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1184, in spite of his great age, he had still sufficient energy to relieve his son Sancho, who was besieged in Santarém by the Moors. He died shortly after, in 1185.[NEWLINE]The Portuguese revere him as a hero, both on account of his personal character and as the founder of their nation.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]葡萄牙语[ Afonso Henriques ] [Brut]国王葡萄牙[新行] [BOLD]生活：[\BOLD ] C.110-9- 1185 Ad[新行] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[Brut] [段落：1 ]葡萄牙的Afonso I，更常被称为Afonso Henriques，也被称为征服者（O征服者），是葡萄牙的第一位国王，宣布他脱离列昂。他与摩尔人进行了几次成功的战役，1139年7月26日，他在奥里克战役中取得了压倒性的胜利，紧接着他的士兵们一致宣布他为葡萄牙国王。这意味着葡萄牙不再是利昂卡斯蒂尔的附庸国，而是一个独立的王国。接下来，他在拉米戈召集了第一批议会成员，在那里他从布拉加大主教那里获得了皇冠，以确认独立性。[段落：2 ]然而，独立不是一个土地可以自行选择的东西。葡萄牙仍然必须得到邻国的承认，最重要的是，必须得到罗马天主教会和教皇的承认。阿方索与萨伏伊伯爵阿马迪奥三世的女儿萨伏伊的马法尔达结婚，并派大使到罗马与教皇谈判。在葡萄牙，他修建了几座修道院和修道院，并赋予宗教组织重要的特权。1143年，他写信给教皇英诺森二世，宣布自己和教会的王国仆人，发誓要把摩尔人赶出伊比利亚半岛。绕过任何卡斯蒂利亚或里昂国王。阿方索宣称自己是教皇的直接领袖。因此，阿丰索继续以其对摩尔人的战绩而闻名，1147年他从摩尔人手中夺取了圣塔勒姆和里斯本。他还征服了塔格斯河以南的一个重要部分，尽管后来在摩尔人的土地上又一次失掉了。[段：2 ]同时，卡斯蒂利亚国王阿方索七世（Afonso的堂兄）把葡萄牙的独立统治者视为反叛者。在接下来的几年里，这两个国家之间的冲突是不断的，而且是激烈的。阿丰索卷入了一场战争，站在卡斯蒂利亚的敌人，阿拉贡国王一边。为了确保结盟，他的儿子桑丘与巴塞罗那伯爵的妹妹、阿拉贡公主杜尔斯贝伦格订婚。最后，在1143，萨莫拉条约建立了表亲之间的和平，并承认卡斯蒂利亚王国和列昂承认葡萄牙是一个独立的王国。[段：2 ]在1179，给予罗马天主教堂的特权和恩惠得到补偿。教皇亚历山大三世在教皇的公牛“Probatum宣言”中承认阿丰索是国王，葡萄牙是一个独立的国家，有权征服摩尔人的土地。在这张教皇的祝福下，葡萄牙终于成为了一个国家，安全不受任何卡斯蒂利亚企图的兼并。[第2段] 1184，尽管他年纪大了，他仍然有足够的精力去救他的儿子桑丘，他被摩尔人围困在Santar。1185年，他去世不久，葡萄牙人把他尊为英雄，这既是因为他的个人性格，也是他们国家的缔造者。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The principle behind printing is not very complicated, but immense amounts of complexity are invested in the mass production of printed documents. Invented by Johannes Gutenberg in the mid-15th century, the early printing presses used a flat tray of inked type. Once paper was placed over the type, a surface was applied and the ink was pressed into the paper. While an improvement over the traditional duplication methods of the time (being meticulous hand-scribing of volumes), it was a slow and tedious process to use. Around 1800 the first cylinder press was created, followed by the large and immensely fast rotary presses.[PARAGRAPH:2]Today, computers have taken this ancient art out of the craftsman's workshop and placed it on the desktop. Desktop publishing revolutionized the creation of printed documents, not only from the standpoint of speed and accuracy, but also by enabling anyone to mass-produce the printed word without investing the many years it takes to learn the trade.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]印刷的原理并不十分复杂，但大量的复杂性投资于印刷文件的批量生产。15世纪中叶，约翰内斯·古腾堡发明了早期的印刷机，使用的是一种墨水型的平板印刷机。把纸放在铅字上后，涂上表面，墨水被压在纸上。虽然这是对当时传统复制方法的改进（对卷进行细致的手工抄写），但使用起来却是一个缓慢而乏味的过程。大约1800，第一个圆柱形压力机被创造出来，紧接着是巨大而非常快的旋转式压力机。[段：2 ]今天，计算机把这个古老的艺术从工匠的车间里取出，放在桌面上。桌面出版不仅从速度和准确性的角度，而且通过使任何人能够大规模生产印刷品，而不必花费多年时间来学习这一行业，彻底改变了印刷文档的创作。

TEXT.English: [H1]Krishnadevaraya[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of Vijayanagara Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1471 - 1529 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Krishnadevaraya was an emperor of the Vijayanagara Empire who reigned from 1509-1529. He is the third ruler of the Tuluva Dynasty. Presiding over the empire at its zenith, he is regarded as an icon by many Indians. Krishna Deva Raya earned the titles Kannada Rajya Rama Ramana (lit, "Lord of the Kannada empire"), Andhra Bhoja and Mooru Rayara Ganda (lit, "King of three Kings"). He became the dominant ruler of the peninsula of India by defeating the Sultans of Bijapur, Golconda, the Bahmani Sultanate and the Raja of Odisha. The great south Indian mathematician Nilakantha Somayaji also lived in the Empire of Krishnadevaraya. He was the most powerful of all the Hindu rulers of India. Indeed, when the Mughal Babur was taking stock of the potentates of north India, Krishnadevaraya was rated the most powerful and had the most extensive empire in the subcontinent.[PARAGRAPH:2]Portuguese travellers Domingo Paes and Fernao Nuniz also visited the Vijayanagara Empire during his reign. Krishna Deva Raya benefited from the able prime minister Timmarusu, who was regarded by the emperor as a father figure and was responsible for his coronation. Krishna Deva Raya was the son of Tuluva Narasa Nayaka, an army commander under Saluva Narasimha Deva Raya, who later took control of the empire to prevent its disintegration and became the founder of the Tuluva Dynasty, the third Hindu Dynasty to rule Vijayanagara. The emperor's coronation took place on the birthday of Hindu God Krishna. He built a beautiful suburb near Vijayanagara called Nagalapura. The king was of medium height, had a cheerful disposition, and was reputed to be respectful to foreign visitors, ruthless in maintaining the law, and prone to fits of anger. He maintained himself to a high level of physical fitness through daily exercises. Travelogues indicate that the king was not only an able administrator, but also an excellent general, leading from the front in battle and even attending to the wounded. The south Indian poet Muku Timmana praised him as the destroyer of the Turks.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1] KrasHNaDavaLay[[H1] [Brang] VijayaaGARA帝国的皇帝[Brut] [新行] [BOLD ]：[\BOLD ] 1471到1529 AD [新行] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[段：1 ] Krishnadevaraya是VijayaGaar帝国的皇帝，在位于159年至1529年。他是图卢瓦王朝的第三任统治者。在帝国鼎盛时期，他是许多印度人心目中的偶像。克里希纳·德瓦·瑞亚获得了卡纳达·拉吉亚·拉玛·拉玛娜（光明，“卡纳达帝国之主”）、安得拉博贾和穆鲁·瑞亚拉·甘达（光明，“三王之王”）的称号。他击败了比雅普尔苏丹、戈尔康达苏丹、巴哈马苏丹国和奥迪沙国王，成为印度半岛的统治者。伟大的南印度数学家Nilakantha Somayaji也生活在克里希纳德瓦雷亚帝国。他是印度所有印度教统治者中最有权势的。事实上，当莫卧儿巴布正在研究印度北部的权贵时，Krishnadevaraya被认为是最强大的，在次大陆中拥有最广泛的帝国。[段：2 ]葡萄牙旅行者Domingo Paes和Fernao Nuniz在他的统治期间也访问了VijayaGaar帝国。克里希纳·德瓦·雷亚受益于能干的总理蒂马鲁苏，他被皇帝视为父亲，并对他的加冕负责。克里希纳·德瓦·雷亚是图卢瓦·纳拉萨·纳亚卡的儿子，他是萨卢瓦·纳拉西姆哈·德瓦·雷亚手下的一名陆军指挥官，后来他控制了帝国以防止帝国解体，并成为图卢瓦王朝（第三个统治维贾亚纳加拉的印度教王朝）的创始人。皇帝的加冕典礼是在印度神克里希纳的生日当天举行的。他在Vijayanagara附近建立了一个美丽的郊区，叫做Nagalapura。国王中等身材，性情开朗，被认为是对外国访客的尊重，在维护法律方面冷酷无情，容易发怒。他通过日常锻炼使自己保持高水平的身体健康。游记表明，国王不仅是一个能干的管理者，而且是一个优秀的将军，在战斗中从前线领导，甚至照顾伤员。南印度诗人木库提马纳称赞他是土耳其人的毁灭者。

TEXT.English: [TAB]An assembly plant is a building or complex of buildings where workers build goods from their component parts, which are created on-the-spot or in factories elsewhere. In many cases the goods are assembled using an "assembly line" style of production in which individual parts are added to the product by a number of workers, each of whom performs his or her actions in sequence as the product moves down the production line. The plant also may include a warehouse to store parts as well as the finished products.[PARAGRAPH:1]Although a relative latecomer to the Industrial Revolution and manufacturing in general, by the early twentieth century the German plants were among the most efficient in the world. During the First and Second World Wars German plants built thousands of tanks, planes, and other war materiel under horrendous conditions and in the face of concentrated Allied bombing attacks. Into the twenty-first century the German manufactories remain among the world's best.
TEXT.Chinese: 装配工厂由单个厂房或者一组厂房建筑构成，工人们将本厂生产的、或是从其他工厂进货的零件组装成产品。装配工厂往往采用“生产流水线”进行装配，在“生产流水线”上，整个装配工作被分割成若干道工序，每个工人只在流水线上完成自己的一部分工序。装配工厂有时也包括储存货物的仓库。[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]尽管德国在工业革命时代中是一个后起者，但到了20世纪早期，德国工厂已处于世界上最有效率的工厂之列。在一战和二战期间，德国工厂生产了成千上万的坦克、飞机和其他战略物资，而且这些成就都是在非常艰难的条件——例如盟军的集中轰炸之下完成的。进入21世纪，德国的制造业仍然是世界一流的。

TEXT.English: [TAB]When discovered, paper revolutionized information technology. Before the advent of paper, scholars and writers used a number of different materials upon which to record their words. These included clay tablets, animal skins, silk, and others. These suffered from many shortcomings. Clay was bulky and fragile, animal skins were expensive, silk was expensive and fragile, and so forth - and none of them would have been suitable for use in a printing press.[PARAGRAPH:2]Papyrus was the earliest form of paper. It was created by cutting the stem of the papyrus plant into strips, which were laid in an overlapping pattern and pounded into a sheet. The material was then dried and polished. While serviceable, the resulting sheet is fairly thick and, more importantly, subject to rot in damp climates.[PARAGRAPH:2]Paper as we know it today was invented in China in around 100 AD. Wood and other fibrous material is mixed with liquid and mashed into a pulp, which is then poured onto fine screens. The liquid drains away, leaving a thin layer of fibrous material on the wire. When this material dries, it becomes paper. The Chinese official Cai Lun is credited with adding cotton rags to the pulp; the resulting paper was far sturdier than earlier versions. The Chinese process spread slowly throughout the world, reaching Europe around 1300 AD.[PARAGRAPH:2]When paired with the printing press - yet another Chinese invention - paper exponentially increased the spread of information and art.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]纸一经发明便革命性地改变了信息传播技术。在纸出现之前，学者和作家用了很多种材料来记录他们的话语：泥板、兽皮、丝绸等。这些材料有很多缺点。泥板太大且易碎，兽皮很贵，丝绸又贵又易撕裂――所有的这些材料都不适用于印刷。[PARAGRAPH:2]纸草是最早一种纸。把纸草的茎削成很薄的长条，再把这些长条重叠在一起用力捶打成片状。如此一来这种材料就变得干燥而光滑。尽管它很耐用，纸草仍然很厚，更要命的是，在潮湿的气候下它会腐烂。[PARAGRAPH:2]我们现在知道的纸是公元100年左右在中国发明的。把木头和其他含纤维的材料混合在水中捣成纸浆，再把这些纸浆刷在平滑的墙上。水分排干之后，就留下了一层纤维材料。等这层材料干后，就变成了纸。中国官员蔡伦把棉絮加入到纸浆中，这样造出的纸比早期的产品更坚韧。中国的造纸术传播得很缓慢，直到公元1300年左右才传播到欧洲。[PARAGRAPH:2]当造纸和印刷术（又一项中国人的发明）相配合时，信息与艺术的传播速度便获得了指数级的提升。

TEXT.English: [H1]Cleopatra VII Philopator[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ptolemaic Queen of Egypt[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 69 - 30 BC[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Cleopatra VII Philopator was the last person to rule Egypt as an Egyptian pharaoh - after she died, Egypt became a Roman province.[PARAGRAPH:2]She was a member of the Ptolemaic dynasty of Ancient Egypt, and therefore was a descendant of one of Alexander the Great's generals who had seized control over Egypt after Alexander's death. Most Ptolemeis spoke Greek and refused to learn Egyptian, which is the reason that Greek as well as Egyptian languages were used on official court documents like the Rosetta Stone. By contrast, Cleopatra learned Egyptian and represented herself as the reincarnation of an Egyptian Goddess.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cleopatra originally ruled jointly with her father Ptolemy XII Auletes and later with her brothers, Ptolemy XIII and Ptolemy XIV, whom she married as per Egyptian custom, but eventually she became sole ruler. As pharaoh, she consummated a liaison with Gaius Julius Caesar that solidified her grip on the throne. She later elevated her son with Caesar, Caesarion, to co-ruler in name.[PARAGRAPH:2]After Caesar's assassination in 44 BC, she aligned with Mark Antony in opposition to Caesar's legal heir, Gaius Iulius Caesar Octavianus (later known as Augustus). With Antony, she bore the twins Cleopatra Selene II and Alexander Helios, and another son, Ptolemy Philadelphus. Her unions with her brothers produced no children. After losing the Battle of Actium to Octavian's forces, Antony committed suicide. Cleopatra followed suit, according to tradition killing herself by means of an asp bite on August 12, 30 BC. She was briefly outlived by Caesarion, who was declared pharaoh, but he was soon killed on Octavian's orders. Egypt became the Roman province of Aegyptus.[PARAGRAPH:2]Though Cleopatra bore the ancient Egyptian title of pharaoh, the Ptolemaic dynasty was Hellenistic, having been founded 300 years before by Ptolemy I Soter, a Macedonian Greek general of Alexander the Great. As such, Cleopatra's language was the Greek spoken by the Hellenic aristocracy, though she was reputed to be the first ruler of the dynasty to learn Egyptian. She also adopted common Egyptian beliefs and deities. Her patron goddess was Isis, and thus, during her reign, it was believed that she was the re-incarnation and embodiment of the goddess of wisdom. Her death marked the end of the Ptolemaic Kingdom and Hellenistic period and the beginning of the Roman era in the eastern Mediterranean.[PARAGRAPH:2]To this day, Cleopatra remains a popular figure in Western culture. Her legacy survives in numerous works of art and the many dramatizations of her story in literature and other media, including William Shakespeare's tragedy Antony and Cleopatra, Jules Massenet's opera Cléopâtre and the 1963 film Cleopatra. In most depictions, Cleopatra is put forward as a great beauty and her successive conquests of the world's most powerful men are taken to be proof of her aesthetic and sexual appeal. In his Pensées, philosopher Blaise Pascal contends that Cleopatra's classically beautiful profile changed world history: "Cleopatra's nose, had it been shorter, the whole face of the world would have been changed.
TEXT.Chinese: 〔H1〕克莉奥帕特拉七世VII PiopPoto[[Brut] ]埃及托勒密女王[〔Brut]〕[新加坡]〔Brand〕〔69〕BC〔新行〕[〔Brut〕〕背景〔段落：1〕克利奥帕特拉七世是埃及最后一位统治埃及法老的人。在她死后，埃及成为罗马省。〔段落：2〕她是Ptolemaic的一员。古埃及的一个王朝，因此是亚历山大大帝的一位将军的后裔，他在亚历山大死后控制了埃及。大多数托勒密人讲希腊语，拒绝学习埃及语，这就是为什么希腊语和埃及语被用于官方法庭文件，如罗塞塔石。相比之下，克利奥帕特拉学会了埃及人，并把自己描绘成埃及女神的化身。[段：2 ]克莉奥帕特拉七世最初与她的父亲托勒密Xi Aules共同统治，后来与她的兄弟托勒密十三世和Ptolemy XIV，她按照埃及习俗结婚，但最终她成了唯一的统治者。作为法老，她完成了与凯撒的联络，巩固了她对王位的控制。后来，她将儿子凯撒，恺撒里昂提升为共同统治者。[段：2 ]凯撒在公元前44年遇刺后，她与Mark Antony对抗凯撒的合法继承人盖乌斯-尤利乌斯·恺撒-奥塔维亚努斯（后来称为Augustus）。她和安东尼生了一对双胞胎克利奥帕特拉·赛琳娜二世和亚历山大·赫利俄斯，还有一个儿子托勒密·菲拉德尔弗斯。她和兄弟们的结合没有产生孩子。在被屋大维军队打败后，安东尼自杀了。克利奥帕特拉紧随其后，根据传统，她在公元前8月12日，30日通过一个asp咬自杀。凯撒里昂宣布她为法老，但不久就奉屋大维之命被杀。埃及成为古埃及的埃及人省。[段落：2 ]虽然克莉奥帕特拉七世拥有古埃及法老的称号，托勒密王朝是希腊化的，300年前由马其顿希腊裔Alexander the Great将军Ptolemy I Soter创立。因此，克利奥帕特拉的语言是希腊贵族所说的希腊语，尽管她被认为是该王朝第一个学习埃及语的统治者。她还采用了埃及的共同信仰和神灵。她的守护神是伊西斯，因此，在她统治期间，人们相信她是智慧女神的化身和化身。她的死亡标志着托勒密王国和希腊化时期的结束和地中海东部罗马时代的开始。[段：2 ]直到今天，克莉奥帕特拉七世仍然是西方文化中一个受欢迎的人物。她的遗产保存在众多的艺术作品和许多戏剧化的文学和其他媒体，包括莎士比亚的悲剧安东尼和克利奥帕特拉，朱尔斯马塞内特的歌剧克莱奥普特雷和1963年的电影克利奥帕特拉她的故事。在大多数描写中，克利奥帕特拉被认为是一位伟大的美人，她对世界上最有权势的男人的连续征服被认为是她的审美和性吸引力的证明。哲学家布莱斯·帕斯卡在《画笔》中认为，克利奥帕特拉古典美的侧面改变了世界历史：“克利奥帕特拉的鼻子，如果再短一点，整个世界的面貌都会改变。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The earliest military forces were simply the citizens of the city, armed with whatever implements they could use as weapons. Although a militia made up of warriors was inexpensive, they were no match for organized armies. Warriors were usually used as stopgap measures while waiting for superior units to be trained, or to defend a city that had been temporarily cut off from military support. In a crisis situation, an assembly of warriors is better than no defense at all.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]最早的军事力量只是城市的居民，他们携带任何可以用作武器的工具。虽然由战士组成的民兵不贵，但他们不是有组织的军队的对手。在等待上级部队接受训练或保卫一座暂时与军事支援隔绝的城市时，战士通常被用作权宜之计。在危机的情况下，一个战士集会总比没有防御要好。

TEXT.English: [H1]Ramón Castilla y Marquesado[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Peru[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1797 - 1867 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ramón Castilla y Marquesado was a Peruvian caudillo and President of Peru four times. His earliest prominent appearance in Peruvian history began with his participation in a commanding role of the army of the Libertadores that helped Peru become an independent nation. Later, he led the country when the economy boomed due to the exploitation of guano deposits. Castilla's governments are remembered for having abolished slavery and modernized the state.[PARAGRAPH:2]He assumed the presidency for the first time after general Domingo Nieto's death for a short period in 1844, then in 1845 until 1851, again from 1855 to 1862 and, finally, during a brief period in 1863.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1] Castilla·Y MrCuulAD[\H1] [Brd]秘鲁总统[粗体] [新行] [ BOLD ]损坏：[\BOLD ] 1797到1867 AD [新行] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[ Brd]（段落：1）RAMN Castilla y Marquesado是秘鲁的卡迪罗和秘鲁总统四次。他在秘鲁历史上最早的显赫露面始于他在帮助秘鲁成为一个独立国家的解放军中担任统帅角色。后来，他领导国家时，经济繁荣，由于开发鸟粪存款。卡斯蒂利亚的政府因废除奴隶制和使国家现代化而被铭记。[段：2 ]他在Domingo Nieto将军死后1844年中第一次担任总统，然后在1845到1851年间再次执政，从1855年到1862年，最后在1863年的短暂时期。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A howitzer is a type of artillery piece characterized by a relatively short barrel and the use of comparatively small propellant charges to propel projectiles over relatively high trajectories, with a steep angle of descent.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the taxonomies of artillery pieces used by European (and European-style) armies in the 17th to 20th centuries, the howitzer stood between the "gun" (characterized by a longer barrel, larger propelling charges, smaller shells, higher velocities, and flatter trajectories) and the "mortar" (which was meant to fire at even higher angles of ascent and descent). Howitzers, like other artillery equipment, are usually organized in groups called batteries.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]榴弹炮是一种火炮，其特点是枪管相对较短，使用相对较小的推进剂装药推动炮弹在相对较高的弹道上飞行，在第十七至第二十世纪的欧洲（和欧洲风格）军队使用的火炮部件的分类中，榴弹炮位于“枪”之间（其特点是炮筒较长、推进力大、炮弹小、速度快，以及更平坦的轨迹）和“迫击炮”（其目的是以更高的上升和下降角度开火）。榴弹炮和其他炮兵装备一样，通常被组织成一组，称为炮兵连。

TEXT.English: [H1]Sargon the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Akkad, Kish, Lagash, Umma and Uruk[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] c.2334 - 2279 BC[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Sargon of Akkad, also known as Sargon the Great was an Akkadian emperor famous for his conquest of the Sumerian city-states in the 23rd and 22nd centuries BC. The founder of the Dynasty of Akkad, Sargon reigned during the last quarter of the third millennium BC. Cuneiform sources agree that he was cup-bearer (official in charge of wine) of king Ur-Zababa of Kish, and some later historians have speculated that he killed the king and usurped his throne before embarking on the quest to conquer Mesopotamia. He was originally referred to as Sargon I until records concerning an Assyrian king also named Sargon (now usually referred to as Sargon I) were unearthed.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sargon's vast empire is thought to have included large parts of Mesopotamia, and included parts of modern-day Iran, Asia Minor and Syria. He ruled from a new, but as yet archaeologically unidentified capital, Akkad, which the Sumerian king list claims he built (or possibly renovated). He is sometimes regarded as the first person in recorded history to create a multiethnic, centrally ruled empire, although the Sumerians Lugal-anne-mundu and Lugal-zage-si also have a claim. His dynasty controlled Mesopotamia for around a century and a half (150 years).
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]吉尔伽美什[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]乌鲁克国王[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]背景:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]吉尔伽美什约生于在公元前2500年左右，他是苏美尔当时最大城市乌鲁克的王。据说他有三分之二神的血统（他母亲是女神南松），因而有关他的历史总是和传奇故事纠缠在一起，其中形象最鲜明的就是《吉尔伽美什史诗》。这部史诗最早的抄本写于公元前1700年，差不多是这位圣君去世一千年之后的事了，因此我们很难分辨哪些内容是史实，哪些是演义。不过，《吉尔伽美什史诗》还是描绘出了英雄吉尔伽美什最清晰的影像。[PARAGRAPH:1]说吉尔伽美什是个铁腕君主就再合适不过了。他曾立下法令，将全城少女的初夜权据为己有。这触怒了乌鲁克的臣民，人们祈求神灵惩治他的恶行。但是吉尔伽美什治下的乌鲁克非常繁荣。史诗的作者称，乌鲁克有众多宏伟的工程，其中的佼佼者就是伊什塔尔（苏美尔神话中司爱情的女神）大神殿。然而，吉尔伽美什最伟大的功绩还数他修建了环绕乌鲁克的高大而厚实的城墙。这道城墙成为砖石结构建筑史上的绝唱。[PARAGRAPH:1]吉尔伽美什经历过种种险境。他曾只身穿越一片广袤的杉树林，还曾为了寻求长生不老的秘密而杀死怪兽洪巴巴。尽管吉尔伽美什的旅程满溢着魔幻色彩，人们还是普遍认为史诗的有些内容是可信的，其中最突出的就是吉尔伽美什主持乌鲁克城墙的修建工作。况且，就算吉尔伽美什的真实面貌从此消失在历史长河中，这位乌鲁克圣王的英名也将和这人类的第一部史诗一起永垂世间。

TEXT.English: [H1]Francisco Franco Bahamonde[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Head of the Spanish State[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1892 - 1975 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1] Franco led a successful military career and reached the rank of General. He fought in Morocco and suppressed a strike in 1934 to defend the Republican government's stability. In February 1936, the left-wing Popular Front won the general election and formed a government. A period of severe instability and disarray followed the election, with escalating violence between left and right wing supporters. Anti-clerical violence against the Church by leftist militants further raised tensions. After the assassination of a major opposition figure, José Calvo Sotelo, by a commando unit of the Assault Guards in July 1936, Franco participated in a coup d'etat against the elected Popular Front government. The coup failed and evolved into the Spanish Civil War during which he emerged as the leader of the Nationalists against the Popular Front. After winning the civil war, he dissolved the Spanish Parliament, establishing an authoritarian regime that lasted until 1978, when a new constitution was drafted. During the Second World War, Franco maintained a policy of neutrality, although he did assist Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy on a small scale against the Soviet Union, most famously by sending troops (known as the Blue Division) to aid Nazi Germany in fighting the USSR. Before the invasion of the Soviet Union by the German Army, Franco and Hitler met in Hendaye on October 23, 1940. During the Cold War, the United States established a diplomatic alliance with Franco, due to his strong anti-Communist policy. American President Richard Nixon toasted Franco, and, after Franco's death, stated: "General Franco was a loyal friend and ally of the United States." After his death Spain began a transition to democracy.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Civil War had ravaged the Spanish economy. Infrastructure had been damaged, workers killed, and daily business severely hampered. For more than a decade after Franco's victory, the economy improved little. Franco initially pursued a policy of autarky, cutting off almost all international trade. The policy had devastating effects, and the economy stagnated. Economic growth picked up in 1959 after Franco took authority away from ideologues and gave more power to apolitical technocrats. The country implemented several development policies and growth took off creating the "Spanish Miracle". During the 1960s, the wealthy classes of Francoist Spain's population experienced further increases in wealth. It had the second-fastest growing economy in the world (the fastest being Japan). At the time of Franco's death, Spain still lagged behind most of Western Europe, but the gap between its GDP per capita and that of Western Europe had narrowed. After periods of rapid growth during the late 1980s and late 1990s, Spain now only lags slightly behind the economies of Britain, Ireland,France and Germany, and has now overtaken Italy on some measures.[PARAGRAPH:2]Spain attempted to retain control of its colonial empire throughout Franco's rule. During the Algerian War (1954-62), Madrid became the base of the Organisation de l'armée secrète (OAS) right-wing French Army group which sought to preserve French Algeria. Despite this, Franco was forced to make some concessions. Henceforth, when French Morocco became independent in 1956, he surrendered Spanish Morocco to Mohammed V, retaining only a few enclaves (the Plazas de soberanía). The year after, Mohammed V invaded Spanish Sahara during the Ifni War (known as the "Forgotten War" in Spain). Only in 1975, with the Green March, did Morocco take control of all of the former Spanish territories in the Sahara.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1968, due to United Nations' pressure, Franco granted Spain's colony of Equatorial Guinea its independence, and the next year, ceded the exclave of Ifni to Morocco. Under Franco, Spain also pursued a campaign to gain sovereignty of the British overseas territory of Gibraltar, and closed its border with Gibraltar in 1969. The border would not be fully reopened until 1985.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Spain and abroad, the legacy of Franco remains controversial. Symbols of the Franco regime (such as the national flag with the Imperial Eagle) are now banned by law, while the national anthem of Spain, the Marcha Real, is no longer accompanied by the lyrics introduced by Franco.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]西班牙国家[Brang] [Brut]头[\Brut] [NealLe] [Brd]：[\BOLD ] 1892到1975 AD [NealLe] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[Brd]（段落：1）Franco领导了成功的军事生涯并达到了将军的地位。他在摩洛哥作战，并于1934年镇压了一次罢工，以捍卫共和政府的稳定。1936年2月，左翼人民阵线赢得大选，组建政府。选举之后出现了一段严重的不稳定和混乱时期，左翼和右翼支持者之间的暴力不断升级。左派激进分子针对教会的反教士暴力进一步加剧了紧张局势。1936年7月，一名主要的反对派人物何塞·卡尔沃·索泰洛（JoséCalvo Sotelo）被突击卫队突击队暗杀后，佛朗哥参加了一场反对民选人民阵线政府的政变。政变失败，演变成西班牙内战，期间他成为反对人民阵线的民族主义者领袖。赢得内战后，他解散了西班牙议会，建立了一个独裁政权，一直持续到1978年新宪法起草时。在第二次世界大战期间，佛朗哥保持中立政策，尽管他在小范围内帮助纳粹德国和法西斯意大利对抗苏联，最著名的是派遣军队（称为蓝师）帮助纳粹德国与苏联作战。1940年10月23日，德军入侵苏联前，弗朗哥和希特勒在亨达耶会晤。冷战期间，由于弗朗哥强烈的反共政策，美国与他建立了外交联盟。美国总统理查德·尼克松向Franco致敬，在Franco去世后，他说：“Franco将军是美国忠实的朋友和盟友。”在他死后，西班牙开始向民主过渡。[第2段]内战蹂躏了西班牙经济。基础设施遭到破坏，工人丧生，日常业务严重受阻。佛朗哥获胜十多年来，经济几乎没有改善。佛朗哥最初奉行自给自足的政策，切断了几乎所有的国际贸易。这项政策产生了毁灭性的影响，经济停滞不前。1959年，佛朗哥从理论家手中夺走权力，把更多权力交给了非政治的技术官僚，经济增长开始回升。国家实施了多项发展政策，经济增长创造了“西班牙奇迹”。20世纪60年代，西班牙佛朗哥主义者的富裕阶层财富进一步增加。它拥有世界上第二快的经济增长（最快的是日本）。佛朗哥去世时，西班牙仍落后于西欧大部分地区，但人均国内生产总值与西欧的差距已经缩小。在上世纪80年代末和90年代末的快速增长之后，西班牙现在只落后于英国、爱尔兰、法国和德国的经济，现在已经超过了意大利的某些措施。[段落：2 ]西班牙试图在Franco统治下保持对其殖民帝国的控制。在阿尔及利亚战争期间（1954-62年），马德里成为法国右翼武装组织（OAS）的基地，该组织试图保护法属阿尔及利亚。尽管如此，佛朗哥还是被迫做出了一些让步。此后，1956年法属摩洛哥独立，他将西班牙摩洛哥交给穆罕默德五世，只保留了几个飞地（苏伯拉尼亚广场）。第二年，穆罕默德五世在伊夫尼战争（在西班牙被称为“被遗忘的战争”）中入侵西班牙撒哈拉。仅在1975，随着绿色游行，摩洛哥控制了撒哈拉以前所有西班牙领地。[第1968段]，由于联合国的压力，Franco授予西班牙殖民地赤道几内亚的独立权，并在第二年将Ifni的飞地割让给摩洛哥。在佛朗哥的领导下，西班牙还开展了争取英国海外领土直布罗陀主权的运动，并于1969年关闭了与直布罗陀的边界。直到1985，边界才完全开放。[段：2 ]在西班牙和国外，法兰克遗产仍然存在争议。佛朗哥政权的象征（如带有帝国鹰的国旗）现在已被法律禁止，而西班牙国歌《玛莎·雷亚尔》（Marcha Real）则不再配以佛朗哥介绍的歌词。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Logistics is generally the detailed organization and implementation of a complex operation. In a general business sense, logistics is the management of the flow of things between the point of origin and the point of consumption in order to meet requirements of customers or corporations. The resources managed in logistics may include tangible goods such as materials, equipment, and supplies, as well as food and other consumable items. The logistics of physical items usually involves the integration of information flow, materials handling, production, packaging, inventory, transportation, warehousing, and often security.[PARAGRAPH:2]Logistics management is the part of supply chain management that plans, implements, and controls the efficient, effective forward, and reverse flow and storage of goods, services, and related information between the point of origin and the point of consumption in order to meet customer's requirements. The complexity of logistics can be modeled, analyzed, visualized, and optimized by dedicated simulation software. The minimization of the use of resources is a common motivation in all logistics fields. A professional working in the field of logistics management is called a logistician.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]物流通常是一个复杂操作的详细组织和实施。在一般的商业意义上，物流是指为了满足顾客或企业的需求，对事物在起点和消费点之间的流动进行管理。物流管理的资源可以包括有形物品，如材料、设备和用品，以及食品和其他消费品。物流项目的物流通常涉及信息流、物料搬运、生产、包装、库存、运输、仓储以及安全性的集成。〔2〕物流管理是供应链管理的一部分，其计划、实施和控制高效、有效的正向和反向流程。并存储货物、服务以及原产地与消费地之间的相关信息，以满足客户的要求。物流的复杂性可以通过专用的仿真软件进行建模、分析、可视化和优化。最大限度地减少资源的使用是所有物流领域的共同动机。在物流管理领域工作的专业人员称为物流师。

TEXT.English: [TAB]During the 20th Century, the advent of the automobile has created an urban and suburban landscape in which people live in one area but can shop, play and work elsewhere - often miles away from their homes. Nowhere is this more true than in the United States of America, whose citizens are noted for an almost fanatical devotion to their cars. This has had important social, environmental and economic affects upon life in America, leading to (among other things) the creation of that most American of institution - the shopping mall.[PARAGRAPH:1]American shopping malls are surrounded by acres and acres of parking lots, and they may contain dozens (if not hundreds) of stores selling everything from clothing to jewelry to electronics to books to computers to videos. In some ways American shopping malls are akin in spirit to the old Arabian markets (although Americans don't particularly enjoy haggling and prices are generally fixed).[PARAGRAPH:1]The earliest automobile-centered shopping center was the "Market Square," opened in Chicago, Illinois, in 1916. Constructed in Minnesota in 1992, the "Mall of America" is the largest mall in the world. It contains over 500 shops, 80 restaurants, a theme park, hotel, and movie theatres. It is housed in a building large enough to hold over 30 Boeing 747 airplanes.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]在20世纪，汽车的出现创造了一种城市和郊区的景观，人们生活在一个地区，但可以在其他地方购物、玩耍和工作，通常离家数英里。这一点在美国最为真实，因为美国公民对汽车的热爱几乎是狂热的。这对美国的生活产生了重要的社会、环境和经济影响，导致了美国最为庞大的机构——购物中心的创建。（1：）美国购物中心周围有英亩的停车场，它们可能包含数十家（如果不是数百家）商店，销售从服装到珠宝、电子产品、书籍、电脑到视频等各种商品。在某些方面，美国购物中心与旧阿拉伯市场有着相似的精神（尽管美国人并不特别喜欢讨价还价，价格通常是固定的）。[段：1 ]最早的以汽车为中心的购物中心是“市场广场”，在1916的伊利诺斯芝加哥开张。“美国购物中心”建于1992年，是世界上最大的购物中心。它有500多家商店，80家餐厅，一个主题公园，酒店和电影院。它被安置在一座足以容纳30多架波音747飞机的大楼里。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Sydney Opera House is one of the grandest modern opera houses in the world. Constructed over a 20-year period ending in 1973, the Sydney Opera House is a beautiful building sitting atop Bennelong Point alongside Sydney Harbor in Sydney, Australia. Designed as a series of shells, or wings, the structure is one of the most recognizable in the world and it has come to symbolize Australia itself, in much the same way that the Statue of Liberty symbolizes the United States or the Great Pyramids symbolize Egypt. It houses an Opera Theatre, Concert Hall, three smaller venues, and a restaurant.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]悉尼歌剧院是世界上最宏伟的现代歌剧院之一。悉尼歌剧院建于1973年，历时20年，是一座坐落在澳大利亚悉尼悉尼港旁的本纳隆角上的美丽建筑。这座建筑被设计成一系列贝壳或翅膀，是世界上最著名的建筑之一，它已经成为澳大利亚本身的象征，就像自由女神像象征美国或大金字塔象征埃及一样。它有一个歌剧院、音乐厅、三个较小的场馆和一个餐厅。

TEXT.English: [H1]Suleiman I the Magnificent[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of the Ottoman Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1494 - 1566 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Suleiman I, known as "The Magnificent," "The Legislator" and "The Grand Turk," was the caliph of Islam and the sultan of the Ottoman Empire, taking the reigns of the Turkish kingdom in 1520 and ruling until his death in 1566.[PARAGRAPH:2]The only heir still breathing when his father Selim I passed on, Suleiman continued his father's tradition of expansion throughout the Middle East, creating a new level of prosperity within the empire. Suleiman's conquests reached from Baghdad to Egypt, making the Ottoman Empire the main channel through which the riches of the east could reach Europe. Ottoman naval supremacy in the Mediterranean further aided Suleiman's economic empire, the corsair Barbarossa sending innumerable European ships to the sea floor.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was this penchant for expansionism that struck fear into the heart of Europe. The Sultan's push northward took him as far as Hungary, where he found his progress stalled by the Hapsburg ruler Archduke Ferdinand I.[PARAGRAPH:2]While his territorial accomplishments were impressive, the Sultan did not ignore the culture of his homeland, Suleiman himself a skilled poet and fervent Muslim. Towards the end of his reign, Suleiman commissioned numerous new mosques of a previously unseen grandeur, designed by master architect, Sinan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Suleiman became well known in both the Christian west and the Muslim east, but for strikingly different reasons. Most Europeans envied the Sultan for the sheer opulence in which he lived. Celebrations of a previously unheard of grandeur were held at the Hippodrome in Istanbul. Rooms covered in gold, gems and the finest tapestries could be seen throughout the Sultan's palace at Topkapi.[PARAGRAPH:2]Muslims, on the other hand, respected the Sultan for his belief in the rule of law. The Sultan adopted Islamic sacred law to compliment the traditional law already in place from his predecessors. Both Christian and Muslim recognized the renewed strength and sense of honor that Suleiman brought to the Ottoman Empire, deeming him worthy of the title "The Magnificent."
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]苏莱曼一世[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]奥斯曼帝国苏丹[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]生卒年份:[\BOLD]1494年11月6日-1566年9月6日[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]背景:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]苏莱曼一世，以“大帝”，“立法者”和“大土耳其之君”闻名，是伊斯兰教的哈利发和奥斯曼土耳其帝国苏丹，于1520年继位统治土耳其王国直至1566年逝世。[PARAGRAPH:1]作为其父塞利姆一世身故之际仍在世的唯一继承人，苏莱曼既在中东各地发扬他父亲的扩张传统，又将帝国内部的繁荣提升至新的高度。苏莱曼的征服从巴格达直至埃及，使奥斯曼帝国成为东方财富得以进达欧洲的主要通道。奥斯曼在地中海的海上霸权更进一步加强了苏莱曼的经济帝国，巴巴罗萨的海盗船将无数欧洲船只葬送海底。[PARAGRAPH:1]其扩张主义倾向令欧洲从内心里感到恐惧。苏丹向北推进至匈牙利，直到他发现自己前进的步伐受阻于哈布斯堡王室的统治者费迪南一世大公。[PARAGRAPH:1]在他开疆拓土的成就令人印象深刻的同时，苏丹没有忽视祖国的文化，苏莱曼本人是熟练的诗人和虔诚的穆斯林。苏莱曼在统治后期委托建筑大师锡南设计了许多空前壮观的新清真寺。[PARAGRAPH:1]苏莱曼在基督教西方和穆斯林东方皆广为人知，但显然出于不同原因。大多数欧洲人因其奢华的生活而羡慕苏丹：前所未有的豪华的庆祝活动在伊斯坦布尔的赛马场举行。覆盖黄金的殿堂，珠宝和最好的挂毯在苏丹的托普卡匹宫比比皆是。[PARAGRAPH:1]而另一方面穆斯林因其在立法原则中体现出的信仰而尊敬苏丹。苏丹采用伊斯兰宗教法以向其先辈已实行的传统法律表达敬意。基督徒和穆斯林都承认苏莱曼带给奥斯曼帝国复兴的实力和荣誉感，认为他是当之无愧的“大帝”。

TEXT.English: [TAB]In Aztec culture, religion was inextricably woven into the fabric of daily life. The king was the leader of the nation; he also held high office in the religion. Aztec religious policies had the full force of law behind them. When a condemned criminal was executed, he was killed on the same sacrificial altars that the Aztecs used to sacrifice captured prisoners (and others) during religious rituals.[PARAGRAPH:1]Despite their bloodthirsty - even savage - reputation, the Aztecs had quite a sophisticated judicial system to protect both person and property. Each major city or town had a supreme judge. Once appointed, the supreme judge was totally independent of the monarchy; he wielded ultimate judicial control over his jurisdiction. Beneath the supreme judge was a three-member court, and beneath them were a group of lesser magistrates who were elected to their office by the people of the city. There is little evidence of corruption in the Aztec courts: judicial misconduct was punishable by death.[PARAGRAPH:1]Though the Aztecs could be considered barbaric by most modern standards, their justice system was fairly effective at deterring crime and keeping the peace. For example, there could not have been much theft in the cities: the Aztec residences were not equipped with locks or even bolts.
TEXT.Chinese: 在阿兹特克文化中，宗教与日常生活密不可分。国王是国家的领袖，他在宗教界也担任要职。阿兹特克的宗教政策背后有着充分的法律效力。当一个被判刑的罪犯被处死时，他在祭祀祭坛上被杀害，阿兹特克人在宗教仪式中牺牲俘虏（和其他人）。[段落：1 ]，尽管他们嗜血甚至野蛮的名声，阿兹特克人有相当复杂的司法制度来保护人和财产。每个主要城市或城镇都有最高法官。最高法官一经任命，就完全独立于君主政体；他对自己的管辖权行使最终的司法控制权。在最高法官下面是一个由三人组成的法院，在他们下面是一个由市人民选出的下级治安法官小组。阿兹特克法院几乎没有腐败的证据：司法不端行为被处以死刑。[段落：1 ]尽管阿兹特克人被大多数现代标准认为是野蛮的，但他们的司法系统在制止犯罪和维护和平方面相当有效。例如，在城市里不可能有太多的盗窃：阿兹特克的住宅没有配备锁，甚至没有螺栓。

TEXT.English: [H1]Dharmasetu[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Maharaja of Srivijaya[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 8th Century AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Dharmasetu was an 8th century Maharaja (high king) of Sri Vijaya. While we know little about him, he is commonly referred to as one of, if not the, greatest of the Sri Vijaya monarchs.[PARAGRAPH:2]During Dharmasetus reign, trade gradually started to relocate to cities in Indochina and away from the Sri Vijaya heartland. He solved this problem by sending raids over there and for a while Indrapura was actually controlled from Palembang (the Sri Vijaya capital). He also successfully incorporated Pan Pan, a kingdom located in the north of the Malay Peninsula into Srivijayan sphere of influence before 775 AD. A stele in Thailand also states that he constructed three sanctuaries dedicated to Bodhisattvas Padmapani, Vajrapani and Buddha in Ligor.[PARAGRAPH:2]He is also noted as head of the Saleindra, and this is the first instance of relationship known existed between Srivijaya and the Sailendra. Yet, he was the son of Jayanasa of Srivijaya and a princess from Tarumanagara. Dewi Tara, the daughter of Dharmasetu later married a member of the Sailendra family by the name of Samaratunga whom later would assumed throne of Srivijaya around 792. The relationship between Srivijaya and the Sailendra became intimately close afterwards.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1] DrasMeTu[[HealLe] [Brang] Srvijaya[Brut] [MurLay] [Brut]的MrHARAJA：[\BOLD ]八世纪Ad[新行] [NealLe] [Brut]背景：[ Brd]（段落：1）Dharmasetu是SRI Vijaya的八世纪Maalaja（高级国王）。虽然我们对他知之甚少，但他通常被称为斯里维亚王朝君主中的一个，如果不是的话。[段：2 ]在达摩马图斯统治期间，贸易逐渐开始迁移到印度支那的城市，远离斯里维亚亚的中心地带。他通过在那里发动突袭解决了这个问题，并在一段时间内，因陀罗普拉实际上是从巴邻港（斯里兰卡首都）控制的。他还成功地将位于公元前775年的马列半岛北部的一个王国合并为斯里维贾安势力范围。在泰国的一个碑铭中，他还建造了三座专用于Bodhisattvas Padmapani、维加拉尼和佛陀的庇护所。[段落：2 ]他也被称为Saleindra的首领。是斯里维贾亚和赛伦德拉之间存在关系的第一个例子。然而，他是斯里维贾亚的贾亚纳萨的儿子，也是塔鲁曼阿加拉的公主。德维塔拉，达摩塞图的女儿，后来嫁给了赛伦德拉家族的一个成员，名叫萨马拉通加，后来在792年左右成为斯利维亚的王位。斯里维贾亚和赛伦德拉之间的关系后来变得密切起来。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A Ho Trai is the library of a Thai Buddhist temple.[PARAGRAPH:1]For many centuries, the sacred Tripitaka scriptures had been written on palm leaves. To preserve the scriptures against humidity and against termites, the library was often built on columns to raise the storage from the ground. Bricks were preferably used in constructions to battle termites. Sometimes the Ho trai would be built, especially for this reason, above man-made ponds.[PARAGRAPH:1]Traditionally, the Tripitaka scriptures consisted of individual palm leaves, each measuring around 50 cm in length and around 4 to 6 cm in width. They were perforated and threaded in order to combine them in stacks of 20 to 40 pages. These stacks are kept pressed between two pieces of teakwood which is then wrapped in cloth and stored in a special bookcase. These bookcases are sometimes exquisitely crafted with mother-of-pearl inlay or with gold leaf applied on black lacquer. Beautiful examples of bookcases can be seen in the Bangkok National Museum. Modern Tripitaka are now printed as books.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAP]一个HO-TRAI是泰国佛教寺庙的藏书。[段：1 ]许多世纪以来，神圣的藏经经都是在棕榈叶上写的。为了保护经文不受潮湿和白蚁的侵害，图书馆常常建在柱子上，以便把仓库从地面上抬起来。砖块最好用在对抗白蚁的建筑中。有时，特别是出于这个原因，HO-TRAI将被建造在人工池塘之上。[段落：1 ]传统上，“三棱”经文由单个棕榈叶组成，每根棕榈叶的长度约为50厘米，宽度约为4至6厘米。它们被穿孔和穿线，以便将它们组合成20到40页的书堆。这些书堆被压在两块柚木之间，然后用布包裹，存放在一个特殊的书架上。这些书架有时用珍珠母镶嵌或用金叶涂在黑漆上精心制作。在曼谷国家博物馆可以看到漂亮的书架。现代的大藏经现在被印刷成书。

TEXT.English: [H1]'Aho'eitu[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of the Tu'i Tonga[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 10th Century AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]In Tongan mythology, or oral history, 'Aho'eitu is a son of the god Tangaloa 'Eitumatupu'a and a mortal woman, 'Ilaheva Va'epopua. He became the first king of the Tu'i Tonga (Tonga king) dynasty in the early 10th century, dethroning the previous one with the same name but originating from the uanga (maggots) instead of divine.[PARAGRAPH:2]When 'Aho'eitu was growing up he asked his mother about his father. His mother was a human woman from an area now known as Popua near the large lagoon of Tongatapu island. Aho eitu's mother told him that his father was a god living in the sky. When he had grown up he expressed the wish to find him. 'Ilaheva directed him to the great toa tree. The lad climbed up, went over the road as his mother had said and found his father catching doves. 'Eitumatupu'a was moved to see his son, and invited him to his house for kava and food. After that he sent him to his other sons, 'Aho'eitu's older halfbrothers, who were living in the sky, and at that moment playing sika-'ulu-toa (a dart throwing game with reeds having a head made from toa wood). When those young men found out that this good-looking boy was their brother, they got jealous, tore him in pieces, cooked him (or did not cook him, according to some sources) and ate him. Except his head, which was thrown in some hoi plants which have become poisonous ever since.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some time after 'Eitumatupu'a sent a woman to fetch 'Aho'eitu, but she returned with the message that the lad was not to be found. The god demanded his other sons to come and forced them by tickling their throats to vomit in a large wooden bowl. Noticing the head missing, 'Eitumatupu'a sent a messenger to find the head and also the bones. Everything was put in the bowl. Water was poured on it and the leaves of the nonufiafia, which is a known medicinal plant, able to revive people who were near death. The bowl then was put behind the house. They visited it from time to time, and at last they found 'Aho'eitu sitting up.[PARAGRAPH:2]They all were brought into 'Eitumatupu'a's house, and the god spoke angrily to his elder sons that they were murderers and that for punishment they had to stay in the sky, while 'Aho'eitu would descend to become king of Tonga. But now his older brothers repented and begged their father that they would be allowed to follow him. At last the god gave in, but stipulated that, even though they were older, they would become servants to 'Aho'eitu.
TEXT.Chinese: [H1] [UH'EITU[\H1] [Brut]国王Tu'i-Toua[\Brut] [NealLe] [Brut]生活：[\Brut]十世纪Ad[新行] [NurLang] [Brut]背景：[\Brut] [段落：1 ]在汤加神话或口述历史中，'AH'EITU是神Tangala 'EITUMUATUP' A的儿子和一位凡人“ILAHEVA VAEPUPUA”。他在十世纪初成为图伊汤加（汤加国王）王朝的第一个国王，废除了以前的同一个名字，但起源于Uanga（蛆）而不是神圣的。[段落：2 ]当A'E'u长大时，他问他母亲关于他的父亲。他的母亲是一个人类妇女，来自汤加塔普岛大泻湖附近的一个地区，现在被称为波普亚。阿霍伊图的母亲告诉他，他的父亲是一个生活在天上的神。他长大后表达了寻找他的愿望伊莱赫娃把他带到了大蟾蜍树上。小男孩爬上去，照他母亲说的走了一段路，发现父亲在抓鸽子Eitumatupu'a被感动去看他的儿子，并邀请他到他家吃卡瓦和食物。在那之后，他把他送到了他其他的儿子那里，他们是住在天上的阿霍伊图的同父异母哥哥，在那一刻，他们正在玩锡卡-乌卢-托亚（一种用芦苇做的飞镖游戏，芦苇的头是用蟾蜍木做的）。当这些年轻人发现这个英俊的男孩是他们的兄弟时，他们嫉妒了，把他撕成碎片，煮了他（或者据一些消息来源说，没有煮他），然后吃了他。除了他的头，它被扔在一些有毒的植物中。自从[伊特马图普’a在一段时间之后，一个女人派了一个女人去叫“阿霍”，但是她回来了，说他找不到那个小伙子。上帝要求他的其他儿子来，用挠痒痒的方法强迫他们在一个大木碗里呕吐。“Eitumatupu”发现头部不见了，于是派了一个使者去寻找头部和骨头。所有的东西都放在碗里了。水被倒在上面，诺非亚的叶子，这是一种已知的药用植物，能够救活濒临死亡的人。然后把碗放在房子后面。他们不时地去看它，最后他们发现AHE'EITU坐了起来。[段落：2 ]他们都被带到“伊图马图普”的房子里，上帝愤怒地对他年长的儿子说他们是凶手，惩罚他们必须呆在天上，而‘AH'EITU会下降成为汤加国王。但现在他的哥哥们悔改了，求他们的父亲允许他们跟随他。最后，上帝屈服了，但规定，即使他们年纪大了，也要成为“阿霍”伊图的仆人。

TEXT.English: [TAB]In modern, developed countries, gardens are often more valued for their aesthetic qualities than for their food growing functionality. However, in ancient civilizations such as Babylonia, gardens were an important source of nutrition for city dwelling families who otherwise could not purchase an adequate variety of food.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]在现代发达国家，园林往往更看重其美学品质，而不是其食物生长功能。然而，在古巴比伦尼亚等古代文明中，花园是城市居民家庭的重要营养来源，否则他们无法购买足够的食物。

TEXT.English: [H1]Dona Maria II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Queen Regent of Portugal and the Algarves[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1819 - 1853 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Dona Maria II was Queen regnant of Portugal from 1826 to 1828 and later from 1834 to 1853. She was the second Queen regnant of Portugal and the Algarves, and the 29th or 30th Portuguese monarch. She was a member of the House of Braganza.[NEWLINE]Born as Maria da Glória Joana Carlota Leopoldina da Cruz Francisca Xavier de Paula Isidora Micaela Gabriela Rafaela Gonzaga, Maria da Glória was the daughter of the future King of Portugal and first Emperor of Brazil, Peter IV and his first wife Maria Leopoldina, Archduchess of Austria, herself a daughter of Emperor Francis II. Born in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Maria is the only European monarch to not have been born in Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]When Maria's grandfather King John VI died in March 1826, there was a succession crisis in Portugal. The king had a male heir, Peter, but Peter had proclaimed the independence of Brazil in 1822 and he was then Emperor Peter I of that country. The late king also had a younger son, Miguel, but he was exiled in Austria after leading a number of revolutions against his father and his liberal regime.[NEWLINE]Before his death, the king had nominated his favourite granddaughter, Isabel Maria, to serve as regent until "the legitimate heir returned to the Kingdom" but he had failed to specify which of his sons was the legitimate heir. Peter, the liberal Emperor of Brazil, or Miguel, the absolutist exiled prince?[PARAGRAPH:2]Most people considered Peter to be the legitimate heir, but nobody wanted him to unite Portugal and Brazil's thrones again. The European country had been under Brazilian rule when both were part of the United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves, established by the King John VI during his stay in Rio de Janeiro from 1808 until 1820. Aware that his brother's supporters were ready to bring Miguel back and put him in the throne, Peter decided for a more consensual option; he abdicated the throne to his eldest daughter, Maria da Glria (who was only seven years old), and she should marry her uncle Miguel, who should accept the liberal constitution and act as a regent until his niece was an adult.[PARAGRAPH:2]Miguel pretended to accept, but when he arrived in Portugal he deposed Maria and proclaimed himself King, abrogating the liberal constitution in the process. During his reign of terror, Maria traveled to many European courts, including her grandfather's in Vienna, as well as London and Paris.[PARAGRAPH:2]Peter abdicated the Brazilian throne in 1831 in favor of his son (and Maria's younger brother, Peter II), and from his base in the Azores he attacked Miguel, forcing him to abdicate in 1834. Maria was thereupon restored to the throne, and obtained an annulment of her betrothal.[PARAGRAPH:2]On January 26, 1835 she married (at the age of fifteen) to Auguste, Duke of Leuchtenberg, son of Eugne de Beauharnais, and grandson of Empress Josephine. However, he died only two months later on March 28, 1835.[PARAGRAPH:2]On January 1, 1836 Maria married again, to the cultured and able Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, who ruled with her as a co-monarch. He received the title of King in 1837, in accordance with Portuguese custom, upon the birth of their first child Peter, an heir to the throne.[PARAGRAPH:2]Maria's reign saw a revolutionary insurrection on May 16, 1846, but this was crushed by royalist troops on February 22, 1847, and Portugal otherwise avoided the European upheavals of 1848. Maria's reign was also notable for a public health act aimed at curbing the spread of cholera throughout the country. She also pursued policies aimed at raising the levels of education throughout the country.[PARAGRAPH:2]After constant pregnancies and births, doctors warned Maria of the dangers of giving birth nearly every year. However, she ignored the risks that had killed her mother, who had died of complications following a miscarriage after many births; "If I die, I die at my post", Maria said. In 1853 she died while giving birth to her eleventh child, Prince Eugene, who also died.[PARAGRAPH:2]Maria II is remembered as a good mother and a kind person, who always acted according to her convictions in the attempt to help her country. She was later given the surname "The Good Mother." Also, in 1842, Pope Gregory XVI presented Maria with a Golden Rose.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The earliest practical use of chemical processes was by metal smiths of the ancient world. These artisans learned how to use heat to melt various naturally occurring metals together to form alloys such as bronze. Early manufacturers of cloth also used primitive chemical processes to set dyes. In the following centuries, chemical processes were studied through the pseudo-science of alchemy, which attempted to change base metals into gold. Although alchemists were, of course, unsuccessful, they did develop many valuable chemical processes as a result.[PARAGRAPH:2]The manuscripts produced by alchemists were studied by succeeding generations, and an effective knowledge of chemistry had been accumulated by the late 13th century. In the 17th century, the ideas of alchemy finally died out as an increasing body of true chemical knowledge was gained through experimental analysis, leading to the modern science of chemistry.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]化学的应用最初是由古代的金属工匠实现的。这些工匠们通过实践学会了如何将某些金属熔化以形成合金，如青铜等。而早期的纺织业在染色时也自然而然的用到了基本的化学知识。在之后的世纪中，化学由于炼金术的盛行而得到了极大的发展。尽管那些炼金术士们从未炼出金子，但他们确实发现了很多极有价值的化学反应。[PARAGRAPH:2]一代代的炼金术士不断研究着前人流传下来的研究手稿，由此保证了化学知识的不断积累和传递。终于在17世纪，炼金术渐渐消亡，通过实验和分析所积累起来的大量知识则为现代化学的产生奠定了基础。

TEXT.English: [TAB]For much of human history, victory has gone to those with access to the finest metals. From the Bronze Age onwards, metal tools, weapons and alloys have been an inherent part of the rise of civilization, spurring conquests and construction by the world's greatest empires. And while metal mining has had an impressive history, it was not until the nineteenth century that industrial mining truly began to take root.[PARAGRAPH:1]Two reasons explain this sudden intensification in mining operations. The first was the almost daily revolutions in the production of tools and consumer items, requiring a continual source of metal to produce them. The second was that the fuel that powered the Industrial Revolution was coal, nestled deep within the earth. In modern times, enormous excavators like the Bagger 288 have it possible to mine a pit three-hundred feet long and one-hundred feet deep in a day, a feat that, in the past, would have required the mobilization of nations.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]在人类历史的大部分时间里，胜利属于那些拥有最优质金属的人。从青铜时代开始，金属工具、武器和合金一直是文明崛起的内在组成部分，推动着世界上最大帝国的征服和建设。虽然金属开采有着令人印象深刻的历史，但直到十九世纪工业开采才真正开始生根。[第1段]解释了采矿业突然加剧的两个原因。第一次是几乎每天都在生产工具和消费品，需要不断的金属来源来生产它们。第二个原因是，推动工业革命的燃料是煤炭，位于地球深处。在现代，像Bagger 288这样的大型挖掘机有可能在一天内开采出一个三百英尺长、一百英尺深的矿井，这一壮举在过去需要动员各国。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The practice of communication by written documents carried by an intermediary from one person or place to another almost certainly dates back nearly to the invention of writing. However, development of formal postal systems occurred much later. The first documented use of an organized courier service for the diffusion of written documents is in Egypt, where Pharaohs used couriers for the diffusion of their decrees in the territory of the State (2400 BC).[PARAGRAPH:2]The first credible claim for the development of a real postal system comes from Ancient Persia but the point of invention remains in question. The best documented claim (Xenophon) attributes the invention to the Persian King Cyrus the Great (550 BC), while other writers credit his successor Darius I of Persia (521 BC). Other sources claim much earlier dates for an Assyrian postal system, with credit given to Hammurabi (1700 BC) and Sargon II (722 BC). Mail may not have been the primary mission of this postal service, however. The role of the system as an intelligence gathering apparatus is well documented, and the service was (later) called angariae, a term that in time turned to indicate a tax system. The Old Testament (Esther, VIII) makes mention of this system: Ahasuerus, king of Medes, used couriers for communicating his decisions.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Persian system worked on stations (called Chapar-Khaneh), where the message carrier (called Chapar) would ride to the next post, whereupon he would swap his horse with a fresh one, for maximum performance and delivery speed. Herodotus described the system in this way: "It is said that as many days as there are in the whole journey, so many are the men and horses that stand along the road, each horse and man at the interval of a day's journey; and these are stayed neither by snow nor rain nor heat nor darkness from accomplishing their appointed course with all speed".[PARAGRAPH:2]The economic growth and political stability under the Mauryan empire (322-185 BC) saw the development of impressive civil infrastructure in ancient India. The Mauryans developed early Indian mail service as well as public wells, rest houses and other facilities for the common public. Common chariots called Dagana were sometimes used as mail chariots in ancient India.[PARAGRAPH:2]In ancient times the kings, emperors, rulers, zamindars or the feudal lords protected their land through the intelligence services of specially trained police or military agencies and courier services to convey and obtain information through runners, messengers and even through pigeons. The chief of the secret service, known as the postmaster, maintained the lines of communication... The people used to send letters to their distant relatives through their friends or neighbors.[PARAGRAPH:2]Early stamps of India were watermarked with an elephant's head. [PARAGRAPH:2]In South India, the Wodeyar dynasty (1399 - 1947) of the Kingdom of Mysore used mail service for espionage purposes thereby acquiring knowledge related to matters that took place at great distances.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the end of the 18th century the postal system in India had reached impressive levels of efficiency. According to British national Thomas Broughton, the Maharaja of Jodhpur sent daily offerings of fresh flowers from his capital to Nathadvara (320 km) and they arrived in time for the first religious Darshan at sunrise. Later this system underwent complete modernization when the British Raj established its full control over India. The Post Office Act XVII of 1837 provided that the Governor-General of India in Council had the exclusive right of conveying letters by post for hire within the territories of the East India Company. The mails were available to certain officials without charge, which became a controversial privilege as the years passed. On this basis the Indian Post Office was established on October 1, 1837.[PARAGRAPH:2]China enjoyed postal relay stations since the Han dynasty (206 BC-220 AD). During the Yuan Dynasty under Kublai Khan, China was integrated into the much larger Örtöö system of the Mongol Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]The first well documented postal service is that of Rome. Organized at the time of Augustus Caesar (62 BC-AD 14), it may also be the first true mail service. The service was called cursus publicus and was provided with light carriages called rhed脙娄 with fast horses. Additionally, there was another slower service equipped with two-wheeled carts (birol脙娄) pulled by oxen. This service was reserved for government correspondence. Another service for citizens was later added.[PARAGRAPH:2]Genghis Khan installed an empire-wide messenger and postal station system named Örtöö within the Mongol Empire. During the Yuan Dynasty under Kublai Khan, this system also covered the territory of China. Postal stations were used not only for the transmission and delivery of official mail, but were also available for traveling officials, military men, and foreign dignitaries. These stations aided and facilitated the transport of foreign and domestic tribute, and trade in general. By the end of Kublai Khan's rule there were more than 1400 postal stations in China alone, which in turn had at their disposal about 50000 horses, 1400 oxen, 6700 mules, 400 carts, 6000 boats, over 200 dogs and 1150 sheep.[PARAGRAPH:2]The stations were 15 to 40 miles apart and had reliable attendants working for the mail service. Foreign observers, such as Marco Polo have attested to the efficiency of this early postal system.[PARAGRAPH:2]Another important postal service was created in the Islamic world by the caliph Mu'awiyya; the service was called barid, by the name of the towers built to protect the roads by which couriers travelled.[PARAGRAPH:2]Well before the Middle Ages and during them, homing pigeons were used for pigeon post, taking advantage of a singular quality of this bird, which when taken far from its nest is able to find his way home due to a particularly developed sense of orientation. Messages were then tied around the legs of the pigeon, which was freed and could reach his original nest.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mail has been transported by quite a few other methods throughout history, including dogsled, balloon, rocket, mule, pneumatic tubes and even submarine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many religious orders had a private mail service, notably Cistercians ' one connected more than 6,000 abbeys, monasteries and churches. The best organization however was created by the Knights Templar. The newly instituted universities too had their private services, starting from Bologna (1158).[PARAGRAPH:2]Popular illiteracy was accommodated through the service of scribes. Illiterates who needed to communicate dictated their messages to a scribe, another profession now quite generally disappeared.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1505, Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I established a postal system in the Empire, appointing Franz von Thurn und Taxis to run it. The Thurn and Taxis family, then known as Tassis, had operated postal services between Italian city states from 1290 onwards. Following the abolition of the Empire in 1806 the Thurn and Taxis postal system continued as a private organisation, continuing to exist into the postage stamp era before finally being absorbed into the postal system of the new German Empire after 1871.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the United Kingdom, prior to 1840 the postal system was expensive, confusing and seen as corrupt. Letters were paid for by the recipient rather than the sender, and were charged according to the distance the letter had travelled and the number of sheets of paper it contained. If there is one man who can be said to have changed the face of the postal service forever it is Sir Rowland Hill, with his reforms of the postal system based on the concept of penny postage, and his solution of pre payment. In his proposal Hill also called for official pre-printed envelopes and adhesive postage stamps as alternative ways of getting the sender to pay for the postage, at a time when prepayment was optional, which led to the invention of the postage stamp, the Penny Black.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was around this time nationalization and centralization of most postal systems took place. Today, the study of mail systems is known as postal history.[PARAGRAPH:2]The postal system was important in the development of modern transportation. Railroads carried railway post offices. During the 20th century, air mail became the transport of choice for inter-continental mail. Postmen started to utilize mail trucks. The handling of mail became increasingly automated.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Internet came to change the conditions for physical mail. E-mail (and in recent years social networking sites) became a fierce competitor, but online auctions and Internet shopping opened new business opportunities as people often get items bought online through the mail.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]由中介人从一个人或一个地方携带到另一个人的书面文件进行交流的做法几乎可以肯定地追溯到写作发明的年代。但是，正式邮政系统的开发发生的时间要晚得多。在埃及，有组织的快递服务首次用于散布书面文件，这是法老王首次利用信使在该国领土上散布其法令。[PARAGRAPH：2]真正的邮政系统的发展来自古代波斯，但发明的重点仍然存在。记载最充分的索赔（Xenophon）将发明归功于波斯国王居鲁士大帝（550 BC），而其他作家则将其继承人波斯的大流士一世（Darius I）（521 BC）归功于此。其他消息来源声称亚述邮政系统的日期要早得多，这要归功于Hammurabi（公元前1700年）和Sargon II（公元前722年）。但是，邮件可能不是该邮政服务的主要任务。该系统作为情报收集设备的作用已得到充分证明，该服务（后来）被称为“安格里亚伊”（anariae），该术语随即转为表示税制。旧约圣经（Esther，VIII）提到了这个系统：Medes之王Ahasuerus使用快递员传达了他的决定。[PARAGRAPH：2]波斯语系统在信息载体（称为Chapar-Khaneh）的站点（称为Chapar-Khaneh）上工作称为Chapar）将骑到下一个职位，随后他将他的马换成新的，以最大程度地提高性能和交付速度。希罗多德斯用这种方式描述了这个系统：“据说，整个旅程有很多天，沿路站立的人和马太多了，每匹马和人在一天的旅程中间隔一遍；以及这些都没有被雪，雨，热或黑暗所阻止，无法全速地完成其指定的路线。[PARAGRAPH：2]莫里扬帝国（公元前322-185年）下的经济增长和政治稳定见证了令人印象深刻的民用基础设施的发展在古代印度。 Mauryans开发了早期的印度邮件服务以及公共井，休息室和其他公共设施。在古印度，有时将称为Dagana的普通战车用作邮递战车。[PARAGRAPH：2]在古代，国王，皇帝，统治者，zamindars或封建领主通过受过专门训练的警察或军事机构及信使的情报服务来保护自己的土地。通过跑步者，信使甚至鸽子传递和获取信息的服务。特勤局局长被称为邮政局长，维持着沟通渠道……人们过去常常通过朋友或邻居向远方亲戚发信。[PARAGRAPH：2]印度早期的邮票印有大象的水印。头。 [PARAGRAPH：2]在印度南部，迈索尔王国的Wodeyar王朝（1399年至1947年）使用邮件服务进行间谍活动，从而获得了与远距离事件相关的知识。[PARAGRAPH：2] 18世纪，印度的邮政系统达到了令人印象深刻的效率水平。根据英国国民托马斯·布劳顿（Thomas Broughton）的说法，焦特布尔的大公每天从他的首都向纳萨德瓦拉（320公里）献花，他们赶在日出时赶到了第一个宗教达尔山。后来，当英国王朝建立对印度的完全控制权时，该系统经历了完全现代化。 1837年的《第十七号邮局法》规定，印度总督会同行政会议享有在东印度公司领土内以邮递方式出租信件的专有权。这些邮件免费提供给某些官员，随着时间的流逝，这成为有争议的特权。在此基础上，印度邮政局于1837年10月1日成立。[PARAGRAPH：2]自汉朝（公元前206年至220年）以来，中国便享有邮政中继站。元朝时期，在忽必烈汗（Kublai Khan）的领导下，中国融入了蒙古帝国更大的Örtöö系统。[PARAGRAPH：2]第一个有据可查的邮政服务是罗马。它是在奥古斯都·凯撒（Augustus Caesar）（公元前62年-公元14年）成立时组织的，它也许也是第一个真正的邮件服务。这项服务被称为“ cursus publicus”，并配备了名为“rhedÃ”的轻便马车和快马。此外，还有另一项较慢的服务，配备了由牛拉动的两轮小车（birolÃ¦）。该服务保留给政府来往。 [PARAGRAPH：2]成吉思汗在蒙古帝国内部安装了整个帝国的信使和邮政系统，名为Örtöö。元朝在忽必烈汗统治下，这一制度也覆盖了中国的领土。邮政站不仅用于公务邮件的传输和传递，而且还用于旅行官员，军人和外国要人。这些车站帮助和便利了外国和国内贡品的运输以及一般贸易。到忽必烈汗统治结束时，仅在中国就有1400多个邮政站，而这些邮政站又为他们提供了约5万匹马，1400头牛，6700 les，400辆车，6000艘船，200多只狗和1150只绵羊。[PARAGRAPH ：2]这些站相距15至40英里，并且有可靠的服务员为邮件服务工作。马可·波罗（Marco Polo）等外国观察员已经证明了这种早期邮政系统的效率。[PARAGRAPH：2]哈里发穆阿维雅在伊斯兰世界创造了另一项重要的邮政服务； [PARAGRAPH：2]在中世纪之前，在中世纪之前，他们都利用归巢的鸽子作为鸽舍，因此这项服务被称为barid，是为了保护快递员所经过的道路而建造的。这只鸟的巢穴，由于其特别发达的定向感，在远离巢穴时能够找到回家的路。然后将信息绑在鸽子的腿上，鸽子的腿被释放并可以到达其最初的巢。[PARAGRAPH：2]邮件在整个历史中还通过其他多种方法运输，包括狗拉雪橇，气球，火箭，ule子，气动管[PARAGRAPH：2]许多宗教团体都有私人邮件服务，特别是西多会的一员将6000多个修道院，修道院和教堂连接起来。然而，最好的组织是由圣殿骑士团创建的。从博洛尼亚（1158）开始，新成立的大学也提供私人服务。[PARAGRAPH：2]通过文士服务来普及文盲。需要交流的文盲将其信息传达给抄写员，现在另一个职业普遍消失了。[PARAGRAPH：2] 1505年，神圣罗马帝国皇帝马克西米利安一世在帝国建立了一个邮政系统，任命弗朗茨·冯·图恩和出租车来运营它。 Thurn and Taxis家族（当时称为Tassis）从1290年开始在意大利各城市之间运营邮政服务。在1806年帝国废除之后，瑟恩和的士邮政系统继续作为一个私人组织，继续存在于邮票时代，直到1871年以后被新德意志帝国的邮政系统吸收。[PARAGRAPH：2]英国，在1840年之前，邮政系统昂贵，令人困惑，并被视为腐败。信件是由收件人而不是发件人支付的，并根据信件行进的距离和所含纸张的数量收费。如果有人可以说永远改变了邮政服务的面貌，那就是罗兰·希尔爵士，他根据便士邮费的概念对邮政系统进行了改革，并解决了预付款问题。在他的提案中，希尔还呼吁使用官方预打印的信封和不干胶邮票作为让发件人支付邮费的替代方式，而在这种情况下，预付是可选的，这导致了邮票Penny Black的发明。 [PARAGRAPH：2]大约是在这个时候，大多数邮政系统都被国有化和集中化。今天，对邮件系统的研究被称为邮政历史。[PARAGRAPH：2]邮政系统在现代交通发展中非常重要。铁路运输铁路邮局。在20世纪，航空邮件成为洲际邮件的首选运输方式。邮递员开始使用邮件卡车。邮件的处理变得越来越自动化。[PARAGRAPH：2]互联网开始改变物理邮件的条件。电子邮件（以及近年来的社交网站）成为了激烈的竞争者，但是在线拍卖和互联网购物为人们带来了新的商机，因为人们经常通过邮件在网上购买商品。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Pyramid of the Sun is the largest building in Teotihuacan and one of the largest in Mesoamerica. Found along the Avenue of the Dead, in between the Pyramid of the Moon and the Ciudadela, and in the shadow of the massive mountain Cerro Gordo, the pyramid is part of a large complex in the heart of the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The name Pyramid of the Sun comes from the Aztecs, who visited the city of Teotihuacan centuries after it was abandoned; the name given to the pyramid by the Teotihuacanos is unknown. It was constructed in two phases. The first construction stage, around 100 AD, brought the pyramid to nearly the size it is today. The second round of construction resulted in its completed size of 225 meters across and 75 meters high, making it the third largest pyramid in the world, but being much shorter than the Great Pyramid of Giza (146 meters). The second phase also saw the construction of an altar atop of the pyramid, which has not survived into modern times. The Adosada platform was added to the pyramid in the early third century, at around the same time that the Ciudadela and Temple of the Feathered Serpent, Teotihuacan Pyramid of the Feathered Serpent were constructed.
